Assets/Collections/Incidents/A Favor For: "Hmm... gossip about the %QUESTGOSSIPFACTION%, in %QUESTTIME% days? I can do that."
"I don't have time for that, Pierre."

You enter Pierre's office to find it more disorderly than usual, with Pierre pacing frantically in the midst of all the chaos. 

He looks up at you and exclaims "Ah, madame! Thank God you've arrived!"
"However I am at a loss for such information. If you can get me something in the next %QUESTTIME% days, then I'll reward you with %QUESTREWARD%, in addition to your regular finder's fee."
"Ah, fantastique, madame! I just knew you were the perfect woman for the job." He replies with an excited grin. "I already await your success with baited breath!"
His expression sours at this rejection. "I see... fine, I shall simply have to find other ways to sate our readership's needs for the light of truth."
"Do you feel up to the task?"
"I have been keenly checking the winds of public opinion, and my finely honed journalistic senses tell me that our readership desperately cries out for stories concerning the %QUESTGOSSIPFACTION%."
Assets/Collections/Incidents/A Lively Pl: "Everyone here seems to be having a great time, and I can't blame them. This is a lot of fun."
"If I wanted drunk strangers and rustic music, then I would have stayed back in the village."
"If I wanted drunk strangers and rustic music, then I would have stayed back in the village."
Feeling like you could use some fresh air, you decide to take your travels to the edge of the Paris. As much as you like the city, the change of pace is appreciated.
Passing through a checkpoint at the city's outer wall, you hear the sounds of music and raucous laughter.
Turning a corner you stumble upon an idyllic looking establishment named 'Guinguette Paradis'. A band plays music, while the patrons drink wine and dance.
Sitting down at one of the rustic tables, you note down the guinguette in your journal.
After a spending a few hours taking in the crowds and bobbing in time with the lively music, you decide to head home, but you have a feeling you'll be back there soon.
The entertainment may be on the coarse side for some, but it's perfect for those that just want to relax and have fun.
With a shake of your head you turn and start the long walk home. The music fades into the distance and you welcome the hustle, bustle, and sophistication at the heart of Paris.
(Guinguette Paradis is now an available rendezvous location)
Assets/Collections/Incidents/A Promenade: "It's nice to get a break from Paris sometimes."
"Walking in circles doesn't feel like my idea of a fun evening."

Deciding to explore the 5th arrondisement today, you stroll along the southern banks of the river Seine. Barges sail up and down the river, jockeying for position with the pleasure crafts of the wealthy, and the ocassional floating bathhouse. A merry patron of one such bathhouse waves to you from the comfort of his tub.
Just as you cross the street, you spot a verdant clearing ahead of you.

Looking around at the well manicured greenery, you realize that you've arrvied at the Jardin Des Plantes. It's beautiful and tranquil. A lush respite from the bustle and cacophany of the city. Couples stroll the paths, arm in arm. Furtive glances and nods of respect are exchanged between passing groups, as people put forth their best efforts to see and be seen.
Pulling out your journal, you jot down the location. (Jardin Des Plantes is now an available rendezvous location)
After lingering a few minutes further, you head home. Hopefully, you'll be able visit the gardens again soon.
You head home immediately, taking a detour through some of the more lively parts of time in order to get your energy back up again. Hopefully, you won't have occassion to visit the gardens too often.
This is the perfect place to go with someone who wanted to get some fresh air, without the oppressing crowds of the city.
This is the perfect place to go with someone who wanted to get some fresh air, without the oppressing crowds of the city.

Strolling through the 6th arrondissement, you weave your way through crowds of excited students, pontificating intellectuals, and agitated artists. It feels like every corner is home to another gallery, or part of the various academies strewn throughout the district.

Your nose picks up the scent of fine coffee and you find yourself subconsciously gravitating towards the origin of this delightful smell. The closer you get to the source of the scent, the thicker the crowds become.
"What say you?" One of the patrons asks you, suddenly.

You say your goodbyes to the various patrons of the cafe and head home, with a little more knowledge than you had before.
"What say you?" One of the patrons asks you, suddenly.
"What say you?" One of the patrons asks you, suddenly.
"What say you?" One of the patrons asks you, suddenly.

You get drawn into a conversation about the Military and the Crown. Aristocratic officers are currently lobbying the king for the right to dress as they please at court, instead of wearing their uniforms. They feel that being forced to wear military livery casts them as servants, instead of leaders.

The generals are obviously unhappy about this.

You get drawn into a conversation about the Bourgeoisie and the Crown. Merchants in France want the taxes to be simplified, to make it easier to move goods around the country. The aristocrats say that the current system keeps the economy stable.
“If you insist, madame, I’ll leave you to your refreshments.”

You get drawn into a conversation about the Bourgeoisie and the Crown. Merchants in France want the taxes to be simplified, to make it easier to move goods around the country. The aristocrats say that the current system keeps the economy stable.

You get drawn into an argument between supporters of the Revolution and the Crown. Nationalists want to move France towards a constitutional government, but monarchists claim that France is in too tumultuous a state for such a radical transition.

You get drawn into a conversation about the Church and the Bourgeoisie. Members of the Bourgeoisie are saying the Church should no longer be exempt from taxation.

Apparently, due to skipped wages, soldiers have become notoriously delinquent on their debts, and some have even reacted violently when asked to pay. This has led to some shop owners refusing to do business with soldiers at all. 

Nobody's certain if that's right, or even legal.

You get drawn into a conversation about the Military and the Church. Given the rising tensions, patriotically minded people are asking where the loyalties of French priests lie. After all, the Catholic Church is a foreign government with its own laws. More pious citizens are saying that even asking that question is blasphemy, and that a priest's first duty is always to the people of thier parish.
“Oui, madame. I shall fetch you free water, while you occupy a table in our busy cafe.”

You get drawn into a conversation about the Military and the Church. Given the rising tensions, patriotically minded people are asking where the loyalties of French priests lie. After all, the Catholic Church is a foreign government with its own laws. More pious citizens are saying that even asking that question is blasphemy, and that a priest's first duty is always to the people of thier parish.

You get drawn into a conversation about the Bourgeoisie and the Revolution. Times have been hard for the poorest people of Paris and some believe that the richest members of the common people have a duty to provide food and other assistance to the poor. Others are saying that without the nobility or the church paying taxes, the wealthiest commoners are already paying the lion's share of taxes and can't afford to keep giving away their money.

You get drawn into a conversation about the Bourgeoisie and the Revolution. Times have been hard for the poorest people of Paris and some believe that the richest members of the common people have a duty to provide food and other assistance to the poor. Others are saying that without the nobility or the church paying taxes, the wealthiest commoners are already paying the lion's share of taxes and can't afford to keep giving away their money.

You get drawn into a conversation about the Revolution and the Military. Nationalists are upset that the military has been disbursing protests and other political gatherings. Soldiers claim they following their orders from the king, as required by law.

You get drawn into a conversation about the Revolution and the Military. Nationalists are upset that the military has been disbursing protests and other political gatherings. Soldiers claim they following their orders from the king, as required by law.
“Is there anything else I can get you?”
With a scowl, she skulks away to attend to the other customers, while you applaud yourself for your thriftiness. She shortly returns with your water, which is surprisingly cool and refreshing.
Instantly, the woman is all smiles, once again. “Oh yes, an excellent choice madame!”

Eventually, you arrive at a bustling coffee house with large glass windows. The sign outside reads 'Cafe Principe'. Your heart sinks at the site of the massive crowd of students milling around outside the cafe. It doesn’t look like you’ll be able to get in at all.
As for the women, they are... prostitutes.”
At the sound of fresh giggling from Monsieur Boehmer’s table she leans in close to you and whispers behind her hand “He’s not actually that funny, the laughing is just good for business.”
“Is there anything else you’d like to know about?”

“Oh, the cafe!” the woman exclaims, suddenly understanding your point. “Don’t worry, everything here is pretty simple, I’ve watched it play out with our patrons the same way everyday, for the last few years.”

“First you come in and sit down, and order something. While we can’t make you order anything, we would strongly prefer that you order some coffee.” She stops to stare at you significantly for a moment. 

“The coffee also perks you up, and makes you less exhausted, if you’re feeling tired. It’s no substitute for sleep, but it’s a start!”

“After you get your drink, you can settle in and listen to our patrons here. Everyone here is obsessed with politics, so it’s a great place to find out who among the high and mighty is doing particularly well at the moment. Everything is always shifting in Paris, so it’s nice to come in regularly and stay on top of things.”

“Once you’ve listened for a while, you’ll probably get dragged into one of the debates. Be carefully with your answer, as news travels fast. Depending on who you support in the debate, you can earn some favor with one faction, and lose some reputation with another.”
“After that? You head home with a little more energy, a little more knowledge, and hopefully you’re a little more well liked. That’s all there is, really!”
“Now, if you can excuse me madame, I must get back to my other tables.”

She favors you with a quick curtsey before leaving. You sip at your drink and get settled in. It feels familiar in a way, like a louder and livelier version of ‘Le Cygne’, the tavern you used to frequent back home

However, before you can give up on this venture, a woman in a coffee stained apron emerges from the door. She loudly asks if any of the students are actually interested in buying anything, or if they’re just hanging around to look important.

She favors you with a quick curtsey before leaving. You sip at your drink and get settled in. It feels familiar in a way, like a louder and livelier version of ‘Le Cygne’, a tavern you used to frequent back home.

Taking out your journal and a traveler’s pencil, you close your eyes and relax, just focusing on listening to the whole bustling cafe. Not focusing on one individual conversation, but just letting the sum total of the room flow into your ears, and then assessing it all together. Occasionally, you open your eyes to jot down a quick note.

It doesn’t take long to realize that the Crown isn’t just more powerful than the Revolution, but that the difference in power is massive. The nationalists in the Third Estate have quite a fight ahead of them if they want to make the Crown give into their demands.

After a few minutes, it becomes obvious that the Crown is significantly more powerful than the Revolution. While it might be possible for the Revolution to make the Crown give into their demands, they would have to build strong alliances with the other factions in order to do so.

It takes a while before you come to the conclusion that the Crown is more powerful than the Revolution. The difference in power, however, is not that large. In fact, it wouldn’t take a great reversal of fortune for the Crown to find themselves on their back foot. Maintaining strong alliances from the other factions will be important to their success.

You listen for what feels like an hour and you still can’t draw any solid conclusions. It seems like the Crown and the Revolution are so evenly matched that you can’t determine which one would prevail in any sort of conflict. Assets/Collections/Incidents/Fine Dining: "Exquisite food and an elegant atmosphere. This is exactly what I was looking for."
"I'm sure the food is good, but this is a little too stuffy for my tastes."
Deciding to spend the day exploring Paris, your wanderings take you to the 12th arrondisement.

Just as you feel you've become used to the city's myriad smells, your nose manages to pick up a new, suprising scent. Flavorful, yet subtle. Layered, but restrained.

You've smelled good food before, but this is something else entirely.
Quickening your pace, you find a sign that reads 'La GrandeTaverne de Londres'. This is slightly puzzling, as it looks nothing like the rustic taverns you've seen elsewhere in France.

Inside, you find a dining room brightly lit by crystal chandeliers, and furnished with mahogany tables draped in fine linen tablecloths. A few aristocrats look up from their table at you, and you suddenly feel rather underdressed in your day clothes.
You pull out your journal and jot the address down. (La Grande Taverne de Londres is now an available rendezvous location)
You spend a few minutes chatting with the staff and perusing the menu before you head home, visions of a feast dancing in your head. Perhaps you'll be able to return, sometime soon.
This feels like the perfect place to visit with someone who cares about fine food, and prefers a formal setting.
Without even so much as a 'bonjour' to the proprietor, you decide to head home. Already, you're looking forward to one of Camille's home cooked meals, which you can eat however you like.
Assets/Collections/Incidents/Frivolous F: "This is absolutely ridiculous, and I can't wait to come back."
"I don't think I could take too much of this for very long."

Travelling the northern section of the 8th arrondisement, the sky is clear and the sun is shining. The crowds in this part of the city are picking up and, out of curiosity, you head in the same general direction.
The sight that greets your eyes is nothing short of surreal.

A massive garden, dotted with all sorts of fantastic buildings. Small Egyptian pyramids, Roman columns, Turkish tents, and more all cluster around a sparkling lake. People in costume strut about the different buildings, enthralling tourists with fantastic tales of dubious authenticity.

Still, it looks like everyone is having fun.
It's fun and tacky, the kind of place to take someone that doesn't take themselves too seriously.
After a quick loop around the gardens, you head home. Already you're dreaming of excuse to head back, and trying to figure out who else you know that might appreciate Parc Monceau as much as you do.

Turning on your heel, you head home. While you're not particularly enthralled by the gardens and the gaudy attractions therein, you wonder who you know that would possibly be interested in that sort of thing.

This must be Parc Monceau, created by the fabulously wealthy Duke of Chartres. Taking note of your surroundings, you jot the location down in your journal. (Parc Monceau is now an available rendezvous location)
Assets/Collections/Incidents/Le Petit Mo: "I have an important party soon, and I need to look amazing." <No Tutorial>
"All of this is so new... what can you tell me about outfits and fashion?" <Tutorial>
"I have an important party soon, and I need to look amazing." <No Tutorial>
"All of this is so new... what can you tell me about outfits and fashion?" <Tutorial>

It’s a long walk to Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré, but the trek to the narrow street is worth it. Every block hums with a vibrant energy, bursting with life. Porters and social climbers wind their way through the streets, festooned with brightly colored parcels.

Paris may be a city swimming in fashion and finery, but this is the source. This street is home to all the major fashion houses in the country, and to Rose Bertin, personal dressmaker to the queen herself.
Her next words are a quiet mumble. “My mother gave it to me.”

And now you’re here. Back home, they sigh and dream of places like this, then quietly get back to their little lives.

Not you. 

Your circumstances may be less than ideal, but you’re still here.
“Le Petit Mogol” you mumble to yourself idly, trying to make sure you remember the name of the shop. Eventually, you find a small boutique tucked between some far grander buildings.

You open the door and walk into the tiny shop, which seems even smaller due to how absolutely full it is. This isn’t just a boutique, it’s a workshop for whoever works here. Rolls of gorgeous fabric cover every available surface. A cloying smoke hangs in the air. The scent is pleasant, but wholly unfamiliar.
As soon as the door swings shut behind you, you hear a sudden rustling of fabric further in the store. “A customer? Hamdullah!” a surprisingly young voice calls out.
“Bonjour Madame and welcome to Le Petit Mogol!” a woman, presumably the owner, calls out to you. “How may I help you?”
Her eyes light up. “Madame, you have come to the right place!”

At those words, she looks giddy to the point of bursting, but tries to play it off as a knowing smile. This deception is only half-successful. 

“Oh, I think I can help with that.”
“Oh… that…” her cheeks flush with embarrassment. “That’s lucky incense, I light it on slow business days.”
Assets/Collections/Incidents/Rest At Hom: You decide to take the day off, and spend some time at home, resting and recuperating.
Determined to be truly prepared for the tasks ahead, you stay in and fully unwind. Already, you feel like you'll perform better at your next party or rendezvous.
With that complete, you turn your focus upon the other matters that demand your attention.
After spending the day in, taking care of yourself and doing some light reading, you finally feel recharged. The exhaustion that had been affecting you before has passed.
(You no longer have any levels of exhaustion)
Assets/Collections/Incidents/That Most R: “Are you Pierre, the esteemed editor of ‘La Trompette du Peuple’?”
“Are you serious? This is your emergency fundraising?”
“I have some valuable… social information for sale” <No Tutorial>
"If I wanted to sell some gossip, how would that work?" <Tutorial>
"If I wanted to sell some gossip, how would that work?" <Tutorial>
"Are you still buying gossip?" <No Tutorial>

You walk through the city, following Camille's directions. Eventually, you find yourself threading through narrower and narrower streets. The alleys, packed with refuse and the occasional vagrant napping in the shade, feel almost oppressive in their closeness.

Suddenly, the alleys open up into a wider street near a square. You can hear the splashing of a fountain nearby. You finally find the sign for ‘La Trompette du Peuple’, the paint appears to be fresh, but the office seems awfully small.
He raises an eyebrow conspiratorially and leans in closer to you. His breath smells like cheap brandy. “You are in luck Madame, because we are always willing to pay for such valuable… information.”
A devious smile crosses his face.
“Now what do you want?”

Suddenly flush with embarrassment, he pauses to look into his snuff box.

“I do hope that coins are an acceptable form of payment...”

You come upon a man in grubby finery, up to his knees in the fountain. His shoes have carefully been placed at the water’s edge. He does a little jig as he drops a wet coin into his snuff box, which is clutched tightly in his other hand.
“I suppose you could say that, yes. Our social pages are our most popular section, and we’re always looking for new material. Keep it believable, I’m not wasting my money on fabrications.”

Maintaining his look of indignity, he glances into his dripping wet snuff box.

“You take coins, right?”
"New to this, are you? Don't worry, it's much easier than you think."
The door is locked, so you give it a knock. Nobody answers. Looking around, you find a hastily written note lodged in the door frame. It reads:

'Office temporarily closed. Engaging in emergency fund raising efforts. We apologize for the inconvenience

- Management

PS: Fear not this setback, the light of journalism shall never fade!'

It’s at that moment you realize the splashing in the fountain is getting louder, accompanied by some of the most inventive profanity you’ve ever heard.

Against your better judgement, you decide to investigate.
“Aha!” a reedy voice shouts triumphantly.
Noticing your presence, the main in the fountain turns to you with a nod and a smile that attempts to be ingratiating. “Bonjour madame.”
His smile broadens and the man bows, his manner suddenly as elegant as the finest courtiers of Versailles. “Why, in fact I am, bonne damme! My name is Pierre Renaudot.

The stranger’s smile sours and he marches out of the fountain.

“I shall have you know, that fundraising is far more difficult than it appears. Even the most noble of men must occasionally stoop low to accomplish great things.”
“How may I be of service?”
Assets/Collections/Incidents/The Limits: "This is absolutely delightful. I can't wait to see it in full swing."
"This just feels like vulgarity for the sake of it. I'd rather not."
Today, you decide to explore the Boulevard du Temple between the 11th and 3rd arrondisments. It's the place in the city best known for its theaters.

Strolling down the wide, tree lined street, you finally find what you're looking for. Les Grands-Danseurs du Roi. It's the best known theater in the city, specializing two things: comedies, and skirting the absolute limits of good taste.

Out of sheer curiosity, you step inside. There isn't a production going on at the moment, but you see actors and carpenters rushing around to ready the theater for its next show tonight.

The frantic energy is only amplified by the sight of a hapless young man trying to corral a dancing monkey back into its cage. The monkey doesn't seem interested in cooperating.

When you finally tire of watching the monkey shreik at is handler and pelt them with scraps of fruit, you take out your pencil and journal to jot down the address of the theater. (Les Grands-Danseurs du Roi is now an available rendezvous location)

With the address noted down, you start the walk home, already eager to see one of their shows. Maybe they'll have figured out how to control the monkey by then.

Part of you hopes not.
This feels like the perfect place to visit with someone that loves to laugh. Someone that isn't afraid of liking things that are a little bawdy or lowbrow.

With the address noted down, you hurry home before the crowds start forming outside. You wonder if they'll ever figure out how to control that monkey.

Probably not.
Assets/Collections/Incidents/The Rumour: The Rumour Mill
"This place could be truly valuable, I can't wait to see what I overhear next."
"Well, that was dull. At least I got something useful out of it."
“It’s like being in a gold mine. Time to take my share.” <No Tutorial>
“I think I should observe a little, first.” <Tutorial>

Crossing between the third and fourth arrondissements, you’re struck by the beauty of the buildings around you. Some of the oldest buildings in the city are here, surrounded by the homes of wealthy aristocrats. The entrances of these elegant homes are blocked by garishly dressed doormen, who honestly look more bored than imposing.

Growing up, you read incessantly about Paris, devouring any book or map you could find. Yet for some reason you can’t remember what makes this area special, beyond nice homes and some buildings built in the 1300s…

It all feels so tense. Artisocrats and courtiers merrily flit from conversation to conversation with a practiced ease, but you can never lose the feeling that nobody has really let their guard down. Everything they do is a kind of public performance, reinforcing an image they're trying to create.

After you feel a little a more comfortable with how things work here, you stroll about the square. Staying on the absolute edge of conversations, you pretend to be a traveller just admiring the apartments and gardens.
The socialites in the square are starting to filter out to their dinner appointments and other social commitments, and you decide to head home as well.
The walk home is short and uneventful, save for your daydreams of what secrets you may find in that place.
The walk home is short and uneventful, much like your time at La Place Royale.
(You can now visit La Place Royale on the Paris Map)
(You have acquired some cheap Military Gossip)

(You have come to understand that every time you vist La Place Royale, you'll be awarded a piece of gossip from a random faction. The quality of the gossip will vary from chapter to chapter in the game.)
And then you see it...

La Place Royale, the favored social spot for all the aristocrats in the city. The hub of all gossip, social news, slander, and scandal. If there was ever a telling secret, or a salacious rumor, this was the place to find it.
You see the elegantly dressed aristocrats strutting about the gardens, stopping briefly to chat in hushed tones.

Of course, without the benefit of a title or an introduction, you can’t approach any of these people directly. 

However, there’s nothing to stop you from overhearing things as you just ‘pass by’.
Everyone here is either well dressed, or dressed so casually that it only draws attention to how powerful they must be. After all, only the truly powerful can afford to downplay their importance.
Staying on the absolute edge of conversations, you stroll about the square, pretending to be a traveller just admiring the apartments and gardens.
After an hour or so, you manage to overhear something useful. Pierre will be very interested in this.
Stepping back, underneath a shady awning, you take some time to really take it all in.

"Here goes nothing..."

<Look out the window>
The carriage rumbles and bounces along the cobbles as you approach Paris. It’s taken over a week to get here, even carrying just yourself and your luggage.

You must have read the brief letter over a hundred times, but you always found new details to puzzle over. Armand’s letters were usually so long, a habit would you often tease him for, in your own missives.
Though part of you is worried by your unfamiliar surroundings, you mostly feel excited. This place is to be the stage for your new life.

You crane your neck out the window to peer at Paris. It’s even more than you imagined. The streets are a riot of color and energy as people go about their days. Elegant persons of fashion strut like brilliant peacocks. Students stumble under the weight of their books. Beggars alternate between pleading for alms, and shouting invectives at passers-by. 

Everything feels significant, like world’s next act hinges on all of their choices.
Though part of you is worried by your unfamiliar surroundings, you mostly feel excited. This place is to be the stage for your new life.

Before you know it, the carriage starts slowing down. You must be here!

Armand arranged to meet you at tavern named The Orphan’s Feast. As tired and rumpled as you are, you’re glad that he planned to meet you in a place with ample food and wine.

You must have read the brief letter over a hundred times, but you always found new details to puzzle over. Armand’s letters were usually so long, a habit would you often tease him for, in your own missives.
'Chère Yvette, ‘I know it may be sudden, but I want to invite you to live with me in Paris.’
‘I can’t wait for you to see it. It’s unlike anything back home. A truly vital place, where anyone can be anything.'
After all, ‘Baroness Yvette de Marbo’ has a certain ring to it...
‘I can’t wait for you to see it. It’s unlike anything back home. A truly vital place, where anyone can be anything.'

Inside, a woman polishing a lantern looks up at you as you enter, and her face breaks into a bright smile. "Bonjour Madame and welcome to the Orphan's Feast!" Her eyes linger expectantly on the door for a moment, before settling on you. You're suddenly reminded of how rare it is for women to travel by themselves.
‘Chère Yvette, ‘I know it may be sudden, but I want to invite you to live with me in Paris.’

Inside, a woman polishing a lantern looks up at you as you enter, and her face breaks into a bright smile. "Bonjour Madame and welcome to the Orphan's Feast!" Her eyes linger expectantly on the door for a moment, before settling on you. You're suddenly reminded of how rare it is for women to travel by themselves.
“How may I be of service?” She asks.
“Don’t worry, while the rest of the city can be rather… cutthroat, the Orphan’s Feast is a relaxed place for getting your feet under you.” The woman puts down the lantern she was polishing.
The barmaid pauses to think. "I haven’t heard that name before, but I just started working today. If you ask around, some of our patrons might know where to find your fiance."
When she puts it that way, it suddenly sounds so easy…

Not that your parents cared much about the romance. At first you'd been afraid to tell them their youngest daughter wanted to move far away. Instead, they nearly threw you onto the carriage to follow Armand to Paris.

With a grunt of irritation, the coachman flicks at his reins and the carriage surges forward, sending you lurching back into your seat. The city blurs by as you wind your way towards The Orphan's Feast, a tavern where Armand said he would meet you.
She favors you with a devious smile "Find guests worth talking to, and try to say the right things to the right people. You'll never have time to talk to everyone, so try to use your time wisely."
"Ohhh a missing person. That actually sounds interesting." She says with a devious smile.
While you understood the significant benefits your common family would receive from your marriage into a noble one, you couldnt help but be a little annoyed at their eagerness to see you off.

Your fiance, Armand, arranged for the carriage to take you from your small village to a tavern he enjoys called 'The Orphan's Feast'. There, he'll meet up with you, you'll likely take dinner together, and then he'll show you to your new home in Paris.
After all, ‘Baroness Yvette de Marbo’ has a certain ring to it...
Gnu Moment

You crane your neck out the window to peer at Paris. It’s even more than you imagined. The streets are a riot of color and energy as people go about their days. Elegant persons of fashion strut like brilliant peacocks. Students stumble under the weight of their books. Beggars alternate between pleading for alms, and shouting invectives at passers-by. 

Everything feels significant, like world’s next act hinges on all of their choices.

After a quiet sigh, the coachman obediently flicks at the reins and the horses up their pace to a brisk trot. The city blurs by as you quickly make your way towards The Orphan’s Feast, the tavern where Armand said he would meet you.
When you arrive, the coachman helps you out of the carriage and you find yourself outside a glowing, friendly looking tavern.
The sign shows a grubby looking child, holding with a plate piled high with fresh bread and roasted meats.
For now though, you’ve already finished all of your books and Armand's letter is your only entertainment, other than staring out the window.

Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Fated Conne: That morning, you sit straight up in bed, struck with a bolt of realization.

You need Gabriel to prove that Maximin had an illegitimate child with Marguerite, and that he tried to destroy Marguerite’s life over it. However, Marguerite won’t let you do anything that might put Gabriel in harm’s way, even if it lets her get justice on Maximin.

However, you don’t need Gabriel, in person to do that. You just need something that the public would find convincing.

What if you had a painting?

This would, of course, have to be a great painting. It would need to perfectly show the resemblance between Gabriel and his absentee father. It would also have to be made by an established painter, someone with a spotless reputation.
Wracking your brain for someone like that, you keep coming back to the same name, one that you learned quite recently.

Le Brun’s well known as an accomplished portrait painter, having even painted Queen Marie Antoinette herself. 

In fact, she was trusted to paint a picture of the Queen with her children.

If you can meet up with Madame Le Brun again, you might be able to commission a painting of Marguerite and Gabriel by Le Brun by her. This would add an enormous air of credibility to any accusations you might lay at Maximin’s feet.

"I don't know Alex, this feels like the honorable thing to do..."

You decide to spend the day simply relaxing at La Place Royale to beat the heat. Summers in the city are unbearable, and around this time of day your house turns into an oven. You have no idea how Camille deals with it. At least here, the shade offers some respite, and there are always refreshments close at hand.
"Oh, Yvette, is that you!"
"You may not know me, but I bet you know my sister, Clarisse-Marie!"
"That name... may be familiar to me." Alex replies, eyes darting back and forth between this accuser and you. "The last time I saw her must have been three years ago."
"Well remember it now, you curr! Three years ago you, broke her heart, and it has not mended since. As her brother, I demand satisfaction!"
"Monsieur, if you sincerely want to duel over this matter, simply name the time and the place."
"I don't seek violence, you brute! I want the only thing that would bring her peace!"
"You must marry my sister, Clarisse-Marie!"
"Je suis désolé, I think I misheard you, and heard something totally insane instead. What did you just say?"
"You heard me just fine! Marry my damn sister, or so help me..."
To emphasize this fiction, you hold onto Alex's hand, and present this stranger with your engagement ring. It's not as if he has to know who the ring is from.
"Ah, I see... damn."

You turn around and find yourself face-to-face with Alex. "Trying to stay cool as well, I see? I've already done my exercises for the day and just needed to get out of the barracks as quickly as possible."
"I'm not so easily fooled, madame. If that were true, why isn't Monsieur Dumas wearing a ring?"
"Well, you see... it is..."
"Oh, don't you start too!"
(You have lost some favor with Alex)
"I'm glad to know that you also see it my way, madame!"
(You have gained a decent amount of credibility)
"Well, I don't care who sees it which way. I'm not marrying a woman who I haven't seen in three years on the request of her idiot brother!"
With that, Alex storms off, cursing with an intensity that can only be achieved by those who fight for a living.
"Wait, monsieur! Come back! We need to set a date!"

The aggrieved brother chases after Alex to pester him with more questions, while you take this time to relax and enjoy the shade. 

You're sure Alex will be fine.
"It's great to see you!" He says with a nostalgic sigh, as he surveys the square "Mon dieu... Years ago, I used to spend way too much time here."
"Don't presume to tell me how far I would be willing to go!"
(You have gained some peril)
"My companion may have put it less delicately than I would have, but she's right. There's nothing you can do to make me consider this."
"If you'd like to compel me by force, please understand that you're not the first man to attempt that mistake, but it may be your last." Alex rests his hand on the pommel of his sabre for emphasis.
"You haven't heard the last of me."
"For your sake, I hope I have."
With that, this aggrieved brother storms off, cursing to himself with an alarming intensity.
"Ah, you went straight to the point, as always!" Alex laughs, putting his hand around your waist. "Thank you for your help."
(You have gained a decent amount of favor with Alex)

As he continues to sing your praises, Alex takes you on a walking tour of La Place Royale, pointing out his favorite spots, and telling stories of past misadventures that happened there. Together you get some lovely tea from a vendor that Alex seems to know personally.
"Everyone wanted gossip, and I loved being talked about. So, it was a natural fit, really!"
Eventually, you part ways, and head home. Your head is still spinning from the absurdity of what just transpired.
"It's quite true. I proposed just last week!" Alex chimes in. "Please give my regards to Clarisse-Marie."
"Congratulations..." The aggrieved brother replies, meaning absolutely none of it.
(You have lost a decent amount of credibility)
Alex frowns and whispers to you, "Yvette, I could have solved this if you let me."
(You have lost some favor with Alex)
"Now that we've confirmed that you're free. I hope that you're starting to see things my way..."
With that, he storms off, cursing to himself with an alarming intensity.
"An extremely cunning ruse. Yvette... and not entirely disagreeable, if I may be so bold." Alex laughs, putting his hand around your waist.
"Actually, now that you're here, I've been meaning to ask. Have you-"
"Hey! You there! Stop"
"What the devil?" Alex murmurs as you both watch an irate man approach the two of you.
"Yes, you! Monsieur Dumas, I presume? Returned to the scene of the crime, I take it?"
"Make another accusation at your own peril, sir. I have no idea who you even are."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Missing Car: *Sigh* “This has been a night. I’ll just leave.”
“That’s fine by me! My face was the only pretty thing in that gaudy house anyway!”
“Perhaps not, I’ll examine the other carriages.”
“He’s a man of honor, sworn to protect France. I’m the next best thing to that. Let’s go.”
“Perhaps not, I’ll examine the other carriages.”
“A wealthy widow helping a lost soul in need? It works in the books. Let’s go.”
“Perhaps not, I’ll examine the other carriages.”
“A priest should be willing to help a poor, innocent woman like myself. Let’s go.”
<Inspect the humble carriage to the left>
<Inspect the bold carriage in the middle>
<Inspect the extravagant carriage to the right>

Before you can reply, a valet grabs you roughly by the arm and drags you from the room. People like Viscountess de Foix don’t need to do their own dirty work, they have servants for that. It takes far longer than you’d like to get outside, as the entryway is crowded with guests preparing to leave.
 
You can feel their eyes weighing heavily on you.
The only thing left to do is go home.

The carriage to the left of you is of foreign design, and features a gilded crest as its only ornamentation. This crest is emblazoned with a motto in latin, and appears to belong to a priest of some description. The curtains are drawn, but someone appears to have lit a lantern inside. Judging by the occupant’s silhouette, it looks like he’s reading.

The carriage in front of you is obviously being used by a soldier of some sort. The driver is leaning intently towards the passenger compartment, waiting for orders. You recognize the insignia of the Queen’s Dragoons on the side of the carriage. It feels noble and proud, but also capable.

The carriage to your right is richly decorated, yet somber. Swags of black crepe hang from the roof of the carriage, leaving only glimmers of the gold underneath. The decidedly feminine bent of the decorations indicates that the occupant is a woman, but all of the black suggests that she’s in mourning.
You consider the humble carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
You consider the bold carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to an honorable stranger.
You consider the extravagant carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a mysterious stranger.
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a modest stranger.
You nod to the more appreciative members of your audience before leaving towards your own carriage.

Choosing to take the high ground, you straighten your posture and hold your head high, striding towards your carriage as if it was your intention to leave like this all along. While you make a great effort to haughtily avoid eye contact with all of those watching you, you can tell that some of them are quite surprised by your decorum in this dire situation.
(You have gained a little credibility)

(You have lost some favor with members of the Crown)
(You have gained some favor with members of the Revolution)
It's gone.

"He went home!" A passing coachman says helpfully, while adjusting the harness on a particularly grumpy horse. "Doorman came out about an hour ago, and told him you wanted the coach to leave without you. Seemed real important, so he went home."

Boiling over with anger, you turn and rain insults upon the house, upon the host, even upon her dog. In fact, you consider throwing your shoe through one of their windows, before you remember how much you like that shoe. 

It’s then that you notice that several of the carriages have stopped, just to watch your display.

When you finally get to the door, you feel a brutish shove, and you stumble out into the courtyard, barely keeping your balance in your heels. The area is equally crowded, with various persons entering their personal carriages. 

You can hear somebody snicker, but you have no idea who it was.
When you arrive at the place where your carriage is parked, you quickly find out that… it isn’t.

Scanning the faces of your new audience, you see the glaring, unamused faces of the various party guests. Your views on Marcelle, and the Crown in general, have not gone unnoticed. The coachmen and valets on the other hand, think you’re hilarious.
You check to make sure that you’re in the right place, but to no avail. The carriage you hired is simply not there.

Before you can even respond, he gets his carriage moving, leaving you alone with yet another indignity. 

Going back to Marcelle is obviously unacceptable, it’s too far to walk home, and most of the other guests have already left.
However, there appear to be three other carriages waiting to leave, each of them quite different. Perhaps one of them can help?
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Pauper's Gr: Cimetière du Calvaire is a tiny cemetery on a hill in the Montemartre district. It’s so small that you had to ask for directions twice, as people seem to have forgotten that it even exists at all.

Finally, you arrive at the cemetery, and make your way past the short stone wall, and through the open gate. The air smells both musty and acidic.

There’s nobody here but you, two lonely looking trees, and the dead.

The old Viscount, the real Viscount, had been a destitute nobleman. He received loans from Marcelle’s father, Gatien le Vassor. When the Viscount died, Marcelle’s father must have found out, impersonated him, and had the grave moved to this cemetery, far from any prying eyes. A few small bribes to silence the grave-diggers, and nobody would be the wiser.
That’s why the Viscount never paid back his debts. Why repay yourself?

Marcelle’s father isn’t a real nobleman, he’s just using the title of a dead man. With a noble title it would be easy to avoid taxes, secure loans, all the things one would need to amass a fortune.

If her father isn’t a real member of the nobility, neither is Marcelle.
Her family’s storied history, her fortune, it’s all built on a lie. A lie that you know the truth of, and you have the proof, right in front of you.
You cover the grave marker again with dead leaves, and carefully put away the rubbing you’ve made of the plaque.
Now it’s time to find a way to face Marcelle. Soon, your revenge shall be complete.
You don’t really know what you’re looking for, not even the name of the dead man you’ve come to investigate, but you have a decent idea of when they died, and there’s less than fifty graves here...
The search is slow at first, most of the headstones have been worn down to the point of near-illegibility, and many of them are over 100 years old. No possible connection.
You’re just about to give up when you nearly trip over something. It’s a cheap sandstone plaque, set into the ground, and obscured by leaves.
You brush the leaves aside, and see a name.

‘Alfonso Joseph Du Foix
Born in February 23rd, 1690
Died in November 2nd, 1768
Interred Here in November 12th, 1768’
Hands shaking, you frantically take out a piece of paper and your traveler’s pencil. Brushing the edge of the pencil back and forth, you take a rubbing of the burial plaque.
This is it. This is what you’ve been searching for.
It all makes sense now. Marcelle’s father didn’t kill Viscount Alfonso Du Foix. He became Viscount Alfonso Du Foix.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Portrait, C: You wake up and notice a letter on your nightstand. Camille must have put it there while you were still asleep.

Opening the letter, you immediately recognize Élisabeth’s messy handwriting. You’re still not sure how someone who can draw and paint so well is so utterly incapable of writing clearly. It takes a few moments of squinting before the squiggles on the page start to look like actual words.

Opening the letter, you are initially baffled by a wall of sloppy handwriting. After a few moments of squinting, the squiggles on the page start to look like actual words. Apparently the letter is from the artist, Élisabeth.

‘Chère Yvette, I just finished my portrait of the two amazing subjects you introduced me too! I just know that anyone who sees it is going to find it very surprising, though you’ll have to see it for yourself.’
‘You already know how to contact me. Whenever you’re ready, send me a message and I can bring the painting over for one final evaluation. Affectueuses pensées, Élisabeth’
‘PS: I have one more surprise for you, but you’ll have to see it in person.’

'Madame Yvette,

I just finished my portrait of the two amazing subjects you introduced me too! I just know that anyone who sees it is going to find it very surprising, though you’ll have to see it for yourself.'
‘I’ve left instructions with your maid on how to contact me. Whenever you’re ready, send me a message and I can bring the painting over for one final evaluation. Bien à vous, Élisabeth’
(The Promised Painting is now available to visit in the Paris map)
It’s still early in the morning. If you don’t have anything pressing, you could invite her over and see the painting today.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Reason for: "I'm in Paris because my fiance, Armand, is here."
“Paris is a hub of trade, wealth, and craftsmen. It’s where I can get the lifestyle I want.”
“This is the only place where I can achieve the status that I deserve.”
"I see... very well."
"His business isn't mine to discuss."
“An idyllic farming town to the south, I’m a little sorry I left it behind.”
"Well, he's the Baron de Marbo, and he's here for the Estates General."
"I'd prefer not to discuss that, if you don't mind."
<Grab his wrist> "Please monsieur, you have to tell me where he is."
"Are you sure you can't remember anything?"
“It was nowhere significant, I’m happier to be here.”
"I'm actually looking for someone. Do you know where I could find the Baron de Marbo?"
“I’m here because my fiance, Armand, is here. I'd follow him anywhere.”
“This is the only place where I can achieve the status that I deserve.”
“Paris is a hub of trade, wealth, and craftsmen. It’s where I can get the lifestyle I want.”
You approach a man standing by himself. His wig is slightly dishevelled, and he has fresh mud on his boots.
“Ah, bonjour madame! You must have just arrived in Paris as well.” He says affably.

“Seeking the finer things in life? Well, you’re in the right place for it. Fashion is a way of life here."  He gestures around the tavern and you can see that even the people of more humble means have chosen their attire carefully.
“And what has brought you to this bustling metropolis?”

"I think you'll fit in well with the merchants, lawyers, and physicians of the Bourgeoisie." 

(You've gained a little favor with members of the Bourgeoisie)
"Sorry, madame. I simply... haven't been here long enough to know enough about him."
"Are you here in the city alone?"

"Allow me to suggest that you take some time to speak with members of the army, and their supporters. They come from backgrounds both high and low, yet they're all willing to sacrifice so much to raise their station just a little." 

(You've gained a little favor with members of the Military)
"If that is why you are here, you might want to seek out those associated with the church. Love and tradition are very much on their minds."
"I'm sorry madame, I must go. I have an urgent appointment." He says very brusquely.
"Thank you for your understanding madame." He says with a polite nod before he drains his wineglass. "Now it appears that, I must go. I have an urgent appointment."
Without another word, he drains his wineglass and leaves.
“Where did you journey from?”
He departs, leaving you with your thoughts, and more questions.
"So, this Armand of yours, what brought him to Paris?"

He nods his head affably. "My apologies madame, I didn't mean to pry. Discretion is such a rare virtue in this day and age, that I'd almost forgotten it entirely."

(You have gained a little credibility)
The two of you spend the next few minutes exchanging small talk and pleasant travel stories. It's nice to talk with another person again, even if it's about nothing in particular.

Eventually he excuses himself, as he needs to make it to some sort of appointment.

A pleasant diversion, but you're no closer to finding Armand than when you started.

The traveller startles at your sudden forwardness, and you can feel the weight of eyes in the tavern watching the next moments. "Madame, please understand that I cannot say much more. Your fiance has made some powerful enemies, and if you don't know how he did that, then you might want to reconsider him entirely."

(You have gained a little peril)
While you may have learned something, you feel like you still have more questions than answers. You should be able to clear all of this up when you find Armand.
His eyes go wide for a moment before settling into an expression of discomfort. Gathering up his things, he starts preparing to leave.
Without another word, he pulls free of your grasp, drains his wineglass and leaves.
He sighs and looks from side to side, obviously torn on what to do.
“Do not worry madame, I’m sure you’ll be able to return there soon enough!” He replies with a warm laugh. “I myself came a few months ago from similar, idyllic surroundings in Brittany.”
Getting close to you, he whispers. "If you must know madame, your fiance has made some powerful enemies, and if you don't know how he did that, then you might want to reconsider him entirely."
Without another word, he drains his wineglass and leaves.
(You've gained a little favor with members of the Church)
(You've gained a little favor with members of the Military)
(You've gained a little favor with members of the Bourgeoisie)
(You've gained a little credibility)
(You've gained a little peril)
(You've lost some credibility)
(You've gained a little credibility)
“Well, madame you are in luck, for you have arrived in the most significant city in all the world.”
"The Baron de Marbo?" He pauses to think, scratching his chin. "Why does that name sound so familiar?"

“But of course, the harvest has not been so good this year, which is what brings me to Paris. I’m searching for a way to revitalize our estate. Back home, I tried new farming techniques, imported tools, and I even built a shrine to Saint Isidore himself! Yet, it was to no avail. So I am here, in search of a solution.”
“Et vous, madame? What has brought you to Paris, so far from home?”

"You've travelled all the way here for your fiance? Such love and devotion remind me of when I was your age." His eyes have a far off look for a moment. 

"Never let yourself lose sight of such things."
"Ambition, advancement, and glory? Such things are not easy for a commoner like yourself. However, you are correct, Paris is the place best for those looking to raise their station."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Request for: Waking up to the sound of the wind rattling your shutters, you sit up and languidly stretch your arms. It appears that Camille has left a unoppened letter on your bedside table. It's sealed with blue wax.
Examining the letter's seal and address, it appears to be from Corporal Dumas. Opening the letter, you find it written in his well practiced, and flowing handwriting.

'Chère Yvette, While I hope this letter finds you well, I write to ask you for a favor. There is a place I need you to meet me, so that I can do something that I've been meaning to do for quite some time.'

The letter lists an address on it, but seems to provide no other context. You note it down in your journal.

'I'll be positioned here, near midday, for the forseeable future. Please join me, if you can.'
'Though I may be known for my considerable vigor, there are things I would still rather have reinforcements for. Please understand that I do not make such a request lightly.'

Looking at the address you noted in you journal, you pause to consult your map of the city. The address appears to point towards a cemetary. What could he possibly need there?

('Legacy' is now available to visit in the Paris map)
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Revolutiona: “Maximin and I kept running into each other, at various salons and readings. We’re old friends now.”
“This is quite embarrassing, but I don’t know much about our host. Could you tell me more?”
“A baron willing to reject the very system that benefits him? He sounds like a man of principle.”
“So, he’s a political hobbyist, who advances himself by condemning others? Did I get that right?”

You approach a woman who’s standing by herself. She’s looking around at the party, and just seems extremely pleased to be here.

“Isn’t this magnificent?” She beams. “So many revolutionary minds in one place, all brought together by one man.”
“How do you know our host, Baron Maximin de Termes?” She asks.
The next few minutes pass in awkward silence, punctuated only by bouts of glaring and the occasional upturned nose. Eventually, you walk away to explore the rest of the party.

“Then again..." She continues with uncertainty. "I know the Baron also hosts his own private gatherings like this one, and this is my first. That makes so much sense, I’m sorry for doubting you. I had no idea you were so familiar with the Baron.”
“Perhaps later, you would be able to introduce us?” She asks, with some trepidation. “I’m sure he and I would have a lot to… discuss.”

The two of you chat and joke for a while. During the course of conversation, you maintain the lie so flawlessly that, for a brief moment, you have to remind yourself that you don’t actually know the Baron.
Eventually, the two of you part ways to explore the rest of the party.

“In fact, the only way this could be true, is if we had attended all the events the other one had missed, for years. Which would be convenient indeed!" She replies cheerily. "Since we've exclusively attended such different events, I have some helpful advice for you."
“Don’t lie about your relationship to the host. Maximin has no time for the ridiculous intrigues of courtiers, and I’m sure he would certainly not appreciate this, if he were to find out.”
You manage to mumble a few polite words of thanks before you decide to slink away.
The Estates General hasnt even convened yet, but hes already expressed his support for the Third Estate and a new, enlightened France.

(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained a little peril)
"Really?" She asks, her voice dropping to a low whisper. "I dont mean to be rude, but I've never seen you before, and I attend many of the salons."
(You have gained some credibility)
It appears that nothing would please her more.

“Oh, Baron Maximin de Termes is a cut apart from the rest of the nobility! He host salons, sponsors pamphlet printings, and associates with our heroes who fought in the American War for Independence.” She clasps her hands together and gazes off into the distance.

“Of course, he has made a few enemies. The Baron has already had to denounce some of his associates for not properly embodying revolutionary ideals. Thankfully, his reputation has only thrived because of his bravery!”
“Isn’t he wonderful?”

“Oh, he most certainly is!” She replies happily.

You get the feeling that her interest in the Baron strays beyond the strictly ideological, but that’s none of your business.

Her expression immediately sours.

“Well, that’s not how I would have put it, but I suppose one could say that…”
You two talk and joke for a while, and eventually part ways. If you get a chance to speak with the Baron de Termes, you’re absolutely certain that you’ll have a lot to talk about.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Secretive W: A Secretive Waitress
“What do you mean by ‘us’?”
“What, exactly, have you been protecting Gabriel from?”
“Don’t worry, I’m no friend of his.”
“Take a seat, this will only be a moment.”
“Have you ever wanted to get revenge on Maximin?”
“Why not take this to the courts?”
"Are you familiar with Baron Maximin de Termes?"
"Do you know of any other waitresses with eyes like yours?"
“What, exactly, has Remi been protecting you from?”
“What do you mean by ‘us’?”
“What, exactly, has Remi been protecting you from?”
Pushing through the crowds outside, you walk into Cafe Principe and find yourself a seat. Opening your journal, you get ready to open your ears and start writing down the political news of the day.
Within a few moments, Marguerite is waiting to take your order. “Welcome back, madame!”

Marguerite stares at you for a while, her face a mask of barely concealed confusion.

“You’re not working for Maximin, are you?”

Marguerite stares at you for a while, her face a mask of barely concealed confusion.

“You’re not working for Maximin, are you?”
“But, after a few weeks of looking, I found the cafe. Remi’s last waitress suddenly quit because she was getting married, so he was desperate. I got the job, along with a little room in the attic.”

“Of course, Maximin wasn’t happy with… anything really. So he tried to pressure Remi into firing me. Maximin decried the cafe, convinced his friends to stop attending, and even got the Guet Royal to raid the place, once.”

“I was so scared that Remi would toss me out that I worked my fingers to the bone, every single day, for three months. The way I saw it, Remi couldn’t fire me if I was the best employee he’d ever had.”

“At the end of those three months, Remi didn’t fire me, and Maximin just gave up. As long as I stay here and don’t make too much noise. I’m safe. Eventually, all of the rumors died down and the city of Paris lost interest in our little story.”
She sighs. "I suppose I should start at the beginning..."
“I was sixteen when I moved to Paris. My family was poor, and hoped I could find someone to marry, maybe someone with better fortunes than ours.”
“He’s seven years old now, and already looks just like his father.”

“My cousin got me a job as a maid-of-all-works in Maximin’s household. A few months later, she started working at a different estate and I was alone.” She taps her chin and thinks for a while, dredging up a discarded memory.
While her facial expression doesn’t change, her spine visibly straightens and everything about her suddenly feels stiff and tense.
“I think that was when Maximin had my name changed to Rose. It was more fashionable, and most of the servants I know have had their names changed at one point or another.”

“I was young, but even then I knew Maximin was interested in me. Of course, I was smitten. A common girl, trading coy glances and little flirtations with a Baron. The whole thing was so romantic, and I wasn’t old enough to understand that things like that don’t really happen.”
That stings a little.

“We were together for a while. Eventually, we made a mistake. I was pregnant, and he was afraid. He was growing important, politically, and having an illegitimate child with his young maid didn’t paint the picture of a ‘serious revolutionary thinker.’”
“So he wanted me to keep it a secret, and to get rid of Gabriel.” She sighs and shakes her head. “I could do one, but I could never do the other.”

“When Maximin found out, he was furious. He called me every name under the sun. Said I was trying to ruin him. This man I adored, just turned on me in an instant. He told me that if didn’t get of Gabriel, that he’d accuse me of stealing from him.”

She waits to let that sink in. 

A servant found guilty of stealing from their employer faces the death penalty, and most courts treat servants as guilty until proven innocent.

“So, I did the only thing I could. I fled, still pregnant, in the middle of the night with anything I could carry, and slept in the streets for a month while I tried to find a job. I can never really go home, because this would ruin my family. Still, I got to keep my son, and I got my real name back.”
“Rose doesn’t really suit me.”

Marguerite examines you carefully, trying to judge your character. 

“All the time.”
“I’m not sure what you’re talking about madame.” She says, after a long pause.

She shrugs helplessly. “Rich men like Maximin are the ones that write the laws. They don’t exist to protect people like you and me. If I took Maximin to court, I’d only be putting my Gabriel in danger.”
“However, that’s not possible for me. Not without endangering Gabriel.” She states that with a firmness that feel utterly immovable. “Now if you’ll excuse me, I have to see to my other customers.”
Marguerite departs and you’re left alone. Try as you might, your mind too full of these recent revelations to think and talk politics with agitated strangers.

A few fruitless hours later, you head home. You’ve already found Maximin’s weakness, but the trouble is that you don’t know how to use it. You need some way to proving that Maximin is Gabriel’s father, but one that doesn’t physically expose him to danger.
But how?
“Which is something I’m not going to do.” She states that with a firmness that feel utterly immovable.
While her facial expression doesn't change, her spine visibly straightens and everything about her suddenly feels stiff and tense.
"Now if you'll excuse me, I have to see to my other customers."
You look her in the eye and something about her feels familiar, important even.
She exhales slowly, visibly relieved. “That is good to hear madame. Remi, the owner, has always been so good at protecting us, but the Baron de Termes is a powerful man.”

Marguerite slowly sits into the chair, glancing worriedly around the room. Nobody seems to notice her anxious state.

“So, it has come to this,” she says with a sigh. “Remi did his best to protect us, but I suppose he is just one man.”
“I’ve always feared that Maximin would try to reach out to us by some other means.”
“After I left Maximin’s service, I needed a job. However, getting a job as a servant usually requires a recommendation from your previous employer, something Maximin would have definitely withheld.”
“I mean me and my son, Gabriel. He lives with me, in the attic upstairs.” She says, pointing up at the ceiling. “Everything I’ve done, has been to protect him.”
“Somehow, I always knew that Maximin would try to lash out at us by some other means.”
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Small Wager: "Risk a little coin, gain a little excitement? Sounds fun!"
"I'll bet on black."
"Let's go with red."
"I'll bet on black."
"Let's go with red."
"I'll bet on black."
"Je suis désolé, but I try to avoid such pursuits."
"I'm not sure, can you tell me how it works?"

Hearing an outburst of cheers, you wander into a room to see what the fuss is all about.

Inside, you find a group of men clustered around a table with a roulette wheel set up on it. Their faces are a mixture of fear, disappointment and triumph, but they're all obviously excited. 

After the latest spin, some grumbling is heard and some coin is exchanged.
"Now, would you like to bet on red or black?"
He places your coins on the outside betting track for red, and the dealer releases the ball into the spinning wheel.
He places your coins on the outside betting track for black, and the dealer releases the ball into the spinning wheel.

As the ball starts to slow down, leaving the rim and drifting towards one of the pockets. Everyone in the room goes as still as a statue. 

That's when you make your move.

"Well, if you insist..." He replies, turning away from you. You can tell that the other gamblers in the room have also lost interest in your entirely.

Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Splendid Ho: “Oh, Marcelle? Her family used to summer near mine in the south. We’re old friends.”
“I’ve actually never met her before. What’s she like?”
“A monied woman of fashion who tolerates no fools? Interesting.”
“Wealthy, vain, and somewhat vindictive? I’ll keep that in mind.”

Looking for someone to talk to, you approach an older man who seems to be standing by himself and appraising the room. He nods politely to you as you approach.

“I don’t think I’ve seen you here before.”
“How do you know our hostess, the Viscountess de Foix?”
“Ah yes!" He says, suddenly perking up. "I remember her saying something about a summer home in the south of the country. For you to be here now, you must have quite the close bond with our hostess."
“Perhaps later on, you’ll be able to put in a good word for me?”
You talk and laugh with him for a while longer, before you eventually part ways, in order to see what else is going on at the party.

“In fact, I find your story… rather hard to believe.” He replies, icily. “I would go so far as to say that it’s quite rude to lie about your relationship to the hostess. Marcelle would certainly not appreciate this, if she were to find out.”
You two stand together, swaddled in tense silence, before you decide to slink away.

(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained a little peril)
(You have gained some credibility)

Over your shoulder, you hear an older womans voice call out. A brief glance reveals an elegant older woman, bedecked in jewelry, gesturing insistently with her fan. "Ah, pardon moi madame, duty calls."
"Oh, really?" He leans back and appraises you anew. "I've never heard Marcelle mention you before."

“Ah! The Viscountess inherited her title a few years ago, and her father’s vast fortune with it. She’s currently unwed, though a few suitors certainly appear to be trying to court her.” The older man rapidly lists the hostesses’ qualities with the same tone that one might use to describe a horse they were trying to sell.

“However, with her current level of favor at court, any suitor would have to be influential indeed in order to attract her notice. She also happens to be rather particular about her appearance, and in all my years of knowing her, I have yet to see her forget anyone who has slighted her.”
“Does that help clarify things at all?” He asks.
“Exactly! Marcelle has many qualities, but humility and forgiveness are not among them.”
The older man chuckles drolly at your blunt assessment. “I would recommend that you do. Once the Viscountess de Foix has it in mind to hate someone, nothing will ever change her mind.”
With a polite nod, he exits the conversation to mingle in the rest of the party.

Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Storied Lin: "He sounds like my kind of person."
"Warmth, good drink, and even better company? I love all of those."
"You exercise a lot more restraint"
"What pleasures were those?"
"And what pleasures were those?"
"Well, if it makes you happy."
"Well, at least you got to France."
"How could your father do that to you?"
"I'm sorry, he... uh... sold you? How? Why?"
"I have to say, that's an amazing story."
"Alex, your father sold you like property. That's monstrous."
"Does this mean you're actually a nobleman?"
"Alright, as long as we don't completely lose our heads."
"Temporary or not, it's still an amazing story."
"Alex, your father sold you like property. That's monstrous."
"Does this mean you're actually a nobleman?"
It's still an amazing story.
It's still an amazing story.
"You were born a noble and nothing changes that. The Crown needs you."
"Trust your heart, you're a child of both places."
"I've never met someone better prepared to fight for the common good. Support the Revolution."
"Weren't you born a noble? Shouldn't you support the Crown?"
"Of course, your heart burns for freedom, just like theirs. Support the Revolution."
"Of course you should! You're only defending your birthright."
"Yet, weren't you also born a victim of that same tradition? The Revolution needs you."
"It sounds like you already have your answer. Trust your heart."
"Trust your gut."
"It sounds like you already have your answer. Trust your heart."
"Trust your gut."
"Trust your gut."
"Don't sell yourself short, this has been great. I appreciate you trusting me like this."
"Merci Alexandre, I appreciate your restraint."
Alexandre is once again walking you back home after your rendezvous. It's unusually chilly tonight, so you both walk close together, arm in arm, to help stave off the cold.
"Merci, Yvette. It's nice to know that someone like you has confidence in me."
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
Alexandre orders a bottle of Malaga from the barmaid. You ask for a pitcher of water to accompany it. If one isn't careful, the hangover from these sweet wines can be absolutely debilitating.
Both of the drinks arrive and he fills your glasses before his own.
Stopping at the tavern's entrance, he holds the door open for you. "After you then, madame."
Raising his glass for a toast, he says "To quick decisions and life's little joys."
You clink glasses with him, and sip the fortified wine. It's sweet, and strong. The chill inside you melts away, almost instantly.
Alexandre pauses to contemplate the charms of his glass of Malaga by the light of your table's lamp. His eyes seem focused on something distant.
"Malaga was always a favorite of my father. Even when I was growing up in Saint Doaminue, he would leap at any chance to get a bottle of it."
"Then again, he often went to great lengths to obtain his pleasures."
"If that's the case, maybe we should have met a few years ago." He smirks as he takes another sip.
"It's so brisk, that I'm feeling up for a drink to stay warm. If you're interested, I know of a decent tavern nearby."
"Me? You flatter me." He chuckles. "You should have seen me a few years ago."
"Oh, the usual. Wine... women... other people's money."

"When I first moved to Paris, I spent years as a typical, unscrupulous rake. Strutting about the Palais-Royale, finding romance in the booths of Nicolet's theater, spending far too much money on fine clothes and finer drink."
"He'd lived a nobleman's life of ease, and he wanted the same for me. To be honest, I was more than happy to take him up on his offer."
"As fun as it sounds, I was just another jobless scion of nobility, living off of my father's largess."
"He didn't disapprove at all, in fact he delighted in my adventures. Sometimes, I think he was trying to live through me."
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
"Of course, to get that pleasure for himself, he first had to get us from his hiding place in Saint-Domingue to the the family estate in France." Alexandre punctuates this with a long sip of wine.
"So my father sold me. Well, technically, he pawned me off..."
"Would you care to join me?"
"Exactly!" He replies excitedly, almost grateful for your agreement.
"Well, he was forced to it," Alexandre explains. "Even though he was the eldest son, and the heirs to our fortune, everyone in the family thought my father was dead."
"Because you can still sell slaves in the colonies, and I was one." He says, like it's the most obvious thing imaginable.
"Let's say that he had a falling out with his brothers that lasted a few... decades."
"My father owned my mother, so I was born his slave."

"Once his parents died, he could come out of hiding and claim his inheritance. But first, he needed to get to France to prove his legitimacy. So, he temporarily sold me to pay for passage on a ship, so he could claim his title."
"Once my father got his fortune, he bought me back."
"I'm glad you liked it!" He laughs, clinking glasses with you.
"What? Absolutely not! He did what he could to help me."
"In the eyes of the law, I was always a nobleman, even when I was a slave."
"I see we're in agreement!" He replies with a grateful laugh.
"Once I arrived, he hired tutors to make up for lost time in my education. I learned how to fence, how to ride, even how to play an instrument. All of the things that make one a proper gentleman."
"So yes, it just was a temporary inconvenience."
"He needed money to pay for his return to France, and claim his fortune and title. That's why he sold me, to pay for the trip over."
"Don't worry, it was only a few months before he bought me back, and brought me here. The second I set foot on French soil, I was a free man."
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
"The only thing that's wrong are the laws that let people be bought and sold at all."
"However, to answer your question, yes. As his eldest legitimate son, I'm the heir to his land and titles, should I choose to claim them... from his wife."
"I'm not sure if I told you this, but what spurred me to enlist was that I wanted to show my father that I was a good as any other noble."

He pauses to examine his hand in the candlelight, as if his skin could answer some long, unanswered mystery. "Of course, it happens that men like me need four generations of documentation to prove their link to nobility, something we didn't have."
"Now, I look at everything happening the city, I and don't know how to feel. Am I even a real noble? Or am I just a commoner whose had more advantages than most?"
"Why in fact, it does!" He laughs, mostly to himself.
"These days, I feel closer to the Crown. I'm a child of nobility, shouldn't I serve that tradition?"
"I just don't know."
"These days, I feel closer to the common people's struggle for freedom."
As he sips his drink, you catch a glimmer of something in his eyes. Was that doubt?
"So, I enlisted. Father wasn't happy, but I didn't it anyway. At his insistence I did so under a different name, so as not to bring shame upon our legacy. To not bring shame upon him."
"Then... he died less than a fortnight later. I never claimed his title."
"I was so confident that I'd prove him wrong. That I'd take all the things he'd given me and make him proud, even as a simple soldier."
"You know what? You're absolutley right. I have a duty to defend my birthright, if not for myself, but for any children that I should have."
"Merci, Yvette. It's nice to know that someone like you has confidence in me."
"You know what? You're absolutley right. All over Paris, commoners cry out for freedom. Me, and my compatriots should be the ones to give it to them."
"Madame, have you met us before? That's hardly a possibility." He replies with a wink. Stopping at the entrance, he holds the door open for you.
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown somewhat)
Alexandre sighs and shakes his head. "Je suis désolé. That was all a little more serious than I'd intended."
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution somewhat)
"I suppose it's true that I was born to a noble title." He admits. He stares at the lamp on your table, considering your point.
"With an endorsement like that, how can I say no?" He laughs. "I must admit, I never took you for such a firebrand."
"And vive la roi to you as well!" He laughs with a mock salute. "I didn't expect you to be such a commited monarchist. Still, you're absolutely right."
"I suppose that's true." He admits. He stares at the lamp on your table, considering your point.
With a great swig his finishes off his wine and drops some coins on the counter. You finish off yours as well, but in a more refined fashion.

That familiar smile is suddenly back in place. "Thank you for joining me on this little stop! I think I'm ready to do what I actually promised to do, and walk you home. Sorry again for boring you with all of that."
"You're absolutely right! I can't betray my legacy just because of how I feel for a moment."
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown somewhat)

The two of you take a longer and more scenic route back to your home. It gives you more of a chance to talk, and to bring extra details from his mysterious past to light.
Wanting to get home before the warmth of the Malaga wears off, the two of you take the quickest route available. It's a short trip, but you get home safely nonetheless.
"Most fathers would have disapproved of my behavior, but not him. In fact he delighted in my adventures. Sometimes, I think he was trying to live through me."
