Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Study in Ch: A Study in Chemistry
"If I have a choice, then tell me about the Crown."
"I'd prefer to learn more about the Revolution."
"An experiment? What exactly are you doing here? What's your game?"
"If I have a choice, then tell me about the Crown."
"I'd prefer to learn more about the Revolution."
"Why, in fact I am."
"Monsieur, I think you have me confused for someone else."
"I'm not certain if I should say. Who are you?"
You decide to take a walk around the city, hoping to stumble across something new that might help you.
Just as you cross the street to avoid an approaching wagon, you're approached by a colorfully dressed young man. He studies you carefully for a moment before speaking.
"In the name of a little experiment that I am performing, I might have a lead for you. In fact I might have two."
"Which would you prefer to know more about, the Crown or the Revolution?"
"Ah, a wise choice!"
"Ah, a wise choice!"
His smile is enigmatic. "That, madame, for me alone to know. If I were to tell you what I aimed to learn, that would undermine the experiment, wouldn't it?"
"So, which shall it be?"

He steps in closer and starts to tell you about some of the more interesting goings-on amongst the aristocrats close to the Crown. At first, you were skeptical of the quality of the story he could provide, but you find yourself surprised. This could actually be quite valuable.

He steps in closer and starts to tell you about some of the more interesting goings-on in the Revolution. At first, you were skeptical of the quality of the story he could provide, but you find yourself surprised. This could actually be quite valuable.
(You have lost a little credibility)

"Excusez-moi madame, but you're Yvette Decaux, non?"

With a sigh, you brush aside these swirling concerns. You have something good for Pier. That's what matters, right now.
(You have lost a little credibility)

"I'm trying to find my fiance, Baron Armand de Marbo."
"I'm trying to find my fiance, Baron Armand de Marbo."
"I just moved here, so I'm trying to get a feel for Paris."
"I just moved here, so I'm trying to get a feel for Paris."
The conversation finishes as all the others had, with the various guests walking away from you, charmed and satisfied. A few days spent cooped up in a carriage have done nothing to dull your skills.

You feel a tap at your elbow and turn around, finding yourself face to face with a woman from one of your previous conversations.

“Who are you? I mean, who are you really?” she asks.
“I’m sorry, but I don’t think I can help you find your Armand.”

After a long pause, she continues “Tread carefully. Talents like yours are most valuable, and valuable things tend to attract danger.” The voice of another guest calls out behind her, and she quickly excuses herself before disappearing into the crowd.
With the woman gone, you question a few more of the guests, but to no avail. None of them seem willing to talk about about Armand.
There’s no sign of him, not even an open tab with the tavernkeep.
After the woman leaves, you question a few more of the guests, but none of them seem willing to talk about Armand.
She sips her wine, patiently. Intently.

“Yes, you said that,” the woman observes idly. She sips her wine again, examining you. “I’m just having a hard time figuring you out. You’re obviously a girl fresh from the countryside, but you do not conduct yourself like one… at all.”

“You just walked in, swept an entire room of strangers off of its feet, and made it look easy. Not only that, you did it without a single one us managing to learn anything about you. I know your name, and nothing more.”
“So, let me be more specific. What are you trying to do here, Madame Decaux?”
“What are you doing here, really?”
A look of shock ripples across her face for a brief moment, before return to polite neutrality “Ah, I see.”
“I get the feeling that you’re going to fit in here just fine,” she remarks with the faintest hint of bitterness before disappearing into the crowd.

The woman barks out a laugh of genuine surprise. “If this is what you do for fun, I can’t wait to see what you do when you’re being serious.” She pauses to sip at her wine again, finding her glass to be empty. “I’m sure I’ll see you around,” she says, before slipping into the crowd.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Tennis Cour: A Tennis Court Meeting

This morning, the representatives from the third esate went to meet in their usual chambers, but were blocked by a combination of armed gaurds and construction workers, who claimed their chambers were being shut down for rennovations.

When the representatives attempted to enter anyway to hold a meeting, the armed guards forced them away at gunpoint.

Without a place to meet, the increasingly angry representatives found an empty tennis court. There, they met and discussed the latest issues ahead of them, especially the Crown's latest attempts to thwart their ability to organize.

In a sudden moment of unity, all the members of the third estate vowed that they wouldn't disband until they've established a written constitution for France. Unexpectedly, they were greeted with support from a large group of priests who have broken from the official stance of the first estate to pledge their allegiance to the National Assembly.

(The Revolution has gained quite a bit of power)
(The Bourgeoisie has gained some power)
(The Bourgeoisie has moved closer to the Revolution some)
(The Church has moved clsoer to the Revolution some)
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

His Majesty, the King's indirect method of diverting the National Assembly seems to have weakened them through frustration and infighting. Yet, rather than relieve the growing tension, this only seems to have heightened it.

The exact wording of this tennis court oath borrowed heavily from the Declaration of Independence issued by the American colonists to the King of England. It's not surprising, as many of the most ardent consitutionalists were the same officers sent by the His Majesty to help the Americans throw off the shackles of an unjust monarch.
Now, they have brought that fight home.
This is the first time the third estate has openly opposed His Majesty, the King, and they do it with the support of those who speak for God.
What's a higher priority? Equal taxation, or equal say in governance?
This is the first time the third estate has openly opposed His Majesty, the King.

While there is still infighting amongst the capitalists of the bourgeoisie, and the more high-minded revolutionaries within the third estate, this sudden show of support has given them a much stronger negotiating position.

They were not alone in this meeting, joined by several sympathetic members of the clergy, as well as a group of nobles who aimed to reach across the political aisle, and break the deadlock that has been plaguing the Estates General.
In a sudden moment of unity, all the members of the third estate vowed that they wouldn't disband until they've established a written constitution for France.

Sympathetic to the cause of the poor, a large group of priests from the countryside parishes broke away from the official stance of the first estate to pledge their allegiance to the National Assembly.

Unforunately, this meeting in the tennis courts made little progress. Bogged down by infighting between the capitalists of the bourgeoisie, and the more high-minded revolutionaries within the third estate, the National Assembly failed to articulate what they really wanted.

"Of course, as much as I love the character and the people of the countryside, it's probably for the best that I'm here. My relationship with my family has been rather... strained, as of late."
"They don't want me involved with the Revolutionaries. They don't understand the importance of our times."
Suddenly, you notice a young man heading straight towards you throug hthe crowds. Frankly, he's beautiful, but he radiates a dangerous intensity.

"That's exactly it!" He growls. "Politics is not some civil debate where, at the end, everyone gets to simply agree to disagree. It is real decisions, with real consequences, for real people! The nobility can pretend to sit above it all because they're isolated from those consequences."
You follow up your statement by demurely batting your eyelashes at him. He doesn't seem to notice, instead nodding along thoughtfully. "Humility is a virtue. I respect that."
He looks into the distance and sneers. "You sound just like them. France's future matters for all of us. We cannot afford to be polite with what's at stake."
"The rest of us cannot afford such a privelege."
(You have gained some favor with Antoine)
"Right now, the people of France stand at the edge of a cliff, a raging forest fire burning at our backs."
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
"Will we stay and be incinerated, or develop the courage to jump into the waters below?"
"Oh, that I can guarantee." He replies. His gaze is unflinching, but he can't help but smile.
"Who are you, and what exactly are you doing here?"
He grunts dismissively. "The old order must be cast aside as soon as possible, lest we allow more people to become victim to its repression and cruelty."
He smiles, caught a little off guard. "Well, I did study oratory in school, until I found my teachers wanting."
(You have gained some favor with Antoine)
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)

The two of you chat a little longer. While his mind is often focused on politics, his zeal manages to stop it from becoming tiresome. In some ways, you see quite a bit of Armand in him.

Of course, Armand's passion seems far less violent, so that's something to consider.
Antoine glances over his shoulder and notices that some other guests of the party are impatiently waiting for him. "It appears I am needed elsewhere, madame."

However, you quickly run out of things to say, and Antoine takes the time to glance over his shoulder. He notices that some other guests of the party are waiting patiently for him. "It appears I am needed elsewhere, madame. I must go."
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
(You have gained some favor with Antoine)
"Well, it's nice to have you with us, Madame Decaux. Welcome to our meeting of the minds."
You spend the next few minutes walking around the party, wondering what to do next. Yet, your thoughts keep coming back to that fiery, beautiful man.

You spend the next few minutes walking around the party, wondering what to do next. Yet, your thoughts keep coming back to that distressing young man. There's something dark inside of him, you're certain of it.
The two of you chat a while longer. While his main interests are political, you find that he knows a surprising amount about poetry and theater, especially when it comes to legends and heroic epics.
He leaves as quickly as he came, already striding over to the guests in the other group.
"Don't worry. I will find you again."
"The next time we see each other, I'd be more than happy to tell you more, if you'd like."
Everything seems that way with him. Larger than life heroes, in a perpetual clash against evil. Great people sacrificing themselves for the weak.
"Well Madame Decaux, we already have enough people in our midst who are 'just observing'. What this country needs is action."
He eschews the customary bow for a quick upward nod of respect. "My name is Louis Antoine de Sant-Just."
"But please just call me Antoine. I would rather not share my name with tyrants."
Pausing to breathe deeply, his expression visibly softens. "My apologies. With everything that's going on, there's always the concern of the Crown putting spies in our midst."
"Thankfully, I've already heard of your exploits, and I must admit that I like what I've heard."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Alexandre's L: The next morning, you find a letter on your nightstand. Camille must have brought it in while you were still asleep. It’s sealed in blue wax with the initials “A.D.”
Opening it up, you find a letter from Thomas-Alexandre, written with a precise penmanship that makes you think of expensive tutors, diligent practice, and military discipline.

‘Chère Yvette, I’m truly glad that I was fortunate enough to meet you all those nights ago. However, I cannot stand that it came at the cost of such injustice being committed against you by that treacherous host. To that end, I’ve spent the last few days gathering intelligence and believe that I have found something that you will find quite interesting.’

Thomas-Alexandre goes on to describe a particular fountain deep in the city. He’d like to meet with you in secret, as he’s worried about someone intercepting the letter. Is your enemy really that powerful?
‘Please meet me there as soon as you can, and I will share what I know. Très cordiales salutations, Alexandre’
Using your map, it doesn’t take long to figure out where this particular fountain is. In fact, you could visit it today if you like.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Alex's Clue.a: “Very good, what’s our next step?”
“I must say, I’m shocked that a man of honor like yourself is getting mixed up in all this.”
“Let’s go somewhere away from prying eyes.”
“You couldn’t be a little more discreet?”
You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Thomas mentioned in his letter to you.
Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you decided to dress in darker clothes, and stuck to comfortable walking shoes.

He throws back his head and laughs. “I don’t know if you noticed this madame, but I have a tendency to stick out, even when I’m not in uniform.” He stops to glance pointedly at the passers-by staring at him, who struggle to avert their gaze in time.
“At least when I’m wearing the Queen’s colors, people get out of my way.”
“However, if you’d prefer discretion, there’s a tavern nearby, which is always empty in the middle of the day. We can step inside there to talk.”

“I take it that you’ve read my letter, so you know how much I regret what happened to you that night. I’ve been to some of Marcelle’s parties before, so I always knew that she could be vindictive, but this… even the thought of it still makes my blood boil.”
“So, seeing a chance to correct a great injustice, I reached out to some friends around the city in order to gather intelligence. Everyone has a weakness, after all.”

“However, the moment I started digging deeper, something struck me as odd. She claims that her storied family fortune comes from a series of wise investments, so I visited some of her family’s known business partners. They were suspicious at first, but when I used my father’s last name they would often open up to me. Among all the people I visited I couldn’t find evidence that any of her family’s investments were older than thirty years or so.”

“To an aristocratic family, thirty years isn’t a ‘storied fortune’, it’s extremely recent. Yes, there’s some prestige to be had in a sense of legacy, but nothing worth outright lying about. Why would Marcelle’s family pretend their fortune is older than it really is?”
“Marcelle’s weakness is somehow related to her family’s money. Attack that, and justice will be yours.”
“Unfortunately madame, I have no next step.”
“We’ve known each other less than a few days? You really think I’m a man of honor?”

Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.

“While my position grants me it’s fair share of privileges, it also means I can’t go much further than providing you with information. If I was caught actually helping you exact your revenge, it would reflect very poorly on the royal family.”
“No matter how justified that vengeance might be.”

“Besides, I’ve been in a… similar situation. Of course, back then, I never had anyone to help me. If I can make it so that nobody ever faces such misfortunes alone again, I will have changed the world for the better.”
“Well, you’re right! You’re quite the keen judge of character, madame.”

“However, I don’t see anything dishonorable about what I’m doing. Marcelle has slandered your good name, and that of your fiance. Given her wealth and title, you have no means of recourse against her. It’s only right that I help you defend your character.”

“Besides, I’ve been in a… similar situation. Of course, back then, I never had anyone to help me. If I can make it so that nobody ever faces such misfortunes alone again, I will have changed the world for the better.”

“Without strong evidence, it would just be your word against hers. As a commoner, there’s no way you could win such a contest.” Thomas pauses to leave some coins on the table for the wine. “While you don’t seem the sort to give up easily, I wanted to make sure you understood the difficulty of the task ahead of you.”
Alex stands and gives you a theatrical bow. “Au revoir, madame.” With that, he turns and leaves.

You stop to think about this new information. Marcelle is a wealthy aristocrat, but her fortune appears to be younger than she claims. It seems like this knowledge could be useful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.

Looking around, you can’t spot Alex anywhere, so you decide to take a seat at the edge of the fountain. It makes sense to be visible enough that he’ll be able to find you without any flashy waving or signalling.
(You have lost a little credibility)
(You have gained a little favor with Alex)
(You have gained a little favor with Alex)
(Researching Marcelle is now available to visit in the Paris map)
With that, you start to head home, already planning your next move against your sworn enemy.

You get comfortable, smooth out your skirts and pause for a moment to reflect on the decisions that led you to a point in your life where you’re having secret rendezvous with a member of the Queen’s Dragoons to learn more about your hated enemies. If anything, they must have been good decisions.

Not long after you’ve settled in, Alex appears from around a corner and strides up to you. The uniform draws some attention, but people seem to make an effort of getting out of his way, so it must be useful for something. “Bonjour madame!” he calls out pleasantly. “My sincerest apologies for being late.”
“Should we stay here, or discuss this somewhere in private?”
“Magnifique! There’s a tavern nearby that’s always empty in the middle of the day. We’ll discuss things further there.”

Alex leads you to the tavern and you take a seat with him. The barmaid seems to recognize him, and brings over some wine and two glasses.

“Don’t worry, I’ll cover the cost of the wine,” he assures you with a wave.

“I must say, I’m shocked that a man of honor like yourself is getting mixed up in all this.
“Let’s go somewhere away from prying eyes.”
“You couldn’t be a little more discreet?”
You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Thomas mentioned in his letter to you.
Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you decided to dress in darker clothes, and stuck to comfortable walking shoes.

“I take it that you’ve read my letter, so you know how much I regret what happened to you that night. From what I know, Maximin’s always been a bit of a prick, but I never would have suspected him to stoop so low.”

He throws back his head and laughs. “I don’t know if you noticed this madame, but I have a tendency to stick out, even when I’m not in uniform.” He stops to glance pointedly at the passers-by staring at him, who struggle to avert their gaze in time.
“At least when I’m wearing the Queen’s colors, people get out of my way.”
“However, if you’d prefer discretion, there’s a tavern nearby, which is always empty in the middle of the day. We can step inside there to talk.”

“So, seeing a chance to correct a great injustice, I reached out to some friends around the city in order to gather intelligence. Does Maximin actually lead by example, or is all of his revolutionary talk just that... talk?”

“While I couldn’t find a smoking gun, I also couldn’t help but notice that Maximin’s household goes through servants quite quickly.” He reaches into his coat pocket and hands you a list of names, presumably of servants that used to work for Maximin. “Most of them left of their own accord, usually citing things like long hours, skipped wages, and other issues. However, there’s one servant whose leaving was a complete mystery.”
“A servant who leaves their master, but keeps their reasons a secret… if Maximin has a weakness, then this is it.”
“Unfortunately madame, I have no next step.”
“We’ve known each other for less than a few days? You really think I’m a man of honor?”

“While my position grants me it’s fair share of privileges, it also means I can’t go much further than providing you with information. If I was caught actually helping you exact your revenge, it would reflect very poorly on the royal family.”

Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.
“No matter how justified that vengeance might be.”
“Unfortunately,” Thomas pushes out his chair and stands. “I’m needed back at the barracks. Before I go, I must warn you that this mystery servant has gone to great pains to conceal their identity…”
“Well, you’re right! You’re quite the keen judge of character, madame.”

“However, I don’t see anything dishonorable about what I’m doing. Maximin has slandered your good name, and that of your fiance. Given his position, you have no means of recourse against him. It’s only right that I help you defend your character.”

“Besides, I’ve been in a… similar situation. Of course, back then, I never had anyone to help me. If I can make it so that nobody ever faces such misfortunes alone again, I will have changed the world for the better.”

“I couldn’t find this servant’s name, where they live, or even the position they held in Maximin’s home.” Thomas pauses to leave some coins on the table for the wine. “While you don’t seem the sort to give up easily, I wanted to make sure you understood the difficulty of the task ahead of you.”
Thomas stands and gives you a theatrical bow. “Au revoir, madame.” With that, he turns and leaves.
You stop to think about this new information. A mystery servant, who left Maximin’s employment suddenly, and under murky circumstances. It seems fruitful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.

‘Chère Yvette, I’m truly glad that I was fortunate enough to meet you all those nights ago. To that end, I’ve spent the last few days gathering intelligence and believe that I have found something that you will find quite interesting.’

Assets/Resources/Incidents/An Absent Car: “A priest should be willing to help a poor, innocent woman like myself. Let’s go.”
"Perhaps not, I'll examine the other carriages."
"He's a man of honor, sworn to protect France. I'm the next best thing to that. Let's go!"
"Perhaps not, I'll examine the other carriages."
"A wealthy widow, helping a lost soul in need? It works in the books. Let's go."
"Perhaps not, I'll examine the other carriages."
*Sigh* "This has been a night. I'll just leave."
"That's some big talk about titles, from a man who can't even do his own dirty work!"
<Inspect the humble carriage to the left>
<Inspect the bold carriage in the middle>
<Inspect the extravagant carriage to the right>

Before you can reply, a valet grabs you roughly by the arm and drags you from the study. People like your loathsome host don’t need to do their own dirty work, they have servants for that. It takes far longer than you’d like to get outside, as the entryway is crowded with guests preparing to leave.
 
You can feel their eyes weighing heavily on you.

When you finally get to the door, you feel a brutish shove, and you stumble out into the courtyard, barely keeping your balance in your heels. The area is equally crowded, with various persons entering their personal carriages. 

You can hear somebody snicker, but you have no idea who it was.

The carriage to the left of you is of foreign design, and features a gilded crest as its only ornamentation. This crest is emblazoned with a motto in latin, and appears to belong to a priest of some description. The curtains are drawn, but someone appears to have lit a lantern inside. Judging by the occupant’s silhouette, it looks like he’s reading.

The carriage in front of you is obviously being used by a soldier of some sort. The driver is leaning intently towards the passenger compartment, waiting for orders. You recognize the insignia of the Queen’s Dragoons on the side of the carriage. It feels noble and proud, but also capable.

The carriage to your right is richly decorated, yet somber. Swags of black crepe hang from the roof of the carriage, leaving only glimmers of the gold underneath. The decidedly feminine bent of the decorations indicates that the occupant is a woman, but all of the black suggests that she’s in mourning.
You consider the humble carriage for a moment. Is this who you’d like to ride with?
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a modest stranger.
You consider the bold carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to an honorable stranger.
You consider the extravagant carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a mysterious stranger.
You grace the voyeurs with a haughty sneer before leaving towards your own carriage.
The only thing left to do is go home.

(You have lost some favor with members of the Revolution)
(You have gained some favor with members of the Crown)
(You have gained some credibility)
It's gone.

"He went home!" A passing coachman says helpfully, while adjusting the harness on a particularly grumpy horse. "Doorman came out about an hour ago, and told him you wanted the coach to leave without you. Seemed real important, so he went home."

Choosing to take the high ground, you straighten your posture and hold your head high, striding towards your carriage as if it was your intention to leave like this all along. While you make a great effort to haughtily avoid eye contact with all of those watching you, you can tell that some of them are quite surprised by your decorum in this dire situation.

Boiling over with anger, you turn and rain insults upon the house. In fact, you consider throwing your shoe through one of their windows, before you remember how much you like that shoe. It’s then that you notice that several of the carriages have stopped, just to watch your display.
However, when you arrive at the place where your carriage is parked, you quickly find out that… it isn’t.

Scanning the faces of your new audience, you see the glaring, unamused faces of the various party guests. You’re certain that your hatred of Maximin, the Revolution, and everything else he stands for is going to be well known throughout the city soon enough.
You check to make sure that you’re in the right place, but to no avail. The carriage you hired is simply not there.

Before you can even respond, he gets his carriage moving, leaving you alone with yet another indignity. 

Going back to Maximin is obviously unacceptable, it’s too far to walk home, and most of the other guests have already left.
However, there appear to be three other carriages waiting to leave, each of them quite different. Perhaps one of them can help?
Assets/Resources/Incidents/An Amorous In: "Oh, you are so kind! Please do!"
"Perhaps, in a moment."
"I'm fine for now, thank you."
"Non monsieur, you may not. I am fine by myself."
"I'm so glad to hear that! Can you help me find my fiance?"
"Oui, I think it is."
"What happened to be unable to refuse a woman in need?"
"Oh, nowhere in particular, just around the tavern with you."
"I am trying to find my fiance, Baron Armand de Marbo. Can you help?"
You look around the unfamiliar tavern, trying to find Armand. Your eyes scan for his chestnut hair, your ears strain to hear the sound of his infectious laugh.
"May I... escort you?" His smile is broad and cocky.
"Now, where are you looking to go?"

This isn't the first time you've flirted with strangers since you were engaged. Armand often got so wrapped up in his political endeavours that you'd feel ignored. A few coy glances in the wrong direction were usually enough to get Armand to remember that you, and a world outside his furious letter writing, existed.

"Well, that is what I offered to help you do." The man grimaces, and begrudgingly holds out his arm. You take it happily as he conducts you about the tavern, visiting all the places that you suspect Armand might be.
Once that happened, Armand would woo you back from the hapless object of your deception and life would go on. Nobody ever got hurt, and there was simply something fun about it.

With that in mind, you stroll around the tavern looking for Armand, arm in arm with a stranger. Eventually, you realize that Armand is nowhere to be found and that your playful deception has been a waste.

Or, at least, simply practice.
"I'm thinking about grabbing another bottle of wine, care to join me?"
"Oh madame, you know where to find me when you're ready!" He says with a happy grin before going to request another bottle from the tavern keeper.

Sensing the shift in the conversation, he tries to win you over, but the drinks he's had finally seem to be catching up with him. 

"But madame, we can, escort... there." He points towards a table that's crowded with some of his friends. One of them waves awkwardly to you.

However, after a few minutes searching the tavern, it starts to become clear that Armand is nowhere to be found.

"Madame, I believe this is where we part ways." Your newfound guide says, gently pulling away from you.
Before you can respond, with a wave that is barely as polite as decorum requires, he departs to seek the affection of a different young woman.

"... something I offered to help you do." The man grimaces, and begrudgingly holds out his arm. You take it happily as he conducts you about the tavern, visiting all the places that you suspect Armand might be. A few of the patrons smirk at your clever ploy.

You take this opportunity to explore the rest of the tavern. Flirting with strangers isn't half as fun if there's nobody there to see you do it.

Besides, finding Armand is your real priority.

You politely slip away from him, and his increasingly desperate suggestions. You take this opportunity to explore the rest of the tavern. Flirting with strangers isn't half as fun if there's nobody there to see you do it.

Besides, finding Armand is your real priority.
He scowls and turns on his heel, muttering something ungentlemanly under his breath. Just when you thought yourself rid of him, he shoots you a glance that's surprisingly threatening.
Someone clears their throat behind you.
However, after a few minutes searching the tavern, it starts to become clear that Armand is nowhere to be found.
"Oh, that is..."
"... not what I meant at all, and you know it, madame!" he replies with surprising venom.
With a wave that is barely as polite as decorum requires, he departs to seek the affection of a different young woman.

You didn't think that refusing an invitation from a stranger was rude, but perhaps he was raised to think otherwise. Judging by the stares of the other patrons in the tavern, they seem to feel the same way as yourself.
(You have gained some credibility)

Your turn around to find yourself face to face with an unfamiliar young man. He's well dressed and handsome enough, but it's the middle of day and he already smells like two bottles of wine. "Pardonne-moi madame, but I can never ignore the sight of a woman in need, and you appear to be lost."
(You have gained a little peril)
Now you're truly glad that you refused to go anywhere with him.
(You have gained a little credibility)
(You have lost a little credibility)
The surprised man's face broadens into a happy grin as you reach out and take his arm. "Why it appears that I arrived just in time!"
His brow furrows and he turns up his nose. "Madame, I'm just trying to help. There's no need to be so rude."
"Madame, I believe this is where we part ways." Your newfound guide says, gently pulling away from you.
With a wave that is barely as polite as decorum requires, he departs to seek the affection of a different young woman.
"Madame, I have escorted you up and down. We have sought your Armand to no avail. I have done my duty." He says simply, and shrugs. "Now if you excuse me, I must return to my compatriots."
He walks away to rejoin his friends, who appear to be even deeper into the wine than he is.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/An Awkward Me: “Just delivering a painting on behalf of Madame Le Brun. You’ll love it.”
“Well, I was about to tell you how attractive you are when you don’t talk, but now you’ve spoiled the effect.”

Checking your mental map of the venue, you’re absolutely certain that this room will the best place to hang up the painting, and expose Maximin’s crimes. For a moment, you lose yourself in thought while you survey the room for the perfect spot to hang your masterpiece of vengeance. The room is even mostly empty.
It’s then that you hear someone clear their throat behind you.

“I should have expected such a base attack from someone as ignorant and unrefined as yourself. I am told that you have recently decided to latch onto Madame Le Brun. Perhaps you hoped the Queen’s personal painter would take you a little further than your Armand, yes?”
“What. Are. You. Doing. Here?” Maximin growls at you.

He squints at you suspiciously, then does the same to Camille, who does her best to haughtily avoid any eye contact.

“The Queen’s personal painter wants to present a painting at my salon? That is rather unexpected.”
He sneers are your insult, and clutches his wineglass hard enough that his knuckles start to turn white.

“I’m glad that she understands the superiority of my tastes.” He says with a broad smile before advancing on Camille and reaching for the sheet covering the painting. “I will, of course, have to inspect the artwork to make sure that it meets my refined standards.”

Before you can think of an acceptable excuse, someone else decides to join your conversation.

“Oh, Baron Maximin! It’s so great to see you.”
“Oh yes, how may I help you, madame?” He turns to answer the woman behind him, having to prioritize etiquette over his own curiosity.
Spying your opportunity, you join the conversation, in order to give Camille some time to set up the painting.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/An Impasse.as: The political hobbyists of France has been breathlessly following the events of the Estates General over the last few weeks, and their watchful eyes have led to a stunning revelation.

A revelation that the Estates General has currently accomplished abolutely nothing. While the King has attempted to keep the discussion focused on tax reform to deal with France's crumbling budget, every single debate has stalled out due to fights over voting rights and representation.

Members of the third estate won't let this issue go, as they're the only estate that pays any taxes under the current system. However, any attempts to change this would be inevitably shut down by the first and second estate; who both pay no taxes, and each have just as many votes as the third estate.

Yet, the nobility of the first estate have managed to maintain the upper hand. They have the backing of tradition. Slowly, the third estate's continued demands for such an unprecedented solution in regards to representation have made them seem like bickering children.
The longer this impasse lasts, the more the tension will build. However, if it keeps building, then it won't be long before something snaps.

Yet, the bourgeoisie and the revolutionaries of the third estate have been slowly gaining ground in the public eye. Their claims that the system is unfairly balanced ring more true every day, as people all across the country starve. Every day, mutters of discontent grow louder and louder.
And so, in Paris, life goes on.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/An Invitation: "Splendid! A party!"
"What? Why didn't you tell me sooner?"
"What? Why didn't you tell me sooner?"
"What do you know about the Viscountess de Foix?"
"Well, at least I have a party to go to!"
"Camille, why didn't you tell me about this invitation sooner?"
"Well, at least I have a party to go to!"
"Camille, why didn't you tell me about this invitation sooner?"
"Camille, do you know anything about this Baron Maximin?"
"Splendid! A party!"

Early the next morning, Camille approaches you, occasionally wringing her apron with her hands. She’s obviously nervous.

“Madame, there’s something you should know…” Taking a deep breath, she continues.
“You’re expected to attend a party the day after tomorrow, held by one Viscountess Marcelle de Foix. I mean, Armand replied to the invitation, but you were to be his date.”
"I'm sorry Madame, but a Viscountess... it just felt above my station, so I tried not to pay attention whenever she came up." Camille replies with a shrug.
"I hope that helps Madame."
"I know that she never visited the house. Monsieur Armand seemed to like her, but from what I could tell she was a little... how do I put this?"
"Judgemental! She was a little, very judgemental. I hope that helps, Madame."
"I'm sorry Madame, but I don't know much. It would have been improper for me to pry into Monsieur Armand's affairs." Camille replies with a surprising earnestness.

"All I know is that this Baron de Termes is a very outspoken political type. Always going on about 'constitutions' and 'natural law'. Monsieur Armand attended a lot of his salons, but didn't always look happy when he came back from them."
(Le Petit Mogol is now available to visit in the Paris map)
"If you head out today, you should be well prepared for the party tomorrow night."
Camille looks visibly relieved. “Parfait! If you need anything washed or prepared, just ask!”

Camille looks nervously at the ground for a second, wringing her apron in her hands again.

“Well, after I told you about Monsieur Armand’s absence, you seemed upset. I felt like the last thing I should do was give you an obligation, right after bad news.”

"That reminds me!" Camille exclaims. "If you’re going to a party, you should probably make sure you’re dressed appropriately. Fashion moves so quickly here that people retire outfits before they even wear out!"
“Fortunately, the bad news was yesterday!”
At this proclamation, you can’t help but notice that Camille’s uniform has been repaired many, many times.

Camille continues. "Monsieur Armand was always going through clothes so quickly. He said that every outfit had a certain amount of novelty. Every time you wore them, the novelty would go down a bit. In fact, even a little thing like wearing the same thing twice in a row could run the novelty out faster. Can you imagine?"

"Fortunately, he knew the most delightful clothier on Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré. She runs a shop called 'Le Petit Mogol'. I’ll draw you some directions." Immediately she starts sketching some directions, mostly just simple renderings of local landmarks.
"You're expected to attend a party the day after tomorrow, held by one Baron Maximin de Termes. I mean, Armand replied to the invitation, but you were to be his date."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/An Unwise Rep: The day has opened with staggering news. The King has just dismissed Monsieur Jaques Necker, the Controller General of Finances.

Monsieur Necker's reputation as a friend of the people was so great that he was welcomed into office with a fireworks display. While it's understood that he was always a controversial figure, his competence has never been in question.
He argued for the abolition of serfdom, and once broke a policy stalemate by leaking the national budget to the press, in order to show the people how dire the county's situation really was.
However, this public favor wasn't enough to save him. The King dismissed him from office, and he has been replaced by Monsieur Joseph-François Foullon.

Dismissing Necker was already guaranteed to be unpopular, and replacing him with a converative deeply loyal to the interests of the nobility would have been bad enough, but Monsieur Foullon isn't just disliked. 

He is despised.

During the last famine, when asked of the plight of the common people, Monsieur Foullon replied "If those rascals have no bread, then let them eat hay!"

The common people have not forgotten this.
The great tension that hangs over the country continues to build. Even alone in your home, you can feel it in the air, heavy and thick, like the smoke from a burning building.
And so, in Paris, life goes on.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Antoine's Inv: This morning, it takes you a touch longer than usual to leave the warm cocoon of your blankets. When you do, you notice that Camille has left a letter on your nightstand. The wax seal shines red like fresh blood.

You break the seal with a deft slice from your letter opener. You can immediately tell that the handwriting is Antoine's. He writes quickly enough that you can find small spatters of ink at the top of his compressed, precise letters.

'<i>Chere<i> Yvette,

I've grown dissatisfied with the ceaseless inaction of my peers and have decided to do something myself. I would like you to join me, should you find yourself inclined to the cause of liberty'

The letter goes on to describe a location where you could meet him.
'Fear not. I'm certain that you will enjoy this as much as the royalists will hate it. Affectueusement, - Antoine'
(Direct Action is now available to visit in the Paris map)
You check his directions against your map. If you head out now, it might be possible to meet up with Antoine today.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Apprehended.a: “I’m free? I can just go?”
“Are you serious? What was I even charged with?”
“Oh, but Father, I just thought you were here to save a wicked woman’s soul.”
“Can you actually free me? Do you have that power?”
“How did you know I was here?”
“Oh, but Father, I just thought you were here to save a wicked woman’s soul.”
“Can you actually free me? Do you have that power?”
“How did you know I was here?”
“How did you know I was here?”
“You know me so well.”
“So, it was just random chance?”
“So, it was just random chance?”
The next few moments are a blur.
The watchman grabs you by the wrist, his calloused hand feels like a vice. You pull back and scream in shock. Alarmed by the sound, more of the watchmen’s compatriots appear.

The next day, you bang at the cell door to ask what you’ve been charged with. One of the watchmen says he’ll go find out, but you never hear from him again. The others don’t even bother to answer you.

That night, you wake up to find the fatest rat you’ve ever seen crawling on your leg and trying to eat your shoes. With a few choice words and some shakes of your leg, you manage to shoo it away. 

The obese thing squeaks indignantly at you before waddling away and squeezing into a hole in the wall.

The next morning, you are so bored that you have decided to name the rat. His name is François-Louis, and he is a successful restauranteur in the rat community. He hoped to serve your shoes to his patrons as a lavish delicacy.

You can’t wait to get out of here.

You dream fitfully that night, your sleeping mind trying to compensate for your lack of waking activity by bombarding you with every colorful and outlandish imagery imaginable. At least one of them is a fat rat in a waistcoat.
The morning of the third day, the door opens.
“Alright madame, you’re free to go.”

“I mean, we can keep you here for longer, but we’d have to start charging rent,” the watchman replies with a shrug. “We looked into your background and it doesn’t look like you’re an enemy of the crown. You were just trespassing, and it felt like three days in a cell was enough.”

“What were you charged with?” the watchman asks, indignant at any attempt to question his authority. He scowls, and begins to stretch the limits of his imagination. “Well, you were trespassing and…” 

It’s an impressive effort, with unimpressive results.
“... and trespassing. We didn’t find anything stolen, and you didn’t really do anything else. So after three days, you’re free to go!”
“What is the meaning of this? You’re keeping a lost and vulnerable Christian woman in need of guidance, amongst this loathsome squalor? Have you no shame?”

Accusations are shouted. A sergeant with breath that stinks of cheap wine demands to know who you’re working for, his fat fingers dangerously close to your face. Everything starts getting louder and more chaotic with every passing moment.
“No, I shall not be calm! In the name of Saint Nicholas of Myra, you will turn this lost soul over to my care! You will do this for the sake of her soul, and dare I say, for you own!”
The shouting continues for a little while longer until you hear the jingling of keys, and the creaking of the door being unlocked.
“Here she is, Father Sidotti,” the watchman sighs. He looks like he just wants this entire ordeal to be over.
“Here she is, Father Sidotti,” the watchman sighs. He looks like he just wants this entire ordeal to be over. “Her associate is being held a few cells over, will you be needing that one too?”
“Leave us, my son,” Ludovico commands, his voice steely and stern.

With a weary nod, the watchman leaves the room and shuts the door behind himself. 

You don’t hear the door lock.
“I have to admit, I didn’t expect us to meet again under these circumstances.” Ludovico says with a mischievous grin.
Ludovico smiles at your reply, and for a moment he looks you up and down in silence.

“If by ‘power’, you mean ‘the watchmen can’t make me leave, and giving up a minor criminal is better than having me stand in their post loudly abjuring their immortal souls all day’ then yes, I have that power.”

“One of my many duties in the city is visiting prisoners for confessionals. After all, those who’ve fallen into wickedness are the ones who need our Lord’s guidance the most.” He gestures to the Bible in his hands. It’s well cared for but also well worn, without any gilding or ornamentation.
The watchman grabs you by the wrist. Hansel grabs him by the throat. People start screaming. More watchmen appear. Everything starts getting louder and more chaotic with every passing moment.
“Yes, I will be collecting her hireling as well. Leave us, my son,” Ludovico commands, his voice steely and stern.

With a weary nod, the watchman leaves the room and shuts the door behind himself. 

You don’t hear the door lock.
“I have to admit, I didn’t expect us to meet again under these circumstances.” Ludovico says with a mischievous grin.
“Well, you see signora, I must admit that I’ve never had to deal with a case as… interesting as your own. I think we’d have to see each other quite a lot before I found some kind of solution.”
“But I would rather have this conversation somewhere less… dank and depressing.” Ludovico gestures towards the door. “After you, Yvette.”

Outside, you breathe deeply, tasting fresh air for the first time in a while. It’s a simply pleasure, but one you already missed. The city continues in its daily routine, as if nothing had even happened.

“Your freedom, Yvette, has been delivered unto you.” Ludovico pronounces, with a dramatic sweep of his hands, before continuing. “While I would absolutely love to stay with you and help you celebrate it, I unfortunately have a lot more prisons to visit before the day is up.”

“I find that the best way to deal with the powerful is make myself a balance of ‘helpful samaritan’ and ‘irritating nuisance’. If they give me what I want, then I solve one of their problems, and they don’t have to deal with me anymore. I get what I want, and they still get to feel like they won.” He says idly, examining your cell.
“I could go on, but I would rather have this conversation somewhere less… dank and depressing.” Ludovico gestures towards the door. “After you, Yvette.”

“I also find that knowing what the criminals are up to is a great way to understand what’s really happening in a city.” Ludovico admits with a shrug. “This allows my letters to Rome be a little more… complete.”

An hour later, you’re sitting alone in a dark cell back at the Guet Royal’s watch post. You’re not sure what you’ve been charged with, but this whole situation is obviously less than ideal. 

Somewhere else in the watch post, a pickpocket is screaming about his innocence. His alibi is getting more creative with every passing moment.

He turns to you with a wry smile. “Now imagine my surprise, when on my way to tend to the souls of the thugs and cutpurses of the 7th Arrondissement, I happen to see your name among the roll of prisoners.”
“Obviously, you couldn’t possibly be guilty of any crime, so I decided to intercede,” he says with a wink.
“And yet with all of this knowledge, I’m still hoping to know you better.”
“But please, I would rather have this conversation somewhere less… dank and depressing.” Ludovico gestures towards the door. “After you, Yvette.”
“I wouldn’t say ‘random chance’. After all, the Lord works in mysterious ways.” Ludovico replies with a shrug.
“Your freedom, has been delivered unto you, Yvette.” Ludovico pronounces, with a dramatic sweep of his hands.
“May we meet again soon, under better circumstances.” Ludovico says, with a slow and polite nod of his head. You reply with the appropriate curtsey.

Ludovico quickly disappears into the crowds, and you are left alone. A few gawkers note your bedraggled state and you can easily assume that the fact that you just spent a night in a jail cell is going to make it to all the right people.

You take some comfort in knowing that at least you’re not in prison anymore.
(+1 Scandal)
You start the walk home, already relishing the idea of a hot meal, a long bath, and a fresh change of clothes.
Ludovico turns to Hansel “It has also been delivered unto you… Singore...”

The hours pass until morning. You feel nothing, other than the truly stultifying boredom of being locked in a stone box by yourself. At least it's enough time for people to forget about your more indiscreet actions.
“My name is Hansel, Father.” Hansel replies gruffly. “I am Madame Decaux’s doorman.”
“Her dooman?” Ludovico asks, his eyes resting on Hansel’s recently returned sword.
“Ja. The city has many doors. Some of them are more dangerous than others. Madame Decaux pays me to make sure they’re opened, or kept shut.”

“I see!” Ludovico replies, clapping his hands together as if that just answered everything. “While I would absolutely love to stay, I unfortunately have a lot more prisons to visit before the day is up. May we meet again soon, under better circumstances.” Ludovico says, with a slow and polite nod of his head. You reply with the appropriate curtsey. Hansel gives a grunt of appreciation.

Ludovico disappears into the crowds, leaving you and Hansel alone. A few gawkers note your bedraggled state and you can easily assume that the fact that you just spent a night in a jail cell is going to make it to all the right people.

You take some comfort in knowing that at least you’re not in prison anymore.
(+1 Scandal)
With neither a chastisement nor an apology, you’re lead out onto the street, and the door of the watch post is shut loudly behind you. Just like that, you’re free.

A few gawkers note your bedraggled state and you can easily assume that the fact that you just spent a few days in a jail cell is going to make it to all the right people.
(+1 Scandal)
You start the walk home, already relishing the idea of a hot meal, a long bath, and a fresh change of clothes

Without so much as an apology, you’re lead out onto the street, and the door of the watch post is slammed loudly behind you. A few gawkers note your bedraggled state and you can easily assume that the fact that you just spent a few days in a jail cell is going to make it to all the right people.
(+1 Scandal)
You start the walk home, already relishing the idea of a hot meal, a long bath, and a fresh change of clothes.
You feel yourself being jostled in the sudden melee like a piece of flotsam in a turbulent river. You try to find an exit, a way to flee, but it’s a struggle just to stay standing.

(You have lost quite a bit of credibility)
(You ahve lost some favor with everyone)

(You have lost quite a bit of credibility)
(You have lost some favor with everyone, but Ludovico)
(You have lost a staggering amount of peril)

An hour later, you’re sitting alone in a dark cell back at the Guet Royal’s watch post. You’re not sure what you’ve been charged with, but this is obviously less than ideal. 

Hansel’s been placed in a seperate cell, but you can hear him cursing to himself in German occasionally, so you know he’s fine.

That morning turns to night. Meals are pushed through a slot in the door, and you do your best to stomach the lumpy, tasteless food. While you could refuse to eat out of spite, you get the feeling that the guards would barely notice.
Your malaise is suddenly interrupted by the distant sound of a commotion, followed by the enraged shouts of a familiar voice...
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Armand's Lett: You wake up to find a letter waiting for you on your bedside table, which wouldn't be unusual save for the fact that it's sealed in plain, uncolored wax, which hasn't been stamped with a sigil of any sort.

Opening the letter, you immediately recognize Armand's handwriting. However, the writing style is remarkably brief for him, and you find yourself instinctively checking for another three or four pages of text that don't exist.

'Chère Yvette, Johanna recently finished setting up a meeting place where we can meet with notable individuals who are attending the Estates General. More importantly, these are persons who are interested in learning more about the goals of our humble society.'

It sounds to you like some very influential people sound genuinely intrigued by this Frankish Hapsburgian Society business. You read on a little further and find an address. It looks like these events aren't happening very far from your home.
'Your knowledge, cannyness and infamy would be an amazing asset to us. I would love to see you there.'
You put down the letter, and check your calendar. You might be able to visit that place today.
(Foreign Entanglements is now available for you to visit on the Paris map)
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Armand's Purp: Armand's Purpose
"Dumas is brave because he's suffered, and doesn't want to see others suffer the same way."
"Alex is a fun diversion for me. Nothing more and nothing less."
"The rumors are true, he's naive and not nearly as loyal to the Church as he appears."
"They're wrong, I'm no temptress. Ludovico is thoughtful, romantic, and sweet."
"Ludovico is just a fun diversion to me. Nothing more, nothing less."
"She's exactly that, a mysterious wealthy woman who likes to indulge her... darker tastes."
"Madame Gazel is more than her eccentricities. She's passionate, and dedicated."
"Honorade is merely a fun diversion for me. Nothing more, and nothing less."
"This is amazing Armand. It's perfect!"
"Armand, this is treason."
"I see, so this is why the Viscountess du Foix hated you so much."
"I see, so this is why Maximin hated you so much."
"But, of course."
"Nope, I'm going to steal everything you own while you're gone."
"Do you really have to leave?"
"Oh, but of course!"
"Well, this has certainly taken a turn for the exciting..."
"Just a moment Armand, I don't know how to feel about this Johanna, can you tell me more?"
"How fantastic, I've managed to finally find my fiance and now I'm an accomplice to treason."
"He's exactly as you say, a fiery man who demands dedication form those around him."
"He's more than than. He's thoughtful, and passionate about defending the common people."
"Antoine is merely a fun diversion for me, no more and no less."
"Armand, I just don't want to talk about her."
"It's true. She's brilliant, and couldn't give a damn about what the aristocrats think."
"Her aloofness is a front, something she puts on to protect herself from the world."
"Elisabeth is merely a fun diversion for me. Nothing more, and nothing less."
"He's simply that, extremely skilled in his trade. A man of brashness, valor, and chivalry."
It's a long walk to get to the Armand's address on the western edge of Paris, but compared to the events of the last month or so, it's as easy as a stroll around the block.

The neighborhood is a poor one, but filled with the kind of poor who still feel that they can improve their station. Persons strut proudly down the streets wearing one or two articles of fine clothing over their worn out ones, seeming almost a parody of the wealthy artisocrats who glide about La Place Royale.
"Oh, but of course!" He replies happy, and a little relieved.

"Yvette, can you please at least try to be a little open minded? Everything is already so difficult, and it's not going to be any easier if the two of you spend all this time angrily circling eachother."
(You have lost a little favor with Armand)
"I understand that a man and woman living under the same roof leads to all sort of... assumptions."

"After all, if the gossip is true, you've been recently entangled with Louis-Antoine de Saint Just. The young revolutionary playwright that's so dedicated to their cause, that many of his compatriots are afriad of him."
"I think we can both agree that if there's one thing that life in Paris has taught us, it's that few things are as they appear to be." He laughs.
(You have have gained a little favor with Armand)

"Though she'd never take credit for it, she's the real founder of this society I've become a part of." He says, gesturing to hte walls, which are covered in maps and notes. "She's clever, tenacious, and she speaks French so well for someone who didn't grow up with the language."

You think back on your brief conversations with her, and you never even detected a hint of an foreign accent when she spoke. Why would she put so much effort into sounding exactly like a native French speaker?
"I'm really glad to see you reacting this way." Armand admits. "I was afraid that you'd be jealous of her."

To them, these one or two expensive things are both a luxury, and valuable armor against the sneers and derision of those better off. Time and again, you've seen that the poorer one is, the harder it is to gain someone's trust. In lives like theirs, any scrap of trust could be the difference between survival, and complete destitution.
(You have gained some favor with Armand)
"My friend Charles introduced me to her when I first moved to Paris, and while our organization here has been growing rapidly, I've essentially become her closest confidant."

"As for myself, am I assuming too much when I ask if you're romantically involved with Madame Le Brun? I've heard a few rumors, but nothing conshe does enjoy her discretion. Those rumors also call her a painter so skilled that she's grown detached from the concerns of society."
"I can safely say that, during my first days in Paris, I had my fair share of rude awakenings in that regard."

"Like that Corporal Dumas character you've been seeing, if the gossip is to be believed. A humble dragoon from Saint-Domingue who seems to be skilled at nearly everything he does. I imagine there's more to him than meets the eye."
"On the other hand, from what I've heard in all the gossip that's been circulating about you, you've adjusted extremely quickly. Perhaps Paris is where you were meant to be after all!"

"Will Father Sidotti be another such surprise for me? I've heard stories of priests engaging in secret daliances, but I've never been certain as to whether it was merely rumor. They say you're stringing along a naive young priest, painitng you as a wicked tempress."
"Speaking of gossip circulating around you, I've heard quite a bit involing you and one Madame Gazel. A mysterious widow with... eccentric tastes."

"Oh yes! I have something to show you!" He says, leading you up two creaky flight of stairs to a window. It immediately feels different from the other ones in the house, because you can see that the glass here has actually been cleaned and polished.
"Look out at all that." He says gesturing to the city. You're at the very top of a small hill, and all the buildings in this neighborhood are short, lending you a remarkably clear view of Paris.

You manage to find Armand's new home. Three stories tall, but thin and leaning to one side, it feels less like a home and more like an old man, crippled with age. It reminds you of your own living situation. However, judging from the dust and cracked window panes, he doesn't have anyone like Camille to take care of things.

“I come here to think, every day. To think about the responsibility I have to these people. While I'll never see them all, I can see their houses, their workplaces, and all the other places that serve as the stages for their lives."
"Few of them will ever have the power to change things, sometimes by the mere circumstances of their birth. Still, that only makes it even more important that I do something right."
"That's why I joined this group, 'The Frankish Hapsburgian Society'. In Austria, the House of Hapsburg has managed reforms for more efficient governance, religious tolerance, land reforms, and more."

"Here, in France, we have a battle brewing between two disastrous powers. First there's the aristocracy, who would march our country off a cliff if it allowed them to preserve their priveleges for another day, and the revolutionaries, who can only agree on what they wish to tear down, but not on what they'll build afterwards."

"Her Majesty, our Queen, was born Maria Antonia Josepha Johanna, daughter of the Empress of Austria. Her brother, Joseph II is the Holy Roman Emperor. If our two countries were brought together under a single rule, France would have the resources to solve its immediate crises, and the political will necessary to do away with our more backwards traditions."
"Every single day, I look out this window, and think of all the people that we could save."
"Well, it's certainly amaizng, but it's far from perfect. What we're aiming to do is perilous indeed."
"You're right. It's treason, the highest crime imaginable."

"Well spotted! I noticed early on that Marcelle had an outsized influence among the aristocrats in the second estate. So, I approached her with our proposals. I thought she'd understand what we were trying to preserve."
"Well spotted! I noticed early on that Maximin had an outsized influence among the revolutionaries in the third estate. So, I approached him with our proposals."
Well, Armand isn't the only one living there. There's also this Johanna woman. You're still uncertain of her role in all of this.
He takes his hand in yours. "Yet, there's nobody I'd rather have at my side to fight for this future with, than you."
(You have gained a little favor with Armand)

Armand must have chosen this address because he wouldn't stand out here. In his fashion of a fine nobleman's jacket and plainer clothers underneath, he'd look like any other proud and desperate man, trying to strive for something better.
"Murder and theft are also crimes, but the ancestors of every King and Queen in all the world gained their dominions through conquest. Still, years later, we celebrate their crimes as victories."
"We will break the law, yes, but it's in service to a good that's greater than any one law. Can't you see that?"
Armand stares silently out the window, looking out at Paris, and it's people. You stare with him.
(You have lost a little favor with Armand)

"Instead, she was furious, and threatened to have me arrested for treason. Thankfully, I had taken the time to research her beforehand, and had noticed that something was strange about her family's finances. I didn't get much more information beyond that, but my threat to reveal this information was enough to make her think that having me arrested could lead to her undoing."
"Of course, you managed to pull on those threads for much longer than I did, and exposed her for the fraud that she was."
"That's why she denounced you publicly to discredit me. It's also why I believe she's the one who sent men to my home to attack me. She wanted to silence anyone who could be a threat to her."
You knock on the door, and hear some movement inside before someone opens the door just a crack to see who it is.
"Is it strange to say that I missed how clever you are? It always feels like you're one step ahead."
(You have gained some favor with Armand)

"However, I'd misjudged him. He was livid that I would even suggest such a thing, and claimed that I'd be placing our people under the yoke of a different tyranny. He even threatened to report me to the authorities for treason. Thankfully, I had "

"Thankfully, I had taken the time to research him beforehand, which is how I discovered that something... dark had occurred between him and a former chambermaid of his. I didn't learn much beyond that, but my threat to reveal this information was enough to make him think that having me arrested could lead to his undoing."

"That's why he denounced you publicly to discredit me. It's also why I believe that he's the one who sent men to my home to attack me. Maximin wanted to silence anyone who could be a threat to his image as a paragon of equality and liberty."
"Of course, you managed to pull on those threads for much longer than I did, and exposed him for the predatory monster that he was."
Without a word, you he reaches out, grabs you by the waist, and pulls your closer. Instinctively, you rest your head in a crook of his shoulder that is so familiar, yet you almost forgot how it felt.
The two of you watch the sun set on the city, together. The lights of city slowly appear, like a second set of stars.

Quietly, he says "I have to leave for a meeting tonight. More secrets and skullduggery. We have something coming up that will involve convincing a lot of people to our cause, and I think you'd be perfect for it. I'll leave message with Camille when we get close to the date."
"You can stay here for a little while longer, if you like. Can I trust you to let yourself out?"
Spotting you, Armand flings open the door and bounds outside. "Oh mon cher, it's great to see you again! Please, come in."
He shakes his head and laughs. "What am I saying? Of course I can."
He laughs. "Oh villainous woman, please have mercy! I am but a poor baron who has fallen on hard times."
"Of course I have to leave." He replies, sounding genuinely hurt. "Why don't you take me at my word? I'm not just trying to avoid you, I have responsibilities."
(You have lost a little favor with Armand)
Armand then departs for his meeting, leaving you alone in his house.

The two of you spend the next few minutes giggling as you chase each other around the house. You keep trying to steal various books and silverware, while he keeps trying to put the purloined items back in their proper place. Eventually, he catches you trying to walk away with his broken grandfather clock, and you both collapse in fits of laughter.
(You have gained some favor with Armand)
(You have gained a little favor with Armand)
You relax, and asses your situation for a while, before leaving yourself.
Alone, you walk down the nightime streets by yourself, considering all you've just learned.
You walk in, and he takes your cloak from you to hang it on a coat rack. The inside of the building is remarkably sparse, and without any decorations. It feels more like an outpost than a home.

Heady with the thoughts of the adventures that are surely awaiting you and Armand, you head home with a light step. Even the darkest shadows hold no danger for you tonight, merely the possibility of further excitement.

Your head hangs heavy, as if a millstone had been placed around your neck, as you trudge home. You spend the long walk home through the dark wondering how, exactly, you'll manage to rescue yourself from this latest set of dangers.
He reads your facial expression and holds his hands up innocently. "Please don't take me for a jealous boor, Yvette. As I may have said before, I don't blame you, given the circumstances."
"I'm more curious than anything, as I've never met her. What's she really like?"

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Artistic Lice: "Monsieur, please give her a chance. She's just trying to maintain her reputation."
"I'm sorry, but this just doesn't feel like something I can do."
"Excuse me! You in there! Are you sure you that you want to be so violent towards the Queen's personal painter?"
"Elisabeth, are you alright?"
"What was all that about?"
"Who is this man, and how would you like me to burn his house down?"
Walking the crowded streets of Paris, you gasp in the oppressive heat. Every time you inhale, it feels like you can smell every single person around you.

Just as you feel the relief of a cool breeze, you notice something out of the corner of your eye. It's Elisabeth, the painter, and she's talking to someone through an open door. Her foot is firmly planted in the doorway.
(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
"Yes, really, that's illegal. Don't laugh."

"Not only did I have to pay a mountain of fines that I could barely afford, the black mark on my reputation nearly cost me my career before it started. However, all my old paintings are still circulating, and still doesn't look good for me. So, I'm trying to buy them all back."
"As you can see." She says pointing to the door. "Some of my old customers aren't exactly fond of the idea."
You look at the door, and wonder if there's anything you can do to help.
You can hear someone uncertainly shifting around on the other side of the door.
"C'est la vie. Elisabeth sighs. "I'll just have to think of something by myself."
Carefully placing your ear to the door, you hear frantic scrambling on the other side of the door before it opens and someone steps outside.
(You have lost some favor with Elisabeth)
The door opens, and the man slowly steps outside. "What does your reputation have to do with my painting?"
"No, monsieur, this isn't a joke. I'm willing to pay a very reasonable price for it and-"
"I don't care!" He yells through the door. "It's my painting and you'll part it from my cold dead hands!"
You part ways with Elisabeth and head home. Sometimes the best choice is to not get involved in other people's problems.
"Did you have to be so loud?" He hisses at you, frantically. "Some of us have reputations to uphold, you know."
(You have gained a little peril)
(You have lost a little favor with Elisabeth)
"Yes! I'm one of those people!" Elisabeth hisses back. "Just let me buy the painting, and I'll go."
"But I like the portrait..." He mumbles. "My wife commissioned it for my birthday."
"Well... oh..." Elisabeth replies, mulling over the problem.
"What if I painted you a new one instead?" She ventures with a smile.
"Only if you still pay for the old painting." He grumbles.
"Ow!" She yelps as the door slams shut on her foot, leaping back as she recoils with pain.
"Ugh... fine!"
The two of them spend the better part of the next ten minutes sorting out the specific details, of which there seem to be many. Eventually, they reach something mutually agreeable.
He goes back inside and, after a long pause, Elisabeth breathes a sigh of relief.
(You have lost some credibility)
"I need to buy that painting back because I... sort of made it illegally." Elisabeth admits. "I never meant to deceive you, but please, let me get rid of it."
"Thank you, Yvette... I'm amazed that you managed to get him to see sense. This is going to make things a lot easier for me."
(You have gained a decent amount of favor with Elisabeth)
The two of you walk and talk together, still riding the energy of your success. Eventually, you both part ways, and you head home.
"It's alright, you did your best." Elisabeth sighs. You spend a few moments considering how to actually part that painting from the man's cold dead hands, but decide against it.
"I'll think of something, eventually."
Before she can put herself back in harm's way, the door shuts with a bang.
After a few minutes of stop-and-start conversation, the two of you part ways. You head home, defeated.
"I'm fine," She manages to give you a genuine smile as she rubs her foot. "This isn't even the first time this has happened today."
"What was this about?" She asks, trying to massage some life back into her injured foot. "That's really what you care about?"
"No, it's fine." She says rubbing her injured foot.
(You have gained some favor with Elisabeth)
"Years and years ago, when I was getting started as an artist, I was caught painting portraits without a license."

While exploring the streets of Paris, you find yourself on a calmer street than most. The cacophony of the city fades away, and things are quiet, other than for the sound of a few pigeons feasting upon some grain that's been carelessly spilled in the road.
Just as you are about to turn around to find something more stimulating, you spot a familiar face.
"Magnifique!" She says, clapping her hands together. "Let's go!"

"Hmm, that could work..." she mumbles, more to herself than anyone else. 

"Let's go."
She looks down at her bag, and shifts awkwardly. "I have plenty of willing subjects, and even commissions to complete, but none of it thrills me. None of it inspires me."
You stop in at a nearby tavern and take a seat. It's the middle of the day, but the crowd is closely packed.

"I see what you mean, it is beautiful. Normally I focus on a single subject, but I haven't drawn a crowd in a very long time." She sits at the fountain's edge and starts to unpack her supplies. 

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)

After some time, Elisabeth's feverish drawing begins to subside. What started as a storm of lines and sketching winds down to a few careful marks as she works to get everything just so. Eventually she stops altogether and lays the sketchbook on her lap.

Her hand finds yours, and you both sit there for a while, and just watch the world go by together.

You squeeze her hand back, savoring your closeness together.

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
She notices your change in expression. "He... doesn't know, and I don't think he needs to."

You stay and chat a little while longer, commenting on passing strangers, and trying to determine who would be more interesting to draw. Your mind often wanders back to what any of these people would say if they knew what the two of you were doing together, just paces from them.

She slowly draws her hand away from yours, making a point to tap her wedding ring against your own engagement ring.

"Is it really that bad? There are a million kinds of love, but we only have one life. Does it feel right to spend it with only one person?"
You pause to watch them, and wonder what it must be like to be content with something as simple as a handful of seeds. Is it a better life?

Her voice is quiet, barely louder than a whisper. "I don't think I'm out of my slump just yet, but this is the closest I've felt in a long time."

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
She walks away briskly, leaving you in the square. After a few minutes, you decide to head home, still trying to make sense of what just happened.

Elisabeth stands up and gathers her things, hastily scribbling a note in her sketchbook. She tears out the paper and hands it to you. It's an address. 

"Write me a letter if you change your mind."

(Rendezvous with Elisabeth are now available)

As the sun starts to dip in the sky, Elisabeth stands up and gathers her things. She stops to scribble a note in her sketchbook, then tears out the paper and hands it to you. It's an address. 

"Can you write me a letter, when you want to see me again?"

(Rendezvous with Elisabeth are now available)

With that, she walks away, stopping only to glance back one last time before she leaves you in the square. 

After a few minutes, you decide to head home, your mind still swimming with emotion.
"I can't even remember the last time I was excited by my own work."
"What cheap romance did you pull that line from?"
"I'm out her to find something interesting to draw. Any ideas?"
She squeezes your hand, slowly, tenderly.

Not knowing what else to do, you look around the square to find some kind of distraction. Your wandering eyes catch a flash of sunlight glinting off of metal, and that's when you look down and notice it for the first time.

Elisabeth's wedding ring.
Then again, you've never seen a pigeon that still had all of its toes, so it can't be all that nice.

However, none of these strangers notice. Without realizing it, they treat you and Elisabeth like any other pair of people in the world, and it's freeing. 

Like you've been holding your breath your entire life, and are finally able to exhale.

The two of you walk over to the fountain where you met Pierre, not that long ago. It's still as beautiful as you remembered it to be. The square has plenty of people in it, but it's not uncomfortably packed.

Elisabeth seem happy with it.

She starts drawing, faster than you've ever seen anyone draw before. There's no hesitation in her movements, instead she sketches with the confidence that can only come from decades of practice.

"Oh, that is good." She mumbles under her breath.
"I've spent so much time worrying about people, but if I just draw their reflections in the water... all I have to do is focus on the shapes."

"Hmm, perhaps I can work with this." She says as she starts to unpack her supplies. 

Glancing with some uncertainty about the tavern she starts drawing, faster than you've ever seen anyone draw before. There's no hesitation in her movements, instead she sketches with the confidence that can only come from decades of practice.

“Oh, luring travelers into my cottage, bewitching them, devouring their hearts, the usual…”

“Nope. I’d definitely eat you.”

“I’d love to.”
“Actually, I’d prefer to sit somewhere here with you.”
