February 2nd, 1789 You take a seat at your usual spot in ‘Le Cygne’, a small tavern in your hometown. The hood of your cloak is still up, but it’s less to do with the snow outside and more to do with the fact that you don’t want to talk to anyone else here.
After a few minutes of trying to read your book, but failing to really get into it, you hear a set of footsteps approaching your table.

Armand gives an audible sigh of relief, while he usually cares about keeping his appointments, he rarely let’s something like this get to him. “I’m sorry, it’s just… the general assembly is so important, but so are you. I’m packing and writing letters night and day in order to get ready, but all the time I spend on that is time I’m not spending with you.”
“I knew it...” Armand sighs, defeated.

He pauses, and takes a deep breath. “Enough of that! If I want to feel sorry for myself, I can do it on the carriage to Paris. Tonight is for making sweet memories.”

He waves to barmaid, who brings you a bottle of wine and some glasses, along with a loaf of freshly baked bread that’s still steaming when it touches the table.

Suddenly he begins to perk up, and leans in close to whisper. “You’ll finally leave this place behind, living as a lonely hermit, far from the prying eyes of civilization. At night, children will whisper of the beautiful, wicked woman living in the forest, who reviles all of society.”
“How will you pass your time alone in the woods?”

Armand is more animate now, his words coming out faster and faster “In that case, I shall have no choice but to disguise myself as a huntsman, lost in the forest, and happening upon your grand salon by chance. You might be intrigued by this curious outsider in your midst. This would lead us to talking amongst the birds, the deer, and your other refined guests about the natural order, and the beauties of the wilds.”

Armand leans in, his eyebrow raised conspiratorially, “Ah, but your evil ways would not go unnoticed for long. The whole town would live in fear of you, and as the heir to this Barony I would have no choice but stop you myself. I would disguise myself as a huntsman, lost in the forest and pretend to be blissfully unaware of your wicked predations. While I would be unable to resist your charms, I feel that… you might feel the same way about me.”
“Obviously, I would be unable to resist your charms. Perhaps… you would feel same?”
“What say you, wicked woman of the woods? Would you be swayed by this huntsman’s charms?”
“Ah, the kindling embers of true love would be reignited into a roaring flame. I would cast off my disguise, and you would completely forgive me for being late.”
“Bonjour Yvette, I hope you weren’t waiting too long.”
Armand sighs, “Oh, a tragic ending for our hero. If only he had never been late to see his captivating fiance, this never would have happened.”
He waves to barmaid, who brings you a bottle of wine and some glasses, along with a loaf of freshly baked bread that’s still steaming when it touches the table. Armand fills your glass first.
He then fills his own, then raises his glass for a toast. “To happy endings, may our lives turn out as well as they do in the stories.”
He waves to barmaid, who brings you a bottle of wine and some glasses, along with a loaf of freshly baked bread that’s still steaming when it touches the table. Armand fills your glass first.
He then fills his own, then raises his glass for a toast. “To the loss of our hero, destroyed by that which he loved the most.”

Outside the night air is brisk, even the colors of the moonlit sky are cold. It’s a stark contrast from the fireside warmth of the tavern. Yet, despite the open air, it feels more intimate and personal than the small tavern you’ve left behind.
“While I like Le Cygne as much as the next man, I’d prefer to end our night with something that’s just about us.” Armand says in a soft, low voice.
He turns and holds out his elbow for you to grab onto, “Care for a walk?”
You step in close to him, wrapping your arm around his, before you both wander off into the moonlit night.

Armand smiles, “Very well, Madame!”. 

There’s not much in the way of benches outside the tavern, but he finds a stone mounting block a short distance from the tavern.

“Excellent! This is our last night together for a while, so I want to make sure that it’s a memory we’ll treasure.”

He waves to barmaid, who brings you a bottle of wine and some glasses, along with a loaf of freshly baked bread that’s still steaming when it touches the table.
You walk along the edge of a lake, the only sound being the chirping of the crickets, the sounds of your footfalls, and the steady rhythm of each other’s breath.

Your head leans on his shoulder. His body feels both warm and familiar.

The moon is full, the town distant, and it feels like you’re the only two people in the entire world.
Without a word, Armand leans in towards you, his eyes closed.
Your lips meet his and a joyful shiver runs through your body. His hand comes up to stroke the side of your face as his other arm hugs you close.

You gently pull away and place a finger on his lips. He opens his eyes and blushes.

“Of course, we could keep enjoying the view, for a little while longer...”

He uses his sleeve to sweep the snow off the wide piece of stone, then gestures out towards the lake your town is built on the edge of.

“Our new bench may not be the most prestigious real estate, but the view is quite nice, and the company’s the best in the world.”

You sit on your newfound bench with Armand, your bodies close together for warmth. Side by side, you stare out at the lake. Its water is so still that it almost seems like a mirror, the luminous reflection of the full moon is only lightly obscured the by occasional passing motes of fog dancing across the lake’s surface.
“Yvette, I-” Armand starts, but stops. His talent for words seems to have failed him. Instead, he leans in towards you, his eyes closed.
You’re not sure how long your kiss lasts, time seems to have lost some of its importance.

You pull away from each other, and you stare into his eyes. His face is a mixture of excitement and surprise. He whispers to you “I hope every kiss we have is as good as that one.” 

Armand breathes deep, preparing himself for his next words.
“Je suis désolé mon cher, it’s taken so much longer to get my affairs in order than I thought. Now I’m already spoiling our last night.”

It’s then that a man stumbles out of the darkness towards you, glancing about himself, and trying to catch his breath. 

“Armand, I’ve been looking everywhere for you!” he whisper hoarsely.
Your town is relatively small, and yet you still don’t recognize this man.

Eyes widening for a moment, this man seems to notice you for the first time. 

“I... am Isaac, a good friend of Monsieur Armand,” he states, slowly and carefully. “I was afraid he’d already left for the general assembly.”
Isaac places a small leather case in Armand’s hands. “I just wanted to make sure that he didn’t forget these documents. It’s quite fortunate that I found him in time.”
“Isaac… what a surprise,” Armand starts, his voice flat and tense.

He pulls you closer and stares out at the lake. “I know I’m doing the right thing for France by going, but I’m going to miss moments like this,” he sighs.

Armand breathes deep, preparing himself for his next words.
“And who might you be, madame?”
Isaac winces as if he’d been cut. “I’m so sorry madame, that was very rude of me. It’s a pleasure to finally make your acquaintance.”

Isaac regards you warily as he continues. “Armand, I’ll keep this short. We all knew tensions were going to keep rising after the riots in Grenoble, but it’s happening faster than any of us would have ever imagined.”
Isaac looks back and forth between the two of you and gives a quick, formal bow. “You two are obviously in the middle of something important. Please excuse my intrusion. Bonne nuit.”
Armand fills your glass first. “My father’s been talking my ear off about this particular vintage. I hope it’s up to your standards.”
With that, Isaac leaves. You and Armand stare at each other, silently, for over a minute.

Armand exhales and smiles, but there’s still an air of tension about him.

“Not right now, no. It’s all… very vague at the moment. There’s so much going on that I don’t want to give you something new to worry about.”
“That… was Isaac,” Armand says evenly. “I’ve been corresponding with him and some of his associates about politics for a few months now.
“We share a lot of ideas in common.”

“The general assembly might be the last chance to keep this country on the proper course, which means we can take absolutely no chances.” Isaac glances significantly to the package now in Armand’s hands.

Your fiance is trying to look positive, but his expression falters slightly in the face of Isaac’s grave expression and warning.
Isaac looks back and forth between the two of you and gives a slow, formal bow. “Please excuse my intrusion. Bonne nuit.”

“Armand, things are changing faster than we could have imagined,” the man called Isaac says, hurriedly pressing a small satchel into Armand’s hands. In the dim light you manage to notice the a few papers sticking out of the top of the bag. “We all knew tensions were going to keep rising after Bishop Bonteville killed himself, but this-”
“Isaac…” Armand presses at a louder volume, glancing towards you.

“Armand, I know this is hard, but France itself is at stake here.” Isaac continues, oblivious to your presence. “We helped guarantee your election for our Bailliage, so you could do this for us. You said it yourself ‘We must-”
“Isaac!” Armand barks sharply and suddenly. Even the crickets and the birds seem to go silent.
He then fills his own, then raises his glass for a toast. “To France, to the general assembly, but most importantly, to us!”

Breathing deeply, Armand recomposes himself, and gestures in your direction.

“Isaac, have you met my fiance Yvette Decaux? We were just enjoying our last night together before I left to prepare for the general assembly.”

Isaac’s eyes widen and he seemingly notices you for the first time. “Oh… hello Madame. I was just giving your fiance some important files that he forgot at home. Please excuse my intrusion. Bonne nuit.”

“Ideas about modernity, monarchy, and what makes France different from the rest of the world.” Armand says, almost automatically, before looking away from you and blushing for a moment. His breath mists in the air, as he stares out across the still waters of the lake.
Armand looks away, staring out across the lake. “It’s something… something that I cannot tell you about. Not yet.”
“Still, thank you. It makes me glad to know I still have you on my side.”
“I promise that I’ll explain all of this when it’s over.”

“I know that isn’t the whole answer, or what you want to hear. However, I need you to trust me Yvette, please.”

His voice is serious. Grave. Pained.
“France is changing, that cannot be stopped. It’s up to us to make sure that it changes for the better.”
The red wine is deep and full bodied, it smells of leather, blackberries and cloves. It’s some of the best you’ve had, and you can tell that Armand is enjoying it as well.

You spend an hour finishing the bottle together, pausing occasionally to nibble at the bread. All the while, you trade jokes, news from around the village, and simply try to forget that this is the last you’ll see of each other for months.

With the wine finished, Armand pauses to place the bottle on its side, a curious habit he picked up from his father. He then takes a deep breath, and waits a moment before saying “The snow appears to have stopped. Would you… would you like to join me outside? I have something I want to show you.”
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Balance of Po: Balance of Power
"Monsieurs, surely it's possible for you to take this villain in together, non?"
"The Guet Royal are the best choice for this. After all, keeping the law is their job."
"The Dragoon captured the villain. Should he not get the glory?"
You spend the day aimlessly wandering the streets and trying to clear your head. You've had a lot to think about lately, and it's becomin hard to keep it all straight.

You feel a tension in your breast as you see yet another patrol of archers go by. You've not done anything particularly wrong today, but something about their presence puts you on edge, like you've commited a terrible crime, completely forgotten about it, and now stand on the brink of being discovered.
"Since when do I have to listen to the likes of you?" The dragoon replies. "I found this man cutting purses, I apprehended him, and I shall deliver him to the prisons myself."
The fact that a soldiers performing an arrest probably makes the Guet Royal look terrible is also playing into this somehow.
You notice the men shift their feet, and their hands start to tighten about the grips of their weapons. This could get ugly.
They both break away from their argument to eye you, then examine each other.
"Well, I'm glad someone here is seeing sense!" The archer exclaims, as the crowd starts to grumble in agreement with you.
"Exactly? Is that not the proper order of things?" The young dragoon asks aloud, and the crowd starts to grumble in agreement with him.
"I suppose that could be possible, if you were amenable to such an arrangement..." The dragoon ventures.
"Don't tell us what to do!" They yell, almost in unison.

Like most citizens, you're main interest in the archers is making sure that they ignore you. However, up ahead you see that someone else has chosen a different approach. Two uniformed and armed men stand over a battered fellow who's sitting on the ground between them.

With that, the dragoon mounts his horse and storms off, fuming at this public display of disrespect.
"Thank you again madame for your civic mindedness." The archer says to you with a tiny bow and a self-satisfied grin.
He then marches away, dragging the hapless thief behind him. Standing alone in the street, you're left wondering what happens in a city where even those tasked with keeping order can't work together.

You however, are left in the street, wondering what happens in a city where even those tasked with keeping order can't work together.

As you wander home, you're left to wonder what happens in a city where even those tasked with keeping order can't work together.
The man arguing with the archer is a young soldier. Juding by his uniform, he appears to be a member of the Queen's Royal Dragoons.
"I said stand down!" The watchman growls, taking a single step towards his opponent.

The thief in question is sitting on the ground between them. His clothes are rumpled and a strike to the face has split his lips open, but he looks rather resigned to his fate.

At least, as long as two heavily armed men are standing directly over him.

Their argument continues apace, and you're starting to see the problem. Soldiers and the city watch aren't part of the same organization, and there's no real guide as to who is supposed to be obeying who here. In a time of heightened security, this line gets even blurrier.

Years ago, your father’s eyes started to have trouble focusing on small letters, so you had to help him with the accounting. Now it appears that all those late nights spent in his office, squinting at barely legible expenses, are about to pay off.

Flipping through the pages, you eventually find some entries for Marcelle’s account. She certainly appears to have the fortune one would imagine from a woman of her station, but still you press on. 

From the looks of it, the rumors that Marcelle spent a fortune on her father’s funeral were well founded. It must have been a truly lavish affair.

Not long after that, you get to when Marcelle’s father, Alfonso du Foix was the account holder. It appears that he was the one who made the family’s money, not Marcelle. 

While that would make for a good jab at a party, it’s not enough. A member of the aristocracy having a fortune they didn’t earn is more normal than not.
“Bonjour madame, and welcome to Caisse de Confiance: A name in banking!”
You’re looking deep into the past now, at entries that are over thirty years old. Suddenly, everything just stops making sense…

Marcelle's father was landless, dead broke, under a mountain of debt, and had been for years. He only got by on loans from someone named Gatien de Vassor, who was also a client at this bank. Then, overnight, the Viscount had a respectable sum of money, and everything just started working for him.
In thirty years, the Viscount made no attempt to pay back his loans to de Vassor. In fact, the first thing he bought with his newfound money was…
'November 12th, 1768 - Reinterment Expenses, Cimetière du Calvaire. '

It looks like he had a lot less respect for the dead than Marcelle. You can’t imagine burying a dog for as little money as Marcelle’s father spent to lay whoever this was to rest. Why bother moving someone to a different cemetery, if you’re going to do it so cheaply?

You write down the name of the cemetery, just in case it’s useful.

Besides, what kind of thief would pay to bury their victim?

You look through the ledgers a little further, but can’t seem to find anything else that’s useful. All you have is that Marcelle’s family used to be destitute, but they had a sudden windfall. Well, that and the name of a cemetery with a pauper’s grave.

The Bastille, a looming castle that was once the most infamous prison in all of Paris. Though it barely fills its role as a prison anymore, many still consider it a symbol of tyranny. Of repression.

Today, a mob of over a thousand commoners, armed with pikes, kitchen implements, and stolen rifles, attempted to storm the fortress. The Bastille contains hundreds of rifles, dozens of cannons, and ammunition for all of them. It's also extremely undermanned.
And so, in Paris, life is changed forever.
At their commander's word, the five thousand troops form up and begin a swift march across the Pont Sully. They are grim, and determined to restore order at any cost.

Seeing this enormous force crossing the bridge, many of the attacking militia scatter, and those who don't are quickly trapped in the square surrounding the fortress. The relief force strikes like a hammer, shattering the nascent citizen army against the looming walls of the Bastille.

By the end of the day, bodies litter the streets, and the revolutionaries have gained hundreds of martyrs to their cause. They have lost the first great battle, but it's too late for them to turn back now.

(The Crown has gained a staggering amount of power)
(The Revolution has lost a staggering amount of power)

Camped on the Champ de Mars, on the other side of the river Seine, are five thousand troops in service to the Crown, armed and ready for battle. Barely a mile away, if they decide to cross the river to relieve the defenders of the Bastille, nothing would be able to stop them.
And that's exactly what they do.

However, that's not as easy a decision as it seems. The Bastille isn't just being assaulted by a peasant mob. They've been joined by an entire unit of French Guard deserters, armed with rifles, cannons, and tactical expertise.

On the Champ de Mars, the commander of the relief force looks out at his own men, and wonders how many of them are sympathetic to the revolutionary cause. If he brought his troops to the Bastille, how many of them would be willing to fire on French citizens? Would he be defending the Bastille, or just adding to the numbers of the attackers?
This question paralyzes him... and he does nothing.
By the end of the day, the Bastille has been overwhelmed, and the Bourgeois Militia has more than enough weapons to arm itself
The guards number barely more than a hundred.

(The Revolution has gained a staggering amount of power)
(The Crown has lost a staggering amount of power)

You sit down just as mass is about to begin. While you were raised Catholic, you found yourself to be a touch less zealous than most. In fact, you realize that this is the first time you've even attended a church since arriving in Paris.

Ludovico presides over everything from his lectern, speaking latin as if it was his native tongue.

At one point, a procession brings forth a reliquary containing the forearm bone of a martyred saint. You look at the people around you, and they seem transfixed by it. It's amazing to think that such a thing could still carry so much meaning for so many people. 

Did that saint ever imagine that this would happen? That they would affect so many, long after their death?
"Deo gratias," The crowd replies reflexively, yourself included.

You finally reach the front of the line, and see Ludovico there, looking every part the humble priest, his thumb annointed with holy water.

"Approach, Madame Decaux."

While none of the other parisioners dare speak a word about it, you hear a collective intake of breath. Wind tensely whistling between their teeth.

(You have gained a little peril)
It's all an absurd performance, for the sake of gossipping parisioners who will carry your imagined circumstances far and wide. Yet, you can't help but appreciate the thought he's put into this.
Still, as the service progresses, you find yourself participating as if you'd never stopped. You know when to stand up, when to sit down, when to sing, and when to be silent.

With a polite nod you take your leave before anyone becomes suspicious. 

Well, even more suspicious, really.
It's a beauitful building, meaning that it was built when this neighborhood was still prosperous.
Slinking by the parisioners still exchanging pleasantries outside, you enter the church and make your way to an unoccupied chair, far from everyone else.
It's a good sermon, though he tends to stammer when he makes eye contact with you.
"Benedicamus Domino" Ludovico intones to the crowd, signalling the end of the service.
While most get up to leave, getting ready to go about their work day, you stand as the last in line, behind some of the other parisioners to be blessed.

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Bread and Bri: It's no small secret that the hunger of the countryside has reached Paris.
The King, in an attempt to provide some relief to the citizens of the city, ordered the Pont Neuf closed down and a place to distribute bread set up as a public relief effort.
The bridge was, of course, immediately flooded with people.
The bridge was, of course, immediately flooded with people.
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

These bread wagons only had enough food for a few days, but the gesture was still well received. While it certainly wasn't a long term solution, it showed the people that the Crown cared enough to act on behalf of its neediest citizens.

The bread wagons ran out of bread on the first day, and the lines were plagued with frauds trying to cheat the relief workers into giving them multiple loaves. Enraged, the crowds quickly overwhelmed the meager guards set up to keep order, and threw the empty bread carts into the river. Many went to sleep with bellies empty of food, but hearts stuffed with resentment.

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Clandestine I: Waking up with a yawn, you notice that Camille seems to have left a letter on your night stand.

Chère Yvette, If I know you as well as I think I do, you've already figured out who wrote this. While I cannot risk too many specifics, it appears that I'll be alone in my chambers for the foreseeable future, as all my fellow occupants will be absent due to a commitment in the countryside.'
'You've been so generous with your time these last few weeks, that I would like to repay you with some proper hospitality. Mes salutations respectueuses, An Anonymous Lover'

Reaching the end, you put down the letter, and consider this unexpected opportunity. You pick up and flip through the meticulous notes in your journal, and quickly deduce his home address. In fact, you could visit him at any time.

It's late at night, and you find yourself walking towards the rectory where Ludovico is staying. He's invited you for some simple hospitality, but you already get the feeling the night might involve a little more than that.
Carefully, you try the handle of the door and find it unlocked.
"Oh! What a lovely surprise." He says, resting his head upon your arm as he slowly returns to calm. "It's great to see you." He says with a wide grin.
Inside the close confines of the wardrobe, the sound of your heavy breathing is all you can hear. Carefully, slowly, you try to slow your beating heart and quiet your gasps.
The door opens, and through the slit in the door, you can watch an older man in a cassock walk in with Ludovico.
"Ah yes, that..." Ludovico replies. "I suppose that the grappa helps pass the time alone, and the second glass... well it felt improper to toast alone."
"Ha ha, a fine jest! It didn't realize you were so funny Ludovico."
"But, as I said earlier, I really must be off. Enjoy yourself and try not partake too much. Too many spirits are rarely good for the spirit."

The Bishop's footsteps recede out of the room, and eventually you hear the crack of a whip and the sound of his carriage departing into the night.

The silence afterwards is long and tense
"Well, that could have gone a lot worse than it did." Ludovico announces to the room at large, before mumbling a prayer of thanks.  "Now, where did you manage to hide?"
You announce yourself and step out of the wardrobe, making your exit look as elegant as possible, despite the situation.
Caught up in the moment, you decide to have some fun with Ludovico and stay hidden in the wardrobe.
"It's great to see you."
"Ah, there you are! I don't know about you, but I don't think my heart has managed to slow down at all."
"How are you feeling? Are you alright?"
I have to admit, it certainly added an element of drama to the proceedings.
"Ah, yes. It did spoil the mood somewhat..."
You manage to have half a drink and settle back into your chairs, and your conversation restarts, but slowly.
After about an hour, you realize how drained all of that sneaking around has left you, and get ready to leave.
"Buona notte, Yvette, and sorry again for all of the... danger."
Later, after some protracted goodbyes, you find yourself outside. You look up at Ludovico's window, and see that it's gone dark.
Walking home, you mull over the evening's hospitality, and your proximity to disaster.
You smile and stroll home with an easy step. Everything in life is a mixture of its ups and downs. Fortune is but a wheel, and those on the bottom may find themselves on the top in half a spin.
Standing up, he gently takes you by the hand and leads you to another chair near his desk. You take a seat.
With a sigh, you walk home in the dark, eyeing each shadow with guarded suspicion.
Carefully stalking up the stairs, you find Ludovico's room, where the door has been left ajar. He's bent over a desk, illuminated by the light of a few candles.

"It's grappa from my family's vineyard." He says proudly, uncorking it with a pop. "Wine is more popular these days, but my parents still cling fast to their traditions."
Getting down on your hands and knees, you prepare to hide under the bed in the corner.
However, upon closer inspection you realize that the bed is too low to the ground for you fit underneath it.
The footsteps are getting louder, and you can hear them right outside the door.
"Please, don't worry yourself." Ludovico replies with a forced cheeriness. "I was merely spending my time here, alone. To be truly honest, it's been nice to have this time of peace."
"Ah yes, time spent in solitude and contemplation is good for the soul. It helps one realize the folly of worldly desires."
"It certainly does that," Ludovico agrees. You can hear him rummaging through his desk.
"I believe this is what you're looking for." Ludovico pronounces proudly, presumably as he produces something suitably impressive looking from his desk.
"Ah, magnifique!" the Bishop replies with a tone of releif. "Thank you again, Ludovico. Much as I would like to stay, I must leave immediately."
The sound of your sigh of relief is thankfully muffled by the clothes you're hiding behind.

"But oh ho! What is this I spy?" The Bishop suddenly asks with a disapproving chuckle.

Your heart stops in your chest.
He pours the clear liquid into two small glasses, and you can already smell its potency.

"Oh... w-what is what?" Ludovico asks, poorly concealing the dread in his voice. 

You try to sink further back into the wardrobe, but your shoulderblades are already rubbing against the back wall.
"I see you've been deep in your cups, and some strong stuff by the smell of it..."
"Ah yes, that..." Ludovico replies. "I brought the grappa from Rome. I suppose it helps me pass the time alone."
"Would you mind if I partook of a little myself?" The Bishop asks with a quiet mischeif. "The journey back is going to be most tiresome."
"Oh, of course your excellency!" Ludovico replies. You can hear him pour out two small glasses of the potent liquor. "What shall we toast to?"
"If something so lovely is already passing into lips, let us choose something suitably noble to pass from them. Let us drink to fealty and truth!" The bishop proclaims with no shortage of vigor.
"Ah, yes. To fealty and truth." Ludovico replies weakly.
The two clink glases and drain them. You can hear the bishop cough and sputter from the strength of the grappa.
"Yvette, are you here? Am I... supposed to find you?" He asks, trying to remain serious but you can hear him supress a giggle.

Excitedly, you hold the glass up to your nose and smell the drink, which has a scent of aged perfume. You take your first sip, and the taste is strong like brandy, but sweet like a sour plum dipped in honey.

You have tell Ludovico is happy that you're so enthusiastic about it.
He hunts around the room, looking under the bed, and even checking to see if the window's been opened. You titter to yourself, knowingly.
Eventually, he notices the wardrobe and starts to creep over to it. He slow, stalking steps are both awkward and adorable.
His hand grasps onto the latch of the wardrobe door.
A devilish smile blossoming across you lips, you throw the door open and grab Ludovico by the wrsits before pulling him into the wardrobe with you. The doors swing shut behind him.
"I... think I found you."
You give him no reply, instead there's only the sound of your breathing in the close, intimate confines of your hiding place.
Your lips meet in the dark, and you can feel his entire body tense up, before that tension slowly melts away.

Your hands wander over each other's bodies, and you can feel Ludovico slowly grow bolder with his touch.

Quite bold indeed.
You have to admit, he's very fun to toy with.

Later on, your find yourself outside and getting ready to head home. You look up at his apartment window and spot Ludovico waving to you.

You wave back, because as devilish as you are, you're not a monster.
"Ah yes, well it is a bit of an acquired taste for those that didn't grow up around it."
Tonight ended much more intensely than you had anticipated.

You walk home with an exagerated elegance in your stride as you lose yourself in a fancy. In it you are bold, dangerous, perhaps the greatest temptress of all time.

The night lanterns seem brighter than ever, and you wonder if it's a mere fancy, after all.
You walk home, careful and contemplative. You don't feel afraid, but you have a certain clarity of mind that makes considering your options feel easier than ever.
He stares at the ground awkwardly.
"Yvette, could you- I mean would you like to-"
Ludovico tenses up the moment your lips meet, but slowly his tension melts away. He places a hand in the middle of your back and brings you closer.
"Ah yes, that does sound reasonable." He says with an embarassed smile. "We've had enough close calls tonight as is."
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
You chat together for another hour or so, but you quickly realize how drained all of that sneaking about has left you, and get ready to leave.
(You have gained a good amount of favor with Ludovico)
He flushes a deep red. "No- I mean, it is quite strong, but that wasn't my intent. I just thought you'd like it."
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Ludovico, if that wasn't already obvious)
You have to admit, he's very fun to toy with.
"Puttana means, 'whore'." He says, trying to keep his laughter under control. "And 'figlio de puttana' means 'son of a whore'. It's a very useful word, you see."
"Oh..." Ludovico flushes red as your question really dawns on him.
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
He clears his throat. "Uhm, if you really wanted to say that, all you'd have to say is-"
"However, I would also say that the pleasure has been all mine."
"It's a bit rude, but it feels good for you. You always seem to be in the right place at the right time."
"But if you must know, you would say Ludovico è molto intelligente."
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
Your heart quickening with excitement, you step inside.
(You have gained some favor with Ludovico)
Some minutes pass as you sip leisurely on your respective drinks, before Ludovico says "There something else I was hoping to do tonight. I hope you don't think it's too foolish."
"Would you prefer wine or tea, perhaps?"
"Wine? Of course!"
"Don't worry, I have some tea right here!"
He pours some tea into your glass from the pot sitting on his desk. The warmth of the glass feels nice against your hand.

He rummages around again in the bottom drawer of his desk and produces a bottle of wine before pouring some into your tiny glass.

This should be easier to consume in moderation.

Content to torment Ludovico just a little, you smile devilishly and take your first sip of the grappa. It's strong like brandy, but sweet like a sour plum dipped in honey.

The taste lingers for a long while on your tongue.
"In our brief time together, you've already taught me so much. I was hoping to teach you something in return."
"Specifically, I thought it would be fun to teach you some Italiano."
Your heart quickening with trepidation, you step inside.
"Now, what would you like to learn?"
"Something funny? Hm... what do I have for this?"
He flushes bright red. "I was hoping you'd say that."
"Really? That's what you want to learn?" Ludovico laughs in surprise. "Alright, let me think of something."
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
(You have gained some favor with Ludovico)
"If someone is being really embarassing, you can always tell them Faccia di culo!, which means 'Your face looks like your bottom!'."
"I've always loved that one."
"Ti amo is how you say 'I love you'." He chuckles and looks into his glass. "It's only a few letters, but they're so hard to say."

You spend the next few minutes doing what everyone does when they learn something rude in an unfamiliar language, which is use this new phrase as much as humanly possible. You impugn the honor of the chirping birds outside, the glasses in your hand, and even the furniture.

After a few moments, your eyes adjust to the darkness. The hallways are only lit by a scant few rays of lights emanating from the light of the streetlamps peaking through the shuttered windows. The whole building is as silent as a monastery. This, you suppose, feels appropriate.
You laugh together, chat and eventually drain your drinks. He refills your glass as well as his own.
"You picked up on that quickly. What else can I teach you?"
"You flatter me too much."
"I would say grazie di cuore to thank someone and really mean it."
"Something you can use every day, huh?" He pauses to rub his chin in thought.
(You have gained some favor with Ludovico)
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
"If you want to says that someone's lucky, you can say Avere culo."
With fresh peals of laughter, you continue your merry making and drain your tiny glasses. This time, you refill each of your respective drinks.
"You have quite the ear for languages. I think I can teach you one last phrase. What would you like to know?"

Checking your location against the address you deduced from your notes earlier, you look up and see a building marked with the symbols and crests of the Church. Unlike the well lit buildings up and down the street, this one is dark, save for the window of a single room on the second floor.

You're almost certain that room is where Ludovico is.
"That's easy! You just say-"
"Oh really?" He ask with a giggle "Well, here's how you-"
"Oh, that's simple!" He smiles as he reaches for the bottles on his desk. "All you need to say is-"
You're both struck silent by a series of heady thuds, coming from downstairs.
"What was that?" Ludovico whispers. The only response he receives is another clatter of noise.
"Figlio di puttana, I don't think we're alone anymore." He hisses to you gravely.
He stands up slowly "I'll investigate, and perhaps I can stall them. You should hide."
Knowing you don't have much time, you search the room for an adequate place to hide.
Getting down on your hands and knees, you prepare to hide under the bed in the corner.
You examine the full sized wardrobe, noting that it seems the right size for you to hide in, and that it's sitting in a corner behind the door, making it hard to notice.
He scribbles diligently on a letter, and doesn't appear to have noticed you.

Below the window is a narrow strip that barely qualifies as a ledge. This looks extremely hazardous, but you don't really see any better options. Looking down at the cobblestones below, you silently thank the heavens that you don't suffer from vertigo.

Right as you open the window, you notice a carriage in the streets right outside. The carriage is dectorated with the livery of the Church, and the coachman is smoking a pipe, looking directly at the place where you would land if you lept from the window.

This won't work.
Settling on this plan of action, you step into the wardrobe and secret yourself behind the various clothes hanging inside.
However, upon closer inspection you realize that the bed is too low to the ground for you fit underneath it.
Cursing under your breath, you wrack your brain for a new plan, as you hear footsteps ascending the stairs.
(You have gained a little peril)
You search the room for an adequate place to hide.
Getting down on your hands and knees, you prepare to hide under the bed in the corner.
However, upon closer inspection you realize that the bed is too low to the ground for you fit underneath it.
The footsteps are getting louder, and you can hear them right outside the door.
Ludovico perks up in his chair and looks over at you, standing in the door way. "Ah, I'm glad to see you could make it."
(You have gained some peril)
Cursing under your breath, you wrack your brain for a new plan, as you hear footsteps ascending the stairs.
(You have gained a little peril)
You search the room for an adequate place to hide.

Below the window is a narrow strip that barely qualifies as a ledge. This looks extremely hazardous, but you don't really see any better options. Looking down at the cobblestones below, you silently thank the heavens that you don't suffer from vertigo.
Your heart hammering in your chest, you jump in the wardrobe at the absolute last minute.

Right as you open the window, you notice a carriage in the streets right outside. The carriage is dectorated with the livery of the Church, and the coachman is smoking a pipe, looking directly at the place where you would land if you lept from the window.

This won't work either.
The footsteps are getting louder, and you can hear them right outside the door.
(You have gained some peril)
Inside the close confines of the wardrobe, the sound of your heavy breathing is all you can hear. Carefully, slowly, you try to slow your beating heart and quiet your gasps.
He jumps slightly in his chair before he turns around to face you with a contented smile. "Why hello there, Yvette. I would love some company."
The door opens, and through the slit in the door, you can watch an older man in a cassock walk in with Ludovico.

"I'm dreadfully sorry for disturbing you," The older man says with that tone of voice which implies that his rank is so much greater than Ludovico's, that even the apology is a mere courtesy at best. "Once I realized I'd forgotten that treatise, I hurried back as soon as I could."
"Please, don't worry yourself." Ludovico replies with a forced cheeriness. "I was merely spending my time here, alone. To be truly honest, it's been nice to have this time of peace."
"Ah yes, time spent in solitude and contemplation is good for the soul. It helps one realize the folly of worldly desires."
"It certainly does that," Ludovico agrees. You can hear him rummaging through his desk. Ocassionally, you can hear your drinking glasses clinking together on the desk as it shifts back and forth.
"I believe this is what you're looking for." Ludovico pronounces proudly, presumably as he produces something suitably impressive looking from his desk.
"Ah, magnifique!" the Bishop replies with a tone of releif. "Thank you again, Ludovico. Much as I would like to stay, I must leave immediately."

"But oh ho! What is this I spy?" The Bishop suddenly asks with a disapproving chuckle.

Your heart stops in your chest.

"Oh... w-what is what?" Ludovico asks, poorly concealing the dread in his voice. 

You try to sink further back into the wardrobe, but your shoulderblades are already rubbing against the back wall.
"I see you've been deep in your cups, and some strong stuff by the smell of it..."

Near silently, you sneak up behind Ludovico and drape your arms around his shoulders. He yelps in surprise, and if it weren't for your weight ontop of him, you're certain he would have jumped out of his chair.
"In fact..." the Bishop continues, "You've been so enthusiastic that you seem to have been drinking with two glasses..."
(You have gained a significant amount of peril)
You hastily clean up the bottles, cups, and drinking glasses. Soon, you're satisfied that any evidence of your presence has been adequately concealed.
This does, however, cost you precious time. Downstairs you hear the front door open, and some voices conversing.
(You have gained a tiny amount of Peril)
Knowing you don't have much time, you search the room for an adequate place to hide.
Getting down on your hands and knees, you prepare to hide under the bed in the corner.
You examine the full sized wardrobe, noting that it seems the right size for you to hide in, and that it's sitting in a corner behind the door, making it hard to notice.

Below the window is a narrow strip that barely qualifies as a ledge. This looks extremely hazardous, but you don't really see any better options. Looking down at the cobblestones below, you silently thank the heavens that you don't suffer from vertigo.
Settling on this plan of action, you step into the wardrobe and secret yourself behind the various clothes hanging inside.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Coffee Run.as: "Please! Can anyone let us use your stove? She needs it for work!"
"I will pay ten livres to the first person that lets us borrow their stove for the day!"
<Give up>
"I'm sorry Marguerite, I can't think of anything else."
"Marguerite, over here! Why don't you use the stove at my home?"
"Please! Can anyone let us use your stove? She needs it for work!"
"I will pay ten livres to the first person that lets us borrow their stove for the day!"
Wandering around town, you realize that you're near Cafe Principe, but you can't smell the familiar scent of roasting coffee beans. Which is a quite a shame, because the scent is absolutely heavenly.

You are momentarily lost in a reverie imagining what life would be like if coffee tasted as good as it smelled. Would we ever drink anything else? 

It would be a jittery world, indeed.
Hearing your impassioned plea, someone in the crowd hurriedly escorts you into a tavern where they work. Immediately, Margueritte sets up her kettles on a roaring stove.

Your impassioned plea falls on deaf ears, as people in the crowd simply shuffle by. Admittedly, it is an odd situation, but you still curse the strangers for their inaction. It doesn't take long for you to notice that some of the people nearby have even grown suspicious of you.
(You have lost some credibility)
Perhaps there's something else that you can do...
Someone in the crowd hurriedly escorts you into a tavern where they work. Immediately, Margueritte sets up her kettles on a roaring stove.

You're not exactly sure how you get caught up in everything, but you're soon helping Marguerite ferry kettles of boiling water back and forth from the cafe for a few hours. It's exhausting, but you're met with a cheer from the patrons every time the two of you burst in the door with a new pair of kettles.
Someone jokingly calls you two 'The Angels of Steam'. The nickname sticks, at least for the day.
(You have gained a decent amount of credibility)

The café waitress shrugs. "Don't worry madame, I'll think of something." 

Her eyes don't portray the same optimism as her words.
"Thanks again for your help." Marguerite says to you for the umpteenth time as she passes you during one of your deliveries.
Behind you and to the right, you hear a commotion, you turn and spot a familiar face.
Eventually, the day winds down and you head home. You're tired, but glad that things managed to work out.
(You have spent 10 Livres)
Out of options, you part ways and head home. Things didn't work out today, but perhaps they'll go more smoothly tomorrow.

"Does anyone have a stove I can use? This is an emergency!" It's Margueritte, from the cafe! She's holding a bunch of kettles and looks absolutely frantic. 

Nobody is rushing to help, in fact they're trying to stay out of her way.

She's happy to hear this until you start giving her directions. Her face falls and replies. "Non madame, I'm sorry but that won't work. You live too far away. The water will be cold by the time I reach the café. It has to be somewhere nearby!"
Some members of the crowd turn to listen as you make an impassioned plea for this poor working woman beset by misfortune. She needs no money, no supplies, merely a stove with which to heat her water!
It's amazing how indecisive everyone in the crowd was, until money entered the equation.
"The stove in the café is broken and I have a lot of thirsty customers!"
All the same, she smiles warmly to you "Thank you for trying. That's already more than anyone else here has done."
(You have gained a little credibility)
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Commissioning: Commissioning Vengeance
“How does ‘use the art of painting to destroy a wicked man’ sound, for intriguing?”
“My friend and her young son would make a great subject, if you’re interested.”
“How does ‘use the art of painting to destroy a wicked man’ sound for a subject?”
“This painting is going to help my friend Marguerite get the justice she deserves.”
“The main goal of this painting is to destroy the wicked Baron Maximin de Termes.”
“Yes, your painting could help my friend Marguerite get justice.”
“Absolutely. I want you to paint a painting that will destroy Baron Maximin de Termes.”
“I’d like to commission you for a very special portrait.”
“What were you doing, just now?”
"I'd like to commission you for a very special portrait."
“What were you doing, just now?”
“I’m flattered, but I’m actually hoping you’ll paint my friend and her son.”
Finally, you manage to get a moment alone with Élisabeth.
She idly sips her wine and traces one of her fingers through the air, as if she was drawing something imaginary. She smiles, obviously pleased with whatever it is that she’s doing in her head.
“I’m actually looking for a new subject for my paintings, do you know any?”
“I could work with that, but what’s going to make this interesting?”
“Oh, you’re actually serious,” she realizes aloud.
“You mean actual, physical justice? From a painting?”
“THE Baron de Termes? Ugh…”
She starts sketching a little. “Every artist faces the same problem. You spend your whole life making beautiful things, but you’re never sure that anything you’re doing actually matters.”
“Lots of people like my paintings, even important people like the Queen. Still, I’m always wondering if I’m actually making the world a better place.”
“A more beautiful one? Definitely. A better one? I’m not sure.” Her sketching starts to speed up.
“This, on the other hand. This is exactly what I’ve been looking for!”
“A painting that actually solves a problem in someone’s life. Oh, this will be some of my best work...”
She turns to you, noticing that you’re still here. “Oh, it’s you again! Can I help you?”
“Sorry, I got carried away there. I will absolutely paint this. Where can I find my subjects, and what, exactly, does this painting need to convey to the viewer?”

You spend a few minutes telling Élisabeth about where to find Marguerite Bonnet, and what exactly the painting needs to display. 

You don’t know how you’ll use this painting yet, but it still means that you’re a step closer than you were before.
Your vengeance approaches.
“Ugh!”
“UGH!”
“Sorry, I just hate that man. Did you know that he called one of my self portraits ‘uninspired and selfish’?”

“It’s a self portrait! People have been painting them for… forever! It’s a classic display of an artist’s skills!” She takes a sip of wine and grumbles to herself. “Honestly, how come when men paint pictures of themselves they’re ‘engaging in a serious study’, but when I paint one, it’s suddenly all about my vanity?”
“Sorry, I got carried away there. I will absolutely paint this, if it means that I get to put that pretentious blowhard in his place. How do you want me to do this?”
She idly sips her wine and traces one of her fingers through the air, as if she was drawing something imaginary. She smiles, obviously pleased with whatever it is that she’s doing in her head.
After a while, she turns to you, noticing that you’re still here. “Oh! Can I help you?”
“A very special portrait?” she asks, her curiosity obviously piqued. “I’ll warn you now, I don’t paint nudes of my clients.”

“Sketching in my head. There’s a woman over there with some very interesting features.” She points across the room at the woman in question, obvious enough that anyone could notice, but nobody seems willing to make a fuss about it.
“Even though you’d make a very intriguing subject.”
She rubs her chin thoughtfully, then takes out an actual sketchbook and starts to flip through it, examining old ideas. “A mother with son?”
Élisabeth tilts back her head and laughs at your proposal. After a while, she pauses to reexamine your expression.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Comrades in D: Yesterday, a whole company of soldiers from the gardes francaise marched to the Palais-Royal to publicly announce that they would, under no circumstances, fire upon the people.

This noble declaration raised equal parts celebration and alarm from the common people. After all, they would only make such a statement is they'd been recently ordered to fire upon the people, but only just refused the order.
At the direct request of the Crown, the Military has imposed stern disciplinary measures, to quell further defiance. This is not something they can allow to get out of hand.

Later that day, a group of the soldiers from that very company approached the National Assembly to publicly denounce their own commanding officer, the Duc de Châtelet, as an enemy of the people. Afterwards, they were quickly apprehended by the soldiers still loyal to the Crown, and arrested.

News of this spread like wildfire, and soon a mob of angry citizens had gathered outside the prison where they were being held. This mob grew to be so large and enraged that the commander of the prison was forced to relent and release them, instead of risking a bloodbath. 

The soldiers spent only a day in prison, before they were released to riotous applause and celebration.

(The Military has lost a little power)
(The Military has moved towards the Revolution by a decent amount)
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

While there was public outrage at the imprisonment of these soldiers, the Crown has refused to yield. In fact, reinforcements were sent to the prison where the mutinous men were being held, and many protestors outisde the prison have found themselves arrested as well.

(The Crown has gained a little power)
(The Military has moved towards the Crown by a decent amount)

Later that day, a group of the soldiers from that very company approached the Estates General to publicly denounce their own commanding officer, the Duc de Châtelet as an enemy of the people. While their proclamations could be heard through the doors, they never got past the guards into the assembly room, and were arrested.

The wave of public sentiment reached such heights that the Duc d'Orleans even plans to throw the released soldiers a banquet to celebrate their heroism in the face of tyranny. Needless to say, this has made the Military establishment looks foolish indeed. It has also given many common soldiers cause to investigate their own loyalties. Who do they actually fight for?
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Courting Cont: "Was it amazing?"
"I know she loved your work. Is that why she pushed for your membership to L'Académie?"
"This isn't your fault. Those boors just couldn't tolerate a woman in their special club."
"This isn't your fault. Those guys hated on you because they didn't want a woman in their midst."
"Were you nervous?"
"This isn't your fault. Those guys hated on you because they didn't want a woman in their midst."
"The Queen never turned against you. Reach out to her again, as a friend."
"Maybe this is a sign you don't belong there. Have you considered talking to the nationalists?" <Credibility Check>
"Nothing for now Camille. Elisabeth, thank you, this was a great night."
"I'm sorry to cut this short, but I am exhausted. I must retire for the evening."
"You two seem to be getting along quite well. Should I be worried?"
"Don't be. I overstepped my bounds."
"Apology accepted."
"Apology accepted"
"Apology accepted"
"Elisabeth, you'll never heal this hurt with silence. Reach out to the Queen, as a friend."
"Have you considered reaching out to the nationalists? They might accept you." <Credibility Check>
"It's alright if you don't want to talk about it."
"What happened?"
"What happened?"
"What happened?"

After your day together, Elisabeth decides to walk you home. You sense that she feels much more comfortable with you now. 

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
The artist glances at you for a moment "Did I ever tell you what it was like to paint the Queen?"
"And they hated it."

"I was surrounded by all these men, these master artists, whose work I admired. I had to listen to them tear it to pieces. That my portrait was scandalous. That it was insulting. That it was unbecoming of the Queen."
A duo of tears roll down her cheeks. "But it wasn't. My infamy only brought me more clients, and the common people loved it. Marie was more damaged by the scandal than I was."

"Courtiers spent their lives scheming and lobbying to see Marie-Antoinette, Queen of France and mother of the nation. I got to know the real Marie, gentle and considerate. We would sing duets together after our painting sittings."
Elisabeth laughs "She could never stay on key, but that wasn't important."

"We became friends of a sort."

Elisabeth turns her eyes away from you and to the ground.
"Marie never questioned my motives. She didn't even think about it. She just did it. Suddenly, I was a member." Elisabeth says with a confused shrug.

"A few years later, I painted another painting of her, something with her children. I made what the academy wanted to see. More austere, more appropriate, something befitting the mother of the king's children. Since then, Marie and I have lost touch."
"I feel like I betrayed her."

"I had a good reputation, and I'd painted nobility before, even a few relatives of the Queen, but those were formal paintings. I would show up, chat with them a little, and try to capture the essence of someone I didn't even know. Marie was something else entirely."
"It was surreal."
"Instead I met Marie and her friends at Le Petit Trianon, and joined them in their leisure. I saw them as themselves, not as the masks they wore at court."

"By then Marie had been rejected enough times to be sick of politics and intriques. So, instead she spent her efforts making a simple world of leisure in that chateau. Like a little island isolated from the rest of France."
"My rival, Adélaïde Labille-Guiard, became a member that same year. No connections at court, no back room dealing. One of the only other women in that entire academy and she earned it."
"I wasn't good enough to do it on my own."

She sniffs and wipes the tears from her face.

"Maybe, you're right..."
[Credibility Check]

"That might work." Elisabeth says, hesitantly. "The revolutionaries would appreciate my more relaxed and natural aesthetic. In fact, many of them have already rejected L'Académie's views on art, so I wouldn't have to try pleasing people that already hate me."

Elisabeth stares at you, mouth agape. 

"Are you serious, Yvette? I've already hurt Marie, I'm not going to make things even worse."

"That's a great idea, Yvette! I'm going to reach out to some of them soon!"

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
[The Crown has lost a medium amount of power]
[The Revolution has gained a medium amount of power]

"If this is a joke, it's not a very tasteful one."

(You have lost quite a bit of favor with Elisabeth)
"Oui, L'Académie Royale de Peinture et de Sculpture... the most important art institution in France. I spent years trying to get in, but could never quite make it."
"It was L'Académie that hated my painting, not Marie. I put my heart into something for a friend, and she loved it. That's what matters."

"Thank you. I haven't been focusing on what's really important."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
[The Crown has gained a medium amount of power]
You arrive at home, and Camille greets you both with her usual cheer. "Bonsoir mesdames!"
"Just a maid of all works, madame! Can I get either of you anything?"

The rest of the walk home continues in an awkward silence.

After what feels like an eternity, you arrive home.
After a long pause at your front door she says "I'm sorry. I know you were just trying to help."

"It was." Replies Elisabeth. "Thank you again for your advice, and for taking the time to listen."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
With that, you stumble upstairs and prepare yourself for bed. It was a good night, and you feel like you've managed to push events in a very helpful direction.
Your question draws only silence.

"I think we both made some mistakes. Good night Yvette." She says, before giving you an awkward wave, and heading off into the night.

(You've gained some favor back with Elisabeth)

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Empty Bellies: The price of food has been steadily rising for the last few months, as many farmers lost nearly their entire harvests in last summer’s unseasonable hail storms. This was followed by a drought, and then by one of most brutal winters in nearly a century.
There are reports of starving people in the countryside boiling bark to make gruel. Desperate commoners are abandoning their homes, and fleeing to the cities for relief.

Members of the nobility, like the Duc d’Orléans, have raised money to feed the poor, but the problem is simply too vast for any individual act of charity to solve. Finance Minister Necker has spent over 50 million livres importing grain from the rest of Europe, but the famine persists.

Rumors circulate about wealthy aristocrats with secret stores of grain, purposefully extending the famine in order to lower wages and improve their political power. Workers are demanding higher wages from their Bourgeois employers, who remain intransigent.
They people are hungry, angry, and they want to do something about it. Soon.
The people are hungry, and angry.

It's not a long walk to the address that Armand provided in his letter, but you wait until nighttime before you head out. He said that these notable persons are in Paris attending the Estates General, which means that they'd only be free later in the day, when they were out of session.
When you find the address, you see that it's a tavern, but you see very little light coming from inside. The front door is shut, along with a sign on it that reads 'Closed for a private event'.
"Bonsoir, madame..." He says, shifting awkwardly from foot to foot.

"That's what worries me," Armand agrees. "She is absolutely smarter than that. She founded this whole society, recruited most of its members, and got it all to this point. Then again, intellect has a way of failing at the worst possible time."
"Is it odd to say that I'm not?"
"There's nothing that I find particularly unattractive about her, but the thought simply never crossed my mind." He says with a shrug.

He stands up and you fling yourself against him, as the two of you kiss for the first time in so long. Your eyes are closed, but you can feel his free hand feeling its way up your body, undoing the ribbons that hold your dress shut.
You run your hands up his chest as your bodice slides open, and you already feel his hands reaching for the laces of your corset.
As you takes your plate, he gives you a light kiss on the forehead, before departing for the kitchen.
(You have gained a little favor with Armand)

<Observe from afar>
