"So you're saying that you're unable to make it?"
<Observe from afar>
"Yes, let's bring in the archers, and we can tell them all about Cesar's history."
"If you do this, I guarantee that you'll find Madame Gazelle to be a model customer."
<Observe from afar>
<Observe from afar>
<Observe from afar>
<Observe from afar>
<Observe from afar>
<Observe from afar>
Out in the city, you find yourself wandering a street lined with businesses making and selling fine furntiure. The air smells of rich woods, sweet resins, and pungent varnishes.
Just looking at all the magnificent pieces on display is enough to make you wonder how much it would cost to replace the aging and splintering furnishings in your own home. Probably far too much.
Listening intently, you manage to hear her say "Fine, if that old fool can't help me, then I'll find someone who can..."
As she gets into her carriage and disappears, you can't help but wonder what just transpired in that store.
With a slightly increased knowledge of fine furniture, but no definite answers, you head home.
"What? Yes! This is Boulle's! We do custom work!" He replies both happily, and a little too loudly.

"Magnifique... I've been told that you specialize in craftsmanship and... discretion." Madame Gazel says as she leans in and unrolls a large piece of parchment in front of him. "What do you think it would cost to make something like this?"
Over the next half an hour, you actually manage to learn something about fine furniture. It might be helpful at the next party you go to.
(You have gained a little credibility)
Monsieur Boulle closely examines the paper, reorients it, then stares at it some more. His expression is grave.
(You have gained a little peril)
"Madame... what exactly have you brought into my fine shop?" He asks, his voice tight.
Madame Gazel doesn't seem to notice you as she enters the shop.
Madame Gazel is starting to look concerned. "Are you not Cesar Boulle?"
"More certainly not, madame! I am his brother, Francois Boulle! Cesar was kicked out of this shop last year for his vile and perverse creations..."
"Yvette? What are you doing here?" Madame Gazel asks, noticing you for the first time.
"Yvette? What are you doing here?" Madame Gazel asks, noticing you for the first time.
"Yvette? What are you doing here?" Madame Gazel asks, noticing you for the first time, as you slip a hefty bag of coins into Monsieur Boulle's pocket.
(You have spent 30 Livres)
"You wouldn't really do that... would you?" He affixes you with an appraising stare. Your expression is as firm as stone.

"That's utterly preposterous!" Monsieur Boulle snaps at you, slapping Madame Gazel's plans with the back of his hand. "It's a bizarre design to be sure, but there's nothing difficult about it. It's just peg and dowel construction with some fine upholstery on the..."
"Monsieur, I would expect nothing less from a man of your abilities." She smiles and slips him a business card. "Please send someone by when it's complete."
Before you can say anything else, Madame Gazel takes you by the hand and leads you outside.

You follow Honorade inside the shop, slipping in just before the door closes. Inside, you recognize the establishment as another workshop specializing in fine furniture. The floor is littered with woodchips, but the products themselves look maginificent.
"Yvette, I want to make it absolutely clear that I don't appreciate being followed." She growls at you.
"Oh no... I shall not be so easily manipulated." The man replies, folding his arms over his chest. "Both of you, get out of my shop!"

You look over his shoulder at the plans and immediately recognize Madame Gazel's handwriting. The drawing itself though... you don't recognize furniture like that at all. It's all hard angles, strangely placed padding, and steel rings.
"I should report you to the archers for bringing this obscenity into my fine shop!"
He pauses to reexamine the paper. "No, that's not right... if that was to be load bearing, it would have to..."
"Urgh! Fine!"
"Madame, I shall create this wicked thing for you, but merely as an exercise of my craft."
(You have gained a little credibility)
(You have lost some credibility)
Before you can say anything else, Madame Gazel takes you by the hand and leads you outside.
You wait outside for a while, wondering what to do next. Observing the shop from afar, you pretend to browse through the selections put on display by some of the neighboring merchants.

"While I appreciate your attempts to help, Yvette, I don't appreciate being followed." Madame Gazel affixes you with a steely glare. "Additionally, I do not like when others attempt to speak for me... especially if they fail."
(You have lost some favor with Madame Gazel)
Without another word, Madame Gazel walks away, leaving you to puzzle over what just happened. You decide to head home before things get any worse.

The man places a hand to this newfound bag of coins and doesn't even bother to open it, merely testing it by weight. "Your servant has made a fine argument, Madame Gazel. We would be willing to overlook certain... indiscretions in exchange for your business. I think you'll find our craftsmanship to be outstanding."
"Yet, I do find it hard to argue with the quality of your results."
(You have gained a decent amount of favor with Madame Gazel)
"Of course, I must ask you to forget what you saw." She continues with a breezy laugh. "After all, I'd hate to ruin any potential surprises."
Without another word, Madame Gazel walks away, leaving you to puzzle over what just happened.
(You have gained some peril)
Honorade gently flags down a the proprietor. "Monsieur! Is this 'Boulle's Furnishings'?"
Eventually, Madame Gazel emerges from the store, looking absolutely livid. She gestures to her coachman Rene, who starts bringing her carriage around.

"Eh? What? Speak up, madame!" He replies, holding a hand to his ear. 

All this time around hammering and saws must have taken its toll.
"I said 'Is this store Boulle's Furnishings?'. I've been told you make bespoke furniture."
It's then that you spot a familiar figure, wearing a dress as dark as midnight, examining a store with a worn and illegible sign.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Gentlemanly D: "What happens in Paris is the future of France, and I want to see it happen."
"Paris is the lesser of two evils. Snubs and ridicule are better than insignificance."
"I love the people here. There's a passion that I'm drawn to."
"I miss them quite a lot, actually."
"Who is he? He's one of the Queen's Royal Dragoons, you ingrate!"
"Monsieur, I'm the one you owe an apology to! Or is this how you treat all women?"
"Yes and no. I love them, but I can't be who I really am when I'm around them."
<Say nothing>
"I'm sorry but it doesn't really bother me. I'm my own person."
"Don't worry, I'm fine."
"I'm a little shaken as well."
"I should be asking you that. What happened back there?"
"Oh, but of course!"
"I need some time to think. Tonight was... a bit much."
Your rendezvous complete, you decide to head home. Alexandre insists on walking you there, saying that he'd never forgive himself if he let some misfortune befall you.
Silently, he takes your hand.
"You've had every reason to leave Paris, yet you're still here. Why?"
He nods along. "A good reason. History is being made every day, but here feels like the center of it all. You can feel the tension in the air. You can feel the passion burning in people's hearts."
"I suppose that's true." He admits.
"I feel much the same way." He replies, squeezing your hand gently.
(You've gained some favor with Alexandre)
"Though I hope you manage to find a more worthwhile reason to stay."
(You've gained a little favor with Alexandre)

You continue to walk together, sticking near the buildings to avoid getting struck by any reckless carriages that might come barrelling down the street. Coachmen these days are paid for speed, not safety.
The door of a house suddenly bursts open in front of you. A grimy man steps out.
Without a word, this man shoves you out of the way and silently starts marching down the street.
The conversation dies down somewhat when he takes hold of you, but that doesn't matter. The warmth of his body says enough.
His face controted with anger, Alexandre yells at the man walking away from you."You! Monsieur! Halt, right now!"

The dragoon marches over to this man and looms over him, but not with the force of a soldier preparing for yet another fight. There's something else about Alexandre's demeanor. He is incensed, haughty, and imperious.
"Have you taken leave of your senses, you loathsome imbecile? Do you think it is acceptable for a man to act this way? You will apologize to her, immediately!"
While taken aback at first, the grimy man who treated you so rudely, sneers and replies "I shall do no such thing!"
"I am-" Alexandre begins, but halts suddenly. He steps backwards, less sure of himself.
"I am... I am..."
"I am... nobody..."
At this, Alexandre straightens up again, this time placing his hand on the pommel of his sabre.
"I owe nothing to you, madame." He sneers. "If you dislike my behavior so much, then don't walk near my house!"
"... just the son of a slave..."
"You've been in Paris for quite some time. Do you miss your family at all?"
At this, Alexandre straightens up again, this time placing his hand on the pommel of his sabre. "Monsieur, are you sure that's what you want to say to her?"
"Madame is correct. I am one of the Queen's Royal Dragoons, and those who insult me insult Her Majesty herself."
At this, the boorish man feels less sure of himself. He grumbles a half-hearted apology to the both of you and scurries away, taking great care to avoid eye contact with either of you.
Alexandre tensely watches the man until he's completely out of sight. The dragoon is shaking a little.
He turns to you with a wide grin, as if nothing had happened at all. "Sorry about that. I'm normally much better about this sort of thing."
He looks uncertain. "That's good."
He relaxes, letting tension release from his shoulders. "That's to be expected, I imagine. I appreciate your candor."
"... Dumas isn't my real surname. It was my mother's."
"Do you wish to disrespect your Queen, God preserve her, or do you wish to be as polite as decorum requires?"
Alexandre looks to you, and gives a confident, thankful nod.
"My word, that must be very hard for you." He says with a shake of his head.
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
Alexandre looks to you, and gives a confident nod.
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
The grimy man stares at both of you expectantly, until he finally tires of your silence, and turns to leave.
He marches off into the night, presumably to be terrible to someone else.
"Are you alright?"
"I'm... I'm fine as well."
"Still, you make fine company, even when we're beset by the most boorish louts in Paris!"
"My father forbade me from enlisting under the family name. He felt I would be dragging it through the mud..."
His next words are a whisper, one only you can hear.
He smiles at your reply. "I can understand that. If we are a seed then family is the soil in which we grow. However, if we stay too close, we might find ourselves wilting in their shade."
"Who the devil are you, to ask this of me?"
The two of you walk and talk, and try to settle yourselves after what transpired.
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
"I wanted to make something of myself, and it only brought him shame."
"Thank you for asking, Yvette. As you can imagine, I rarely have occasion to discuss these sorts of things."
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
You both do a decent job it, and manage to almost forget that boorish man's attempts to spoil your evening.
Before you know it, you arrive at your humble home. Camille doesn't come out to greet you, but given the late hour, that's unsurpring.
"Bonne nuit, Yvette." Alexandre says with bow. "Shall I see you again soon?"

Inside, you gently step over Camille, who happens to be sleeping in the hallway. Heading upstairs to undress and to chronicle the evening's events in your journal, you wonder when you'll next learn more of this mysterious soldier.
"There's no need to apologize, at all. Blood is all well and good, but it doesn't have to be the most important thing. Never be ashamed for wanting to make something of your own."

Inside, you carefully step over Camille, who fell asleep in the hallway. You creep upstairs to undress and chronicle the evening's events in your journal. Unfortunately, you can't help but replay the evening's events in your head, and wonder what could possibly come next after that.
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
"As for myself, I'm not sure if I really miss my family, such as it was..."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Getting Caugh: You pause to read the social pages of the newspaper while you take your breakfast, sitting at your vanity. One of the benefits of working for Pierre is getting a free newspaper everyday.

It's then that you nearly spit said breakfast all over your mirror when you read the social pages more closely. Paying attention to key details, you realize that the stories Pierre wrote using your gossip could be traced back to you. 

If you can do it, there's a good chance that someone else can too.
(You have gained a decent amount of peril)
This, of course, will not do great things for your reputation.
(You have lost a decent amount of credibility)
You put down the newspaper and sigh. With that, your day has only begun.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Her Muse.asse: "Elisabeth, is something wrong?"
<Say Nothing>
"I'm not chill with that"
"Oh, really? So, is my real body not good enough?"
"What? Is the real thing not good enough?"
"In that case, I'd love to."
"Hmm... I don't think I can, sorry."
<Say Nothing>
"I can't believe this is happening. This is amazing."
"What did I just agree to?"
"Can I? I'd love to."
"I don't think I can, sorry."
"Wait, nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
"Wait, nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
"Wait, nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
<Say Nothing>
"Wait, nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
<Say Nothing>
"I'd love to."
"I don't think I can do that."
"Nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
"Nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
"Sounds good to me."

After your rendezvous, Elisabeth offers to walk you home. The streets are empty, so you walk down the center of the road, arm in arm. While you can distantly hear the sound of the city's clamor from other streets, you feel like the only people in the world.
She does it again.
"Naked portraits focus on realism, while nudity is about capturing the ideal."

She flushes with embarassment. 

"No! That's not what I meant! I mean the painting isn't just about you being naked. It's about focusing on the ideal, to make a point."
"... it might also be about you being naked."

"It'll take a few sittings, but you can come by my studio whenever you like."

(You can now visit Elisabeth's studio for portrait sessions in the Paris Map)

"I think we'll both find this it very... inspiring." She flashes you a mischevious smile.

The two of you walk and talk together for a while longer, but your mind is swimming with the possibilities of what you just agreed to.
You get home, and pace around your room, feeling a combination of nervousness, excitement and exhaustion.

Your walk the rest of the way home is quiet, with a few attempts at conversation that don't completely spring to life.

Elisabeth seems distracted.
When you get home, she gives you a wave goodbye and heads towards the main road.
Before you go to bed, you practice a few elegant poses in the mirror, imagining what it will be like to have your beauty immortalized by such an incredible artist.
You stare at yourself in the mirror before you go to bed, and hesitantly practice a few poses. The thought of someone staring at you naked, for hours at a time, does little to calm your nerves.

She laughs, and while it isn't loud, it feels like a great pressure has been released.

"Nothing's wrong! I'm sorry, this isn't normally a problem for me."
She glances at you and opens her mouth to speak, but stops and looks away.
Suddenly, she blurts it out. "Can you pose nude for me?"
The painting sessions can't come soon enough.
Fitfully, you manage to get to sleep.

In your room, you barely manage to get undressed before you collapse in your bed.

This has been quite a day.
The feeling in the air grows tenser. She stops and starts a few more times before she finally says it.
"Yvette, I... want to paint a new portrait, but not for a client. I want to make something more personal."
"I want to paint a new portrait, but not for a client. I want to make something more personal."
"Yvette, would you like to pose nude for me?"

"Fantastique!"

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
"Oh. That's too bad."
"Well, not entirely. 'Nude' and 'naked' don't mean the same thing in art."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Holier Than T: "Whatever happened to forgiveness? I'm here to meet with goodly people and change my ways."
"If you know me so well, then you know not to cross me. Don't rush to become a martyr."
"I think that if you spoke with Father Sidotti, he'd be able to vouch for me."
You breathe in deep and take in the smell of nearby candles as you survey the party for the best potential targets of your social endeavours.
In fact, you manage to spot a cluster of people who should be perfect for just that. Exactly the sort who can provide the best gossip.
(You have gained a little credibility)

"If that's the case, I imagine you can't be as bad as I thought." She continues, more cheerily.

You resist the urge to roll your eyes.
(You have gained a little peril)
Your flinty stare suggests that yes, you are more than willing to do that.

After a long pause, she scoffs and leaves, trying not to seem afraid. However, you notice that she's leaving you faster than she approached, significantly undermining the illusion she was trying to create.
She saunters away, seemingly satisfied with the results of her uninvited judgement.
With her dispatched, you approach that promising group you were seeking before and manage to chat with them for a few moments before they disperse.
(You have gained a piece of Cheap Church Gossip)

As these guests scatter, you carefully rehearse your newly acquired gossip in your head, in order to commit it to memory. 

It's not your ideal outcome, but you still managed to rid yourself of that prying fool. If nothing else, that's a victory all its own.
Since the devil fails to appear, she is forced to accept your story.
However, just as you begin to walk over, you're intercepted by a woman who isn't merely wearing a sour look on her face. She instead appears to be living that look.
(You have gained a little credibility)
Without another word, she leaves, both cautious and confused.
(You have lost some credibility)

She turns and leaves in a self righteous huff, which you would care about more if it weren't for the fact that the people you were actually hoping to speak with have already dispersed amongst the rest of the party.
Muttering a variety of curses to yourself, you look around and hope you have some more time at this party to rescue this situation.
"Bon soir, Madame Decaux, let me save you some time and tell you that your reputation has preceded you. A lot has been said about your conduct, and none of it labels you as a woman of God."
"So answer me a simple question. What, exactly are you doing here?"
"What, you’re just here to cast aside your social climbing ways to seek a life of humility?" She asks as you attempt to appear as beatific as you possibly can.
"You're going to issue threats? Here, in a house of God?" She asks incredulously.
"Really? You, of all people, know Father Sidotti?" She asks, reappraising you more carefully this time.
"I suppose that could be possible." She admits, glancing around as if the devil himself was preparing to jump out from a nearby chapel and drag you back into his nefarious embrace.
"... and now you even choose to lie here. How... expected."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Home, Sweet H: “Fine. When I’m done, Armand is simply going to wish the rats had eaten him.”
"Uh... thank you Camille. Do you think Armand's alright?"
“He has a lot of explaining to do.”
“Uh… thank you Camille. Do you think Armand’s alright?”
"Merci Camille, please take me to Armand."
"Is this where he lives? Oh God, the rats in there ate him, didn't they?"

After waiting around for a few hours, you leave the Orphan’s Feast, dragging your small mountain of luggage behind you. After all, the coach was only hired to take you to the tavern. Armand may not have been waiting for you like he said he would, but you memorized his address from all of the times you wrote it on your letters to him.

It’s the middle of the night, but the street is still teeming with life. The light from the windows and the street lamps sparkle like the stars. You’re tired and your feet hurt, but still, you can’t help but smile.

This is it. This is Paris. No matter what happens, you’re still here.
Eyeing her worn shoes, you have a feeling the rats didn’t go quietly.

“I’m sure he’s fine Madame,” Camille replies with a tone of voice that doesn’t fill you with confidence. Glancing around, Camille seems to notice your mountain of luggage for the first time. “Mon Dieu, Madame! Did you carry this all yourself? You must be exhausted!”
At this, Camille takes a deep, nervous breath. “I’m afraid to tell you that you’ll have to wait, Madame. It’s been days since I’ve seen Monsieur Armand. I was hoping that he was with you.”

She’s not wrong. You’re not certain how you’re still upright and awake right now. 
“I’ve already made up your bed Madame, please go inside and let me take care of this.”

You take your diary and leave the heavy lifting to Camille. The inside of the house isn’t much better than the outside. Camille keeps the place tidy, but she can only do such much. Still, you don’t care about that right now, you’re just happy to have a roof over your head.
You flop down on a nearby couch, open your diary, and start to write. You’re tired, disappointed, and perhaps abandoned, but writing things down always helps you make sense of a situation.

While you’re still processing this latest disappointment, Camille seems to notice your mountain of luggage for the first time. “Mon Dieu, Madame! Did you carry this all yourself? You must be exhausted!”

She’s not wrong. You’re not certain how you’re still upright and awake right now. 
“I’ve already made up your bed Madame, please go inside and let me take care of this.” Camille insists.

"I'm sure he's fine Madame," Camille replies with a tone of voice that doesn't fill you with confidence. "I'm sorry to tell you this, but I haven't seen Monsieur Armand in days. I was hoping he was with you."
Glancing around, Camille seems to notice your mountain of luggage for the first time. "Mon dieu Madame! Did you carry this all yourself? You must be exhausted!"
For a brief moment, you’re not a country girl dragging luggage through the streets. You’re the person you feel that you are, when you close your eyes, alone.
You’re overseeing a grand salon, surrounded by poets, musicians, scientists, philosophers, and artists. You are elegant, sophisticated, and respected.

You’re getting close to the address. Armand never described his living conditions much, but he’s the son of a Baron and his family was always well to-do, especially compared to yours. You’ve spent a lot of time in that carriage wondering about the home you’d spend your new life in.
Still, you didn’t expect this...

Calling the house ‘rustic’ would imply that you were out in the country, not in the center of a city. The neighborhood is nice enough, but you’re worried that if you breathe too hard on the building, it’ll fall over. A well kept woman in the attire of a maid opens the door and approaches you.
“Ah, bonsoir! I assume you must be Madame Yvette! My name is Camille, Monsieur Armand told me to expect you.”
“I… I was hoping that he was with you.” Camille replies hesitantly. “I haven’t seen him in days.”
“Impossible, Madame! I’ve taken care of all the rats myself.” Camille replies, emphasizing her point with a playful stomp of her foot.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Honorade's Cl: "I think you’re right, what now?”
“You’re enjoying this, aren’t you?”
“Merci, Honorade.”
“Are you sure this carriage is… discreet?”
You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Honorade mentioned in her letter to you.
Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you decided to dress in darker clothes, and stuck to comfortable walking shoes.
As with before, it takes a few moments for your eyes to adjust to the oppressive darkness within.
Madame Gazel follows you inside and takes up her normal seat across from you. With a silent signal to René, the carriage takes off.

“Besides, this dress is silk and I’m not going to risk falling into a fountain with it on,” she continues and offers her hand to you. Judging from her tone, you get the feeling that disagreeing with her logic won’t get you anywhere.
You take her hand and get into the carriage. As with before, it takes a few moments for your eyes to adjust to the oppressive gloom within.

She sips at her glass of water and spends a few moments simply looking you over. You’re not really sure what she’s looking for. After a while, she seems satisfied, and continues.

“Since you’re here, I’ll assume that you read my letter.”

“It’s possible that you’re more forgiving than myself, but the thought of what happened to you that night still makes me livid. At first, I admittedly knew very little about Marcelle, but the more I started learning about her, the less I liked. Now that I’ve gotten to know her better, I’m not surprised at all that she would be so… contemptible.”

“So, I did what anyone else would do. I held meetings with as many of her business partners as I could, claiming to be interested in investing my husband’s fortune. They, of course, fell all over themselves in order to meet with me and try to part me from my late husband’s money.”

“During those meetings, I asked about Marcelle’s family investments, and pretended to be very impressed with whatever they told me. However, in that whole time, I couldn’t find evidence that any of her family’s investments were older than thirty years or so.”

“Thirty years is a long time for a single person, but that’s not how the aristocratic families see the world. The Gazel family’s fortune is forty years old and we’re still derided as ‘new money’” Honoroade pauses to sip her water and sneer at some unseen adversary. 

“As if recent success was something to be ashamed of. To put it simply, why would her family pretend their fortune is older than it really is?”
“That gaudy wretch is hiding something about her money. Knowing what she’s like in public, anything she wants to hide must be dark indeed.”

Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.
“Now?”
“Oh my, yes.” She answers, making no attempt to hide how much she is relishing the current situation.

“Now you pursue this lead, hatch a plan, and get your revenge. What that requires is really up to you. I’m more than happy to provide you with information, but I think you’ll be better served if you handle the rest yourself.”
“Of course, you could always just give up, but I don’t think that sort of thing suits you.”
“I like you, and I despise Marcelle.” Madame Gazel says, a simple statement of facts. “The idea of you toppling that tasteless wretch is extremely satisfying.”

“Given what I saw from you that night, I have a feeling that you and I share a flare for the dramatic. I expect that whatever you choose to do will be suitably poetic, considering what she’s done to you.”

Madame Gazel signals to René and the carriage begins to roll to a stop. Pulling back the curtains for a moment, you realize that you’re already outside your home. “While we must unfortunately part ways,” Honorade says as René open the door. “I wish you the best of luck in your quest for vengeance.”

She helps you down from the carriage, and with a crack of René’s whip, her carriage departs and winds its way into the city. You stop to think about this new information. Marcelle is a wealthy aristocrat, but her fortune appears to be younger than she claims. It seems like this knowledge could be useful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.
(You have lost a little credibility)
(You haved gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)

Looking around, you can’t spot Madame Gazel anywhere, so you decide to take a seat at the edge of the fountain. It makes sense to be visible enough that she’ll be able to find you without any flashy waving or signalling.
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(Researching Marcelle is now available to visit in the Paris map)
With that, you start to head home, already planning your next move against your sworn enemy.

You get comfortable, smooth out your skirts and pause for a moment to reflect on the decisions that led you to a point in your life where you’re having secret rendezvous with a glamorous widow to learn the secrets of your most hated enemies. If anything, they must have been some good decisions.

After only a few minutes of waiting by the fountain, Honorade’s carriage pulls up and René, Honorade’s trust coachman steps down off of his box to open the door for her. It’s the middle of the day, but the inside of the luxuriously decorated carriage is still shrouded in gloom.

“You’re enjoying this, aren’t you?”
“Merci, Honorade.”
“Are you sure this carriage is… discreet?”
You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Honorade mentioned in her letter to you.
Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you decided to dress in darker clothes, and stuck to comfortable walking shoes.
As with before, it takes a few moments for your eyes to adjust to the oppressive gloom within.
Madame Gazel follows you inside and takes up her normal seat across from you. With a silent signal to René, the carriage takes off.

She sips at her glass of water and spends a few moments simply looking you over. You’re not really sure what she’s looking for. After a while, she seems satisfied, and continues.

“Since you’re here, I’ll assume that you read my letter.”

“Besides, this dress is silk and I’m not going to risk falling into a fountain with it on,” she continues and offers her hand to you. Judging from her tone, you get the feeling that disagreeing with her logic won’t get you anywhere.
You take her hand and get into the carriage. As with before, it takes a few moments for your eyes to adjust to the oppressive gloom within.

“It’s possible that you’re more forgiving than myself, but the thought of what happened to you that night still makes me livid. Starting off, I barely knew anything about Maximin, but the more I started learning about him, the less I liked. Knowing what I know now, it doesn’t surprise me that he would be so absolutely vile to you.”

“While I have nothing against the revolutionary nationalists, per se, I often get the feeling that denouncing those with less informed or extreme views is their preferred way of accruing political currency.” Honorade pauses to stare out the window for a moment. “I prefer money, it seems less cruel.”

“Speaking of cruelty I started looking into Maximin’s household. If you want to learn something about someone, see how they treat those closest to them. That’s when I discovered that Maximin’s estate hires and fires servants at a prodigious rate.” She pauses to reach into the pockets of her dress and hands you a list of names, presumably of the aforementioned servants.

“Most of those that left his service were quite vocal about their reasons for leaving, usually citing things like long hours, skipped wages, and other issues. However, I noticed there was one servant who left completely silently. I wouldn’t have given it a second though, if all the others weren’t so loud.”
“A servant left Maximin’s service, but keeps their reasons a secret… if that presumptuous rodent has a weakness, then this is it.”

Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.
“Now?”
“Oh my, yes.” She answers, making no attempt to hide how much she is relishing the current situation.

“Now you pursue this lead, hatch a plan, and get your revenge. What that requires is really up to you. I’m more than happy to provide you with information, but I think you’ll be better served if you handle the rest yourself.”
“Of course, you could always just give up, but I don’t think that sort of thing suits you.”

“I like you, and now that I actually know something about him, I hate Maximin.” Madame Gazel pauses to take a sip of her water. “The idea of you bringing him to some sort of justice is extremely satisfying.”

“Given what I saw from you that night, I have a feeling that you and I share a flare for the dramatic. I expect that whatever you choose to do will be suitably poetic, considering what he’s done to you.”

Madame Gazel signals to René and the carriage begins to roll to a stop. She helps you down from the carriage, and with a crack of René’s whip, her carriage departs and winds its way into the city. You stop to think about this new information. A mystery servant who left Maximin’s employment suddenly, and under murky circumstances. It seems fruitful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.

Walking to Madame Gazel's home, you realize that you've never actually been there before. Thankfully, you've already memorized her address from all the letters she's sent you.

Of course, even if you didn't know the address already, you'd certainly be able to recognize the place. An elaborate, fashionable rocoo building sits back from the street and behind a gate. The windows are shrouded by gauzy black curtains.
His eyes widen as you produce the black satin oufit that Madame Gazel gave you, so long ago. René smiles, broadly and genuinely.

Looking around, expecting some sort of specter or sorcery at play, you instead notice Madame Gazel's servant, René. You're especially surprised to notice that he's no longer wearing his black armband.
You step back inside for a few minutes, and while his help isn't as quick as Camille's, or as sensual as Madame Gazel's, you still find yourself dressed and looking as amazing as ever.
Back in the garden, she is waiting on her chaise longue. Reading by a lantern amongst the flowers. A single spot of sumptuous darkness, in a halo of light.
You step out of the darkness, suddenly appearing before her dressed in the vision that she imagined for you.
For once, in all of the time that you've known her, you have truly caught her off guard.
Her eyes drink you in, deeply and hungrily as she stalks towards you. "You, my darling Yvette, are a vision."
"That you would even think to..." She trails off, holding the edge of your midnight colored skirt between thumb and forefinger.
"Merveilleuse..."

No tour of the house is provided, but you do stroll through the dining room and the salon towards the garden in the back. You're offered a glass of wine from an impressively dusty bottle, which you take. It's simply nice to be prepared.

"I wasn't an only child, and my mother never made it to this country."
His next words are difficult, a creaking wheeze. "He sold my three siblings, and my mother. There was no policy set in place to buy them back. He never intended to see them again."
"It's nice being your father's favorite, but sometimes..."
"That's true, I suppose. I never asked him for any of this." He admits.
You walk up to him with no hesitation, but he has still yet to notice you.
"Yes, I do feel that," he sighs. "I'm glad you understand."
"... because they're thousands of miles away, where simple messages take months arrive."
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
"What am I saying?" He growls, to himself more than anyone else. "It's not a feeling, it's an objective fact."
Seeing your confused expression, the anger leaves him, replaced only by melancholy. "The average lifespan of a working slave in Saint Domingue... is around ten years."
"... and because this all hapened nearly a decade ago!"
(You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
"I wouldn't be here, with all of my advantages, if he hadn't condemned them to that suffering."

You arrive at a gravestone. It's carved from fine marble, but already marred with dirth and soot. It says 'Marquis Alexandre Antoine Davy de la Pailleterie'. A series of battles are listed under the name.
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
Hanging back, you watch him for a while. He paces back and forth in the street like a caged tiger, wearing an expression of deep concern.
"He served in the army as well. I joined up to make him proud, but when he died I realized that there was nobody left to be proud of me."
"I thought that I should honor his memory, but now I'm starting to think that's wrong too."
"I've been trying to live up to a great legacy... that isn't great at all."
"You're absolutely right. I must fight for others. I must do the things he would have never thought to do."
"No." He replies flatly. "I cannot live selfishly. I cannot live, as he lived."
"I like that idea." He smiles thinly, eyes still fixed on the headstone.
(You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
He leans back his head and shouts "I am Thomas-Alexandre Davy de la Pailleterie, true heir to the title of the Marquis de la Pailleterie!"
With his powerful strides, he still looks ever the man of action, even when he's worried. You feel as if you understand him a little better.
He sighs contentedly, as if letting down a great weight. "But none of that matters..."
"Today, I am Thomas-Alexandre Dumas. I am a man who will help the downtrodden. One who will use his might, in service of right."
He looks at you and grins. "And I am so fortunate, to have people with me, who could help me when I was lost."
He kneels down, and with a handkerchief, cleans the smudges of dirt from the headstone. "Farewell father. I shall not return."
"Yvette, I think we should be on our way."
You walk outside with him, and notice that the funeral party from before has also finished up. While they still look somber, you can tell that they're also ready to move forward with their lives.
"Thank you again. I don't think I could have done that by myself."
He gives you a theatrical bow "I am in your debt."
"I'm sorry, but you should be able to understand why I wasn't comfortable putting some of this in a letter. This has not been easy."
He laughs loudly. "Yvette, if that's nothing to you, I can't wait to see what you think a real favor for your friends is."
(You have gained a little credibility)
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
(You have lost some favor with Alexandre)
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
You look to the horizon and realize that the sun is setting. You glimpse beautiful oranges and purples between the buildings of the Paris skyline.
"Another day in the place that's been kinder to me than anywhere else in the world. It's given me freedom, education, excitement..."
He loops his arm around your waist.
"...and love."
As you crane your neck to bring your lips closer to his, you feel one of his arms sweep behind your knees and he lifts towards himself, almost like a dancer's dip.
You wraps your arms around him and he hugs you close. Tightly and fiercely.
Your lips meet. You fling your arms around his neck and he only holds you closer. Between throes of passion, your eyes open for but a moment, and you glimpse a single tear rolling down his cheek.
He looks up at you and approaches. His face wearing the same stony expression of concern.
(You have earned a lot of favor with Alexandre)

Love is, of course, bigger than its grand romatnic gestures. The two of you spend the next hour watching the sunset, laughing and joking with each other. He regales with stories of daring that grow improbably with every telling.
His body is as still and powerful as a tree, but as you rest your head against his chest, you can hear his heart beating at a furious tempo.
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
The sun sets and with nightfall, he walks you home. You find Camille waiting for you outside.
"Bonsoir madame! Bonsoir monsieur! Did you enjoy your evening?"
"I think Madame Decaux here is going to be a little more cautious when agreeing to mysterious invitations from now on, but otherwise I think things went well!" Alexandre jests.
With that, Alexandre excuses himself and heads off into the night.
"And you enjoyed yourself as well, madame?"
With memories of the happy evening still in your mind, you head upstairs to record the details in your journal, before getting ready for bed.
Seeing no other way to get his attention, you playfully tap him on the shoulder.
Trying to ignore the mental images of the lost souls that you so frequently discussed tonight, you trudge upstairs to record the details in your journal, before getting ready for bed.
"No... I have not..."
"... because my father had made powerful enemies when he left Saint Domingue..."
"Once the rose colored lenses are lifted from your eyes, they can never be put back on, but that's alright. I can still be inspired by my memories."
Love is joy, love is comfort, love is passion, but sometimes love is also catharsis.
Camille laughs, but you're not sure if she gets the joke.
"Ah, you're here! I'm so glad you came." He admits, with no small amount of relief.
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Lost Coin.ass: "We should find the real owner."
"We should find the real owner."
"We should find the real owner."
"We should find the real owner."
"Mon dieu, I'm so glad you found my wallet!"
"An unmarked wallet? I can only assume that half of it is mine, and the other half yours."
"While I understand that you'd like to split it, we should find the real owner."
"We should find the real owner."
"We should find the real owner."
"We should find the real owner."
"We should find the real owner."
Feeling the need to take a quick break, you step into an empty room.

While you're composing yourself, a chambermaid approaches you. She's holding a small, unmarked wallet. "Pardonne moi, madame. I found this wallet while I was tidying up. I took it to the master and mistress of the house, but they do not recognize it. I've been told not to rest until the owner is found."
The two of you check the party together, looking for the owner of the mysterious wallet.

Eventually, you come upon a man who recognizes it immediately. "Oh, thank you so much! I hadn't even realized I'd misplaced it." Some of the nearby guests murmur approvingly of your honesty.

(You have gained a little credibility)
(You have reduced your peril a tiny bit)
"However, if I am mistaken, you may consult our host and have it returned to you." A task which you both know that you will not attempt.

With a fake smile, the chambermaid curtsies politely and leaves. 

Muttering a choice selection of curses, you decide to investigate the rest of the party.
With a polite nod, you excuse yourself and leave to check out the rest of the party.

She hands you the wallet, and curtsies politely. You make a great show of thumbing through this mysterious wallet to make sure that everything is there.

Before the chambermaid can ask you any more questions, you excuse yourself and leave to check out the rest of the party.
After a few second of bluster, she calms down. "I suppose you're right. If we make a circuit of the party together, we might be able to find the owner this time."
"Do you know who this might belong to? Otherwise..."
[Credibility Check]
"Oh madame, you're absolutely right! I can't believe I forgot!" She replies, with outrageously feigned surprise.
"Madame, where could you have gotten that idea?" She replies, eyes darting about.

The two of you split the money found in the wallet, and the chambermaid tucks the emptied article into her bodice. "I can't imagine anyone careless enough to leave this lying around will mind too much." She says with a shrug.

(You have gained 28 livres)

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Ludovico - Ep: <Kiss him>
"This isn't 'goodbye'. Just 'see you soon'."
You hurry south through the city, trying to make sure that you make it to the docks in time.
You've already lost a lot of time from having to double back and find new routes. It looks like new barricades are going up every day, and the streets simply don't feel safe anymore.
You kiss with that passion which can only come from desperation. You drink deep of each other, unsure if this will be your last chance to ever do so.
It isn't a painful delusion, because you both know it isn't real. You feel at peace. You feel some of the danger of the last few days slip away, and gain a sort of clarity.
(You have lost some peril)

"Attention!" Shouts the captain of Ludovico's boat above the din of the crowd. "We're getting ready to cast off. Those who are not on this vessel in three minutes will be left behind." He says with the finality of someone who has actually abandoned passengers before.
You stop for a moment, not because you want to, but because you both need to beathe in order to live.
"This is it. Arrivederci, Yvette."
"I love you." He says, one last time before boarding his boat.

"Attention!" Shouts the captain of Ludovico's boat above the din of the crowd. "We're getting ready to cast off. Those who are not on this vessel in three minutes will be left behind." He says with the finality of someone who has actually abandoned passengers before.

You stay on the dock for a while, and watch his boat disappear into the distance. Part of you wants to watch him for as long as you can, and another part of you simply isn't ready for the trials of getting home through all of this chaos.
You wonder to yourself, is this something lost, or is this just another reason to make sure you survive?

Finally, you make it to the docks. Instead of the normal bevy of merchant vessels, you can only see barges taking on people, most of them laden with as many of their world possessions as possible. The barges will likely take these peopel via the river to a proper port city. Most people with a desire to leave Paris, and the means to do so, are leaving France altogether.

You wonder if they have the right idea.
"This is it. Addio, Yvette."
With a downcast gaze, he boards his boat.
True to his word, the captain casts off in three minutes, and soon it starts to leave Paris behind.
As the boat starts to leave, you're about to turn and head home, until you see Ludovico run to the back of the boat. He starts shouting, loud enough for everyone to hear.
"Yvette! Please stay safe! You're the best woman I've ever met!"
"You're the greatest blessing I've ever had!"
There's a hesitation in his voice, as he realizes that the entire dock is watching you both. He chooses his next words carefully.
"I'll pray for you, every day!"

The dock is awash in murmurs as the assembled crowd tries to understand what they just bore witness to. Tensing up, waiting for the sudden backlash, you realize that the people around you think that you must be an extremely loyal and devout Christian, in order to get a priest to react this way.
(You have gained quite a bit of credibility)
You spot Ludovico walking down from a gangplank, and peering into the crowd. When he spots you, his face blossoms into an exuberant smile.
True to his word, the captain casts off in three minutes. Just like that, it starts to leave Paris behind.
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
He pushes through the crowd to get to you. "Yvette! I'm so glad you came. You have no idea how much this means to me."
However, his joy quickly fades, as he remembers what you're both here to do.
"I guess, this is goodbye."
Unable to restrain yourself further, you grab Ludovico by the wrist and lead him behind a nearby building for one last embrace.

The two of you sit on a the edge of the dock together. You laugh and joke, you talk about which books you've been reading recently. Together, you pretend that nothing is ever going to change.

You pretend as if this moment will last forever.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Ludovico's Cl: “Merci Ludovico, your help means a lot to me.”
“You’re a lot more devious than I expected you to be.”
“Oh father, my woes are too terrible to discuss in a place like this. Perhaps we can go somewhere... private?”
“Ludovico, if we’re being followed, our pursuers already know who we are.”
You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Ludovico mentioned in his letter to you.
Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you’ve decided to dress in darker clothes, and have stuck to comfortable walking shoes.

“I know I’ve already said this before, but I still want to tell you that I’m sorry for everything that happened to you. From what I know, Marcelle’s always had a penchant for being vindictive. This, combined with her wealth and position, makes her a force to be reckoned with.”

“... is a very good point,” he admits with a defeated sigh. You can tell that he was quite enjoying this air of intrigue, but you’d rather have some quick results. Ludovico sits down next to you and composes himself.

“Strangely enough, the moment I actually started looking into Marcelle’s wealth and position, something didn’t feel right. She claims that her storied family fortune comes from a series of wise investments, so I started paying visits and offering blessings to some of her family’s known business partners. In that whole time, I couldn’t find evidence that any of her family’s investments were older than thirty years or so.”

“Thirty years is a long time for most people, yes, but compared to most aristocratic families, that’s barely the blink of an eye. From the mindset of the clergy, it’s even less. There are churches in France that are over 1,000 years old. Why would her family pretend their fortune is older than it really is?”
“It feels like Marcelle is hiding something, and it has to do with her money.”
“Think nothing of it madame, I’m just trying to do the right thing.”

Ludovico leans in close and whispers in your ear, his voice barely audible. “Madame, Rome chose me as their eyes and ears in France. You didn’t think that they’d sent someone who’s never gotten their hands dirty, did you?”
You’re not sure if Ludovico helping you exact your revenge could really be classified as ‘the right thing’, but you’re not going to complain.

“While I must go, remember that all of this is speculation. If you want to use any of this information against Marcelle, you’ll need indisputable proof of whatever lies or wrongdoing she’s engaged in, or it’ll simply be your word against hers. Still, I will pray for your success.”

Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.
“Haha! Sorry, I’ve always wanted to say something like that.”

“Honestly, it’s been a nice change of pace. Normally I just spend a lot of time listening to bishops and writing letters back to the Vatican. This has me out and about, enjoying Paris, and getting a feel for its people.”
“Ciao, madame.” Ludovico says before leaving.

You stop to think about this new information. Marcelle is a wealthy aristocrat, but her fortune appears to be younger than she claims. It seems like this knowledge could be useful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.
(You have lost a little favor with Ludovico)
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
(Researching Marcelle is now available to visit in the Paris map)
With that, you start to head home, already planning your next move against your sworn enemy.

Looking around, you can’t spot Ludovico anywhere, so you decide to take a seat at the edge of the fountain. It makes sense to be visible enough that he’ll be able to find you without any flashy waving or signalling.

You get comfortable, smooth out your skirts and pause for a moment to reflect on the decisions that led you to a point in your life where you’re having secret rendezvous with priests to learn more about your hated enemies. If anything, they must have been some good decisions.

Some time later, after you’ve waved away a particularly enthusiastic tea salesman for the third time, a familiar face emerges from behind the shadows of a tree. “Bonjour madame” he nods pleasantly. “You seem troubled.”
“Is there anything this humble priest can help you with?”
“That is an excellent idea madame. Please lead the way.”
“That…”

You find a quiet corner in the square to speak with Ludovico. It’s secluded and shady. 

Ludovico takes a deep breath before he begins.

She leaves, casting more than one devious glance back at the two of you as she does so. Ludovico says nothing, but the grin on his face already tells you everything you need to know.

“I may be a commoner, but at least I know how to treat my guests.”
“Poor Armand is ill at the moment, but he just insisted that I attend your party.”
“That’s actually what I was hoping to find out. Do you know where I could find him?”
“...why did you invite Armand here?”
“I’m guessing this means you don’t know where he is, either?”
“I may be audacious, but at least I know how to treat my guests.”
“...why did you invite Armand here?”
“Do you always bemoan every ‘nuisance’ you send a handwritten invitation to?”

You nearly mistake the woman standing in front of you for some kind of walking confection. A pampered dog lounges in her arms. “I don’t believe we had the chance to properly introduce ourselves. I am Viscountess Marcelle de Foix.”
Her voice raises in volume imperceptibly, but it’s enough to draw the attention of the large crowd in the room. “Everyone, this is Yvette, Armand’s fiancee!”

Marcelle pauses to pet her dog. “I don’t know where he is. In fact, it’s a shame that Armand’s already scurried off somewhere. I was really hoping to tell him this to his face, but then again, he always was so good at disappointing people. You’ll have to do.”

For a moment, the crowd hushes. You seem to have struck a nerve. Even the dog looks a little undone. “I suppose that when cornered, even a rat will think it’s a lion,” Marcelle whispers, her voice like ice.
“After all, you’ve already helped me!”

“Armand, that ambitious little rat, was always reaching above his station. His audacity truly knew no bounds.” Her eyes are focused on you, but she’s speaking to the crowd, who seem to whisper in agreement. Even the dog regards you with malice.
“Now, not only do I find out that he’s a coward, who’s fled his fiancee, and his responsibilities…”
“but now, I have this commoner, who doesn’t know her place either!”

“Your Armand is a conniving, impish, opportunist who sullies the good name of the entire nobility just by being alive. The only reason he even chose a common girl like you to be his wife, is because any lady of good breeding would see him for the weasel that he is.”

“Please pay attention, because I hate repeating myself. Your Armand is gone, off somewhere on another one of his foolish little political endeavors. However, if you should ever find him, tell him that he is an impudent weasel, who should go back to whatever backwater he crawled out of, and leave the running of this country to his superiors.”
A small cheer rings up from the crowd.

Marcelle studies your face intently for a moment and her voice suddenly fills with concern. “Oh, you poor girl, don’t look so hurt! Think of this as educational. You don’t belong in Paris, the same way that a stray cat doesn’t belong in that dress.” She gestures dismissively at your finery.
A murmur of interest washes through the crowd, and you can feel their eyes focus on you.

“Now pay attention, because I’d hate for you to miss the point. If you should ever find your wandering Armand, tell him that he is an unwelcome, conniving weasel. In fact, both of you should go back to your petty little village, and leave Paris to your superiors.”
“Now leave my estate, and never show your face here again.”
"Trying to look like us? Act like us? Stop. You're just embarassing yourself."
"Oh really, he insisted?" Marcelle trills and her dog yips happily.
“Well I’m so glad you’re here, and I’m sure that he’ll be well soon.”
“I mean, that’s because we both know Armand’s not sick.”

“Nobody’s heard from your cowardly fiance in weeks, which is especially surprising, since he could never stop pestering his betters.” The crowd, which only seems to be growing, murmurs in agreement. “In fact, it’s been so long that I thought I was rid of him once and for all…”
“...but now, I now have his cast off fiancee, who even had the audacity to lie to my face!”
She pauses before speaking to you in a whisper loud enough for the entire room to hear. “Don’t worry, I don’t expect you to understand this.”

She advances on you, close enough to feel the heat of her breath. “Let me be clear. You and your grasping fiance are not guests in my home, nor will you ever be. I invited him here so I could express my displeasure to him in person.”
“Where is Armand, by the way?”

"I'm so glad to see you. Armand, that ambitious little thing, has told me so much about you. In fact, I'd say that he's quite infatuated with you. A common girl like yourself... you're so lucky!"

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Masks and Sha: “Where could I find a party mask?”
“Camille, I need to ruin someone’s birthday party. Fetch me a mask, immediately.”
You wake up to find two things on your nightstand: a letter sealed in wax, and a gaudy invitation printed on pink paper. Camille must have put them there while you were asleep.

You decide to read the letter first. It’s sealed in golden wax with the initials “L.S.” It must be from Ludovico.

Opening it up, you find another missive from him, written in his steady, well practiced handwriting.

‘Given her previous treatment of you, I have no desire to attend. Instead, I have included my invitation. While Marcelle may have banished you from her estate, this invitation and a mask should be sufficient for you to sneak in, by pretending to be my date for the evening.’
(You have recieved an invitation to Marcelle's Birthday Masquerade)

‘Hopefully, this shall make it easier for you to restore your lost honor.

Très cordiales salutations,

Alex’

While Marcelle may have banished you from her estate, this invitation and a mask should be sufficient for you to sneak in, by pretending to be me.’

‘Hopefully, this shall make it easier for you to get the revenge you obviously deserve.

Bien affectueusement,

Honorade’
You look down at the invitation on your nightstand and recognize it immediately as something Marcelle would send out. It’s the same shade of pink as the last ensemble you saw her in.
Just then, Camille enters your room. “Good morning madame!”
“Hmm…” Camille pauses to think, rubbing the hem of her apron between her thumb and forefinger.
“Oui, madame!” Camille replies obediently, before leaving to search the house for something appropriately dramatic.

You decide to read the letter first. It’s sealed in pristine blue wax with the initials “T-A.D.”. It must be from Alex.

Opening it up, you find another missive from him, written in his precise penmanship.

“I believe Monsieur Armand left behind a few masks when he departed. I’m sure one of them would be more than suitable. The masks themselves might be a little masculine, but perhaps that would make a fine contrast with your ensemble?”

Camille’s not wrong, you could make that work. Besides, the main purpose of the mask will be to conceal your identity.

It’s settled then.
You have an invitation. You have a mask. You have a birthday party that you just can’t wait to ruin.

The next few minutes are a cacophony of clatter as Camille frantically searches for an appropriate mask. A ceramic cup sails in and out of view through the open doorway to your bedroom. A small shattering sound marks it as yet another casualty in your quest for revenge.

Camille returns, breathing heavily and carrying a basket full of various costume odds and ends. “It appears that monsieur Armand left behind a few masks when he departed. I’m sure one of them would be more than suitable. The masks themselves might be a little masculine, but perhaps that would make a fine contrast with your ensemble?”

You decide to read the letter first. It’s sealed with a rich, purple wax seal, bearing the initials “H.G.” It must be from Madame Gazel.

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Maximin Appea: Maximin Appears
"I'm sorry, but Armand has taken ill. Still, he said that I just had to attend your party."
"I actually don't know, Maximin. I don't even know where he is."
"...why invite Armand if you disliked him so?"
“I don’t need your pamphlets to know that you’re being a presumptuous boor.”
"...if he was so mediocre, why did you invite him?"
"You don't know where he is either, then?"
“Are you even listening to yourself? Because I am, and I wish I wasn’t.”

Out of the corner of your eye, you notice a tall, thin man dressed in somber, serious colors. The way people are clustered around him, you get the feeling that he’s quite important. He glances up from his current conversation, politely excuses himself, and approaches you.

“But please, let us dispense with titles, you may call me Maximin!”

The crowd chuckles, and you can’t help but be surprised by this noble’s informality. This would be downright scandalous in any other circle. The conversations in the various corners of the room die down as people strain to hear your exchange with Maximin.
“If he’s lost then it means we no longer have to entertain his invalid opinions.”

“I invited your dullard fiance in order to denounce him and his views. People as uninformed as himself should not waste their time clouding discussions with their tiresome ignorance. They’re better served by repeating the words of their more revolutionary peers.”
“I do not know where he has skulked off to, nor am I inclined to find him.”
You hear a collective intake of breath from the gawking crowd. Maximin seems on the verge of a retort, but he stutters for a moment instead.
Maximin narrows his eyes until they’re barely more than slits. “In fact, you can practice this virtue now and make sure that he hears this, should you manage to find him.”

“Calls for moderation in our time of crisis can only be seen as treasonous to the people of France. He is an enemy of the revolution, an enemy of the common people of France, and an enemy of mine. The only thing he can do to atone for his miserable views is to take you, and return to the backwards obscurity from whence he came!”
Maximin’s voice drops low, to a growl barely above a whisper, “Before you speak, I already know what you’re thinking. That somehow, you don’t deserve this…”

“The only reason I even invited him was to save myself the time of authoring a pamphlet denouncing him.” Maximin snorts “He, and his regressive calls for moderation and discussion. In a time of such turmoil in our country, only decisive action has any meaning. To believe otherwise is to be a coward, and a bootlick to the enemies of the people.”

“And you…” he continues “I don’t need to investigate you any further to know that you are cut from the same wretched cloth.” 

The room is quiet enough to hear a pin drop.

The Baron takes a breath to recompose himself and snort derisively. “Well actually, if you’d taken the time to read any of the materials I just gave you, then you’d know that calls for civility are the enemy of progress.”

“It’s great to meet the woman Armand spoke so much of. He said more about you than he did the state of the nation, and you know much he loves that.” Maximin smiles and offers a knowing wink. “Now that I’ve seen you, I can see why he had such muddled priorities.”
He takes a step towards you, and you can see that his eyes are filled with hate. “Now still your childish tongue. The adults are talking.”
“You are wrong.”

“Our associations reflect our character, and you have chosen to associate yourself with an ignorant boor who drags at the heels of true progress in France. I can only assume that you are a craven opportunist who thought that marrying into a title would provide an easy path above her peers. That your life would be easy, if you just found the right person to latch onto.”
“Like a barnacle... or a leech.”
“You are a fool for believing that, and he is a fool for loving you.”
“Titles don’t elevate us above consequences. Now, leave my house and never return.”

“Ah, you must be Madame Decaux! I’m not sure if Armand spoke of me, I am Baron Maximin de Termes.” Right as he focuses his attention on you, you can feel everyone in the room watching you out of the corners of their eyes. His opinion must carry a great deal of weight.
“I’ve been told that Armand is unable to join us tonight. What has delayed him?”
"Oh, really?"
“You’ve lost him?” Maximin asks, a sudden note of confusion marring his features. “And you came here?”

“In fact, you may both find these useful!” He grabs a jumbled stack of political pamphlets off of his desk and hands them to you. “Discourse moves so rapidly after all, and I would hate for the two of you to have any trouble keeping up.”

A few voices in the crowd murmur in approval.

“Tell your Baron de Marbo to stay in his sick bed. It is a blessing for all of France that we no longer have to deal with his ignorant and uninformed declarations.” He emphasizes his point by slapping one of his pamphlets against his thigh. “Who knows? Perhaps if the two of you read enough, you might be able to stop embarrassing yourselves.”

"I must say that I’m surprised that Armand thinks so highly of true, revolutionary minds.” Murmurs of appreciation and agreement ripple through the crowd, but are quickly hushed by other guests, who are also pretending that they’re not listening in.

Maximin chuckles, “Of course, this gathering is more of a salon than a party, but I can see why you would be confused.” He reaches out and pats your hand. “Please don’t be embarrassed, I’m sure Armand will be able to explain the differences later, when he’s feeling better.”
“Unless, of course, he’s not actually sick.”

“It’s been weeks since anyone’s heard from the Baron de Marbo. Originally, I’d taken it as a blessing that we no longer had to deal with his ignorant and uninformed declarations. However, now I find myself face to face with his fiancee, who isn’t just ignorant, but a liar!”

“Your loyalty to Armand is commendable, and exactly the sort of thing we’re striving to bring to this troubled nation of ours.”

A small cheer goes up from some of the crowd.
“Of course, it’s a shame your loyalty is anchored to such mediocrity, but still...”

“Your cowardly fiance could have spent his time doing something useful, like echoing the views of his betters. Instead he chose to waste our time with calls to consider lesser, erroneous perspectives. We don’t need to tolerate this kind of intellectual and moral weakness. Both of you should do the right thing and skulk back to wherever you came from, in silence.”

Maximin pauses, his eyes sweeping the room for a moment. “But please, I must trouble you with a question of my own.”

There's something special about riding a horse. Being in a carriage, you inspire mystery, as you wind through the streets hidden from view. The public is left to wonder about your identity, your appearance, your intentions.
However, on a horse, you're holding yourself up on a living pedestal for all the world to see. People stare, and children point. You inspire awe, by being so public.
It's enough to make you feel like a princess in a fairy tale. Hopefully, it's one of the nice fairy tales. Not the ones with all the torture.
You hold onto Alex's firm waist, thinking about everything that's happened.
