"The Crown?" Alex asks, surprised.
"Really?" He asks with a note of surprise, before he merrily clinks his glass against your own. "Yes! To the Queen, the King, and all their descendants!"
"I certainly can't say no to that." He laughs as he merrily clinks his cup against your own. "To his Majesty, and to us!"
"To the people?" Alex asks, surprised.
(You have gained a little favor with Alex)
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown by quite a bit)
You sip the champagne, to find that it's surprisingly good. It must have cost a fortune.
"Do you like our spoils of battle? I might have... appropriated the champagne from some fearsome brigands who had looted a winery a few months back."

"When we were first called to hunt the theives down, the Count in charge of the winery was shockingly inhospitable towards us." He says with such a carefree air that you can only assume that this nobleman was completely unbearable.
Alex is already waiting for you outside, astride a brilliant white horse. Everything on his uniform is perfectly in place, and the leather polished to a mirror's shine.
"I'm glad you agree! In the grand scheme of things, the Count didn't lose much, and he recieved a simple lesson in how to treat those supposedly beneath him."
"I swore an oath to the King and Queen, not to wretches like that Count. If he cared so much about lost property, he should have been more polite to the people risking their lives to help him."
He laughs "While I appreciate your good taste, there's no need to be greedy. The Count has learned his lesson, and we have fine champagne. Everyone is better off than they were!"
You uncork the champagne with a jolly pop and carefully pour yourselves two tin cups of fine wine. You pass his cup up to him, and he holds it aloft in one hand.
"Yes, I think I am alright." He says. "I can finally put it behind me, and think of the future."
"I was inspired by a feeling, Yvette. Today I woke up feeling more like myself than any other day in my life.
While you can see his face from your position, you can hear the frown in his voice. "Happy with what? Using my horse for personal business?"
"I suppose they won't, but my superiors already have their hands full with civil unrest and safeguarding their own careers, so I don't think they'll mind all that much."
(You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
"Madame, you look far too beautiful to be walking the streets. May Joseph and I assist you?"
"Besides, my unit's been stationed in Paris for far too long, and I think Joseph needed the exercise." He gives the horse an affectionate pat on the side of the neck.
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
(You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
As Joseph starts to slow down, you look around and realize that you've arrived at your destination.
Alex gets down off the horse first, and holds out his hand to you.
Without warning, you leap from the saddle into his arms.
You take his hand, and he gently helps you down from the horse. The gesture reminds you of a different time, a more chivalrous age.
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
Alex stops to tie Joseph to a hitching post, and then the two of you head inside.
"I was hoping you'd say that." Alex says with a grin, as he adjusts himself further forward in his saddle.
Alex manages to catch you, despite his face being frozen in a mask of shock. A passing crowd favors you with some whoops and cheers, and Alex replies with a theatrical wave.
"I don't know if this means that you truly trust me, or if you're simply toying with me. Either way, I'm enjoying it."
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
He pauses, lost in thought for a moment before saying "Thank you for asking."
He reaches back and squeezes your hand. "Which is thanks to a certain someone I know."
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown by quite a bit)
"You're right!" He agrees, before merrily clinking his galss against your own. "To the people of France, and the happiness they deserve."
"Absolutely not. The Crown has given me success and freedom. I can never turn my back on that. Viva la Roix!" He grumbles as he weakly clinks his cup against your own.
(You have lost some credibility)
He looks somewhat taken aback. "I'm not joking. I was hoping to offer you a ride tonight."
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution by quite a bit)
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution by quite a bit)
"That's a great point, Yvette. To the Crown! Viva la roix!" He laughs as he merrily clinks his cup against your own.
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown by quite a bit)
"Absolutely not. The people and their needs have gone unheard for far too long in this country. To them!" He grumbles as he weakly clinks his cup against your own.
(You have lost some credibility)
With a tug of the reins, Joseph takes off down the street at a reasonable clip.
"After days of tracking these theives down, the most incredible thing happened when we found the wine."
"All at once, the laels fell off, and we couldn't remember who to return the wine to!"
He grumbles to himself "Mon dieu, I've met people that spent their whole lives scrounging in the dirt with better manners than that man."
"Yvette, don't be ridiculous!"
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Montgolfier's: Yesterday, there was a hot air balloon launch on the lawn of the palace at Versailles. The public is absolutely fascinated by these new machines, though you remain unconvinced.
These balloons, invented by the Montgolfier brothers, were richly decorated with the King's heraldry. Apparently it was quite a sight.

In fact, the King himself decided at the last minute, to ride along and ascend in the first balloon. Witnesses have lovingly described the King as 'standing astride the heavens like a demigod of antiquity'. The Montgolfiers have been showered with praise for both their achievements towards the sciences, and to the prestige of the royal household.

The launch itself went extremely well, but apparently that was the problem. Those attending couldn't help but notice that despite all of the King's royal privileges, special seating, and resplendent symbols, all of the event's focus was on the balloons themselves. The King, who already struggles with asserting himself, put on a spectacle that he was not the center of.

(The Crown has lost a little power)
(The Bourgeoisie has gained some power)
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

(The Crown has gained some power)
(The Bourgeoisie has moved a little closer to the Crown)
Perhaps royal traditions shall be eclipsed by this swell of science and innovation.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Music to Your: Music to Your Ears
"I suppose it is..."
"Yvette Decaux. Charmed, I'm sure."
"Yvette Decaux, reporter for Le Trompette Du Peuple."
"Yvette. Just Yvette."
"Approach the Church. They've been sponsoring composers since time immemorial."
"The Bourgeoisie are the best choice. They have ample wealth, and a willingness to explore new ideas."
"Moniseur, I must say that such questions are beyond my experience. I simply don't know."
"I wouldn't call two men threatening the virtue of each other's mothers music."
"Do you often sneak up on unsuspecting women?"

You decide to spend the day walking alongside the river. Halfway through your walk, you notice the sun hitting the water just right, lending brilliant light to the colorful ships and boats. It's a chance moment that looks as beautiful as a painting. 

You pause to lean against a railing to just take it all in.
Nearby, you watch a small private ferry bump into a lavish pleasure craft, igniting a stream of insults and violent oaths from the pilots of the two crafts.
"As chaotic as it seems, even this everyday conflict has a familiar rythm, order, and tempo. Just like music."
"Ah yes. Angelos Strassner, at your service, madame." He says, gesturing to himself.
"Ah! So you hear it too!" He says, voice still earnest, yet analytical. You're a touch surprised by his earnestness.
(You have gained a little credibility)
"I'm charmed to meet you as well, Madame Decaux."
"Le Trompette Du Peuple, as in the newspaper? I actually read that one." He laughs. "Their social columns always have something absolutely fascinating in them."
"Well, 'just Yvette', it's a pleasure to meet you."
"We spoke of music earlier, and I just realized that you may be able to help me. I have a decision that's left me feeling quite divided."

"I recently finished a new composition and I'm looking for a sponsor who could help me fund the first performance of it, but I don't know which to pursue. As of right now, the two groups with the most influence in the world of music are the Church and the Bourgeoisie."
"I'm certain my composition will bring popularity to whomever sponsors it, but I don't know who would be best for me."

Just as the ferryman pulls his oar out of the water to hit someone, you notice that you're not watching this scene alone. A man in black and white, with a curious brooch on his jacket is watching the same scene as yourself.
"What are your thoughts on the subject?"
"That's quite the good point." He nods along, coming around to your idea. "I'll start petitioning my associates in the Church, posthaste!"
"That's quite the good point." He nods along, coming around to your idea. "I'll start reaching out to my associates in the Bourgeoisie, posthaste!"
"Really? You know nothing at all?" He asks, sounding quite disappointed.
(You have lost some credibility)
He pauses to check his pocket watch. "Ah it seems that I should be about my business! Enjoy the rest of your day, Yvette."
Angelos excuses himself with a quick bow, and you are once again alone.
(The Bourgeoisie has gained a little power)
(The Church has gained a little power)
You look out, upon the river, and it seems that the conflict between the two boatsmen has been resolved without anyone being sent to the bottom of the river.
"Beautiful music, isn't it?" He asks quietly.
Experimentally, you close your eyes and just listen to the noises of the city. Perhaps you're imagining things, but it does almost sound musical.
"There's a musicality to all things. After all, music is mathematics, and mathematics can be found everywhere in the natural world."
"I simply cannot agree." He says, with a surprising confidence for such an odd statement.
"If I've suprised you, I assure you it was unintentional,"  he replies, his voice still level and quiet.

"I simply didn't want to interrupt the proceedings going on before us." He gestures out to the river. One of the ship pilots is trying to jump over to the other boat, but is in the process of being restrained by his own crewmates.
(You have lost a little credbility)
"It's a hobby of mine to seek out new sounds and see if they could be incorporated into my next composition."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Naval Archite: Naval Architecture
"I know the city well enough, I can at least help you search for it."
"Monsieur, I have frankly no idea."
"I don't, but perhaps we can find someone who does know?"
"I'm afraid that I'm still a little shaken, monsieur."
"It was nothing. I'm sure I'll be fine."
"My word, what has you in such a hurry?"

You decide to spend the day walking around in a fountain square, simply to cool off. It's sweltering outdoors, stifling indoors, and most people are just trying not to lose their tempers with eachother. You swear you can see steam rising up from off the fountain.

At the moment, you're walking easy circles around the fountain, giggling to yourself at a pack of children playing in it. The situation becomes even more amusing when their parents notice, and desperatly try to shepherd them out of it.

It doesn't work, and at least one adult falls in during the chase.

Without any hesitation, he pulls a handercheif from his pocket, soaks it in the fountain, and presses the cold damp cloth to your forehead. 

You have to admit, it helps with the shock and heat at least.
"I'm in a touch of a hurry, and I must have stopped paying attention to where I was going."
"Do you know where I can find the naval department?"
"Capital! Let us be off. Our mission begins anew!"
"I see. How troubling."
"A capital idea! Let us find someone knowledgable, post-haste!"
Combining your knowledge of the city and his map, you manage to locate the naval office, and hurry towards it.
"It seems that I'll have to continue my efforts on my own. All the same, I appreciate your honesty."
After spending a few minutes asking around, you find someone who seems more familiar with the area, and he gives you some directions. Together, the two of you hurry towards your destination.

A few blocks later, you find yourself outside the stately building. It doesn't look nearly as nautical as you would imagine a naval office to be.

There should simply be a stronger nauticual theme.
Your street theater is suddenly interrupted by a man hurtling around a corner and colliding with you. You manage to keep your balance, but are still a little disoriented.
(You have gained a little credibilty)
With that, he disappears into the crowd, and you return to your day spent trying to overcome the stiffling heat.
"Thank you again for your help, madame!" He says with a deep bow. "If not for you, this entire journey would have been a complete waste."
(You have gained a decent amount of credibility)
He departs inside, and you're left to your own devices. It's more than likely that you'll return to the fountain square to spend the rest of your day trying to overcome the stiffling heat.

"The fortresses are leaking terribly, you see. We made them out of wood, which is apparently quite appetizing to all of the sea worms in the port. It was probably something that should have been looked into before we made them."
"Oh! My apologies, madame!" The man sputters as he collects himself.
"Are you hurt, at all?"
"Oh, I'm so sorry to hear that!"
"Oh, that's the spirit!" He replies with an encouraging smile.

He straightens up and adjusts his disheveled specatacles. "You see, madame, I'm lost in the city and terribly late for a meeting. I normally work on the coast in La Rochelle, and this is my first time in Paris."

"I had originaly planned to orienteer my way across the city with my handy compass." He says, holding up a well polished brass compass, and a paper map of Paris. "But that plan seems to have been less effective than I'd have hoped."

He stops to check his pocketwatch, then sighs. "I'm supposed to be meeting with a draftsman to get the plans for the sunken fortresses at Cherbourg, but at this rate I'll miss my appointment at the naval department entirely."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Necessary Hon: Necessary Honesty
"I have nobody else to talk to."
"Indulging in curiosity. What are you doing?"
"Merveilleux, tell me what you know about the military."
"Really? Please tell me what you've learned about the revolution."
", but I'm simply not in the mood for gossip."
"Well, I'm always looking to meet someone and learn something new."
Fountain, doing some wanderings to see if you can find some new info.
Perhaps you'll be able to find something that Pierre would find valuable.
He chuckles. "While I'm afraid to inform you that I'm very busy at the moment, I suppose you can still join me."

"Right now, I'm studying a four hundred year old church to determine why it hasn't fallen down, despite a complete lack of renovations in the last hundred years. The priest has insisted to me that this is a miracle, but I can't imagine the Lord using miracles to reward a century of shoddy maintainance."

He gestures to the chair across from him. "Please take a seat." 

You do so and settle in, finally feeling a little more comfortable in the situation.
Without breaking eye contact from the document, he waves over to a waitress and orders you some coffee.
When it arrives, you take a sip. It is coffee sweet, strong, and hot. It's also quite invigorating.
(You have lost a level of exhaustion)

"Judging from your interest in the affairs of strangers, I imagine you also have a thirst for gossip, yes?"

While this is true, you're not sure if he had to put it quite so cynically.
"To that end, would you prefer to learn something interesting about the military, or the revolution?"
"As I suspected." He sighs. "Here's what I've learned."
"As I suspected." He sighs. "Here's what I've learned."
Perhaps you'll be able to find something that would bring you a little closer to finding out what happened to Armand.
For the first time, he looks up at you from his document. "It seems that I've rudely misjudged you. My apologies."

Carefully, he sets aside his work and engages you in earnest. His full name is Christophe Von Mayendorf, and he's an architect visiting from Vienna. He's studying the oldest buildings in Paris, in order to learn techniques for designing structures that can withstand the tests of time, both physically and aesthetically.

He spends the next few minutes detailing some gossip concerning the revolution. It's certainly an interesting story, but something about the whole exchange feels rather untoward. It feels so heartless and mercantile.

He spends the next few minutes detailing some gossip concerning the military. It's certainly an interesting story, but something about the whole exchange feels rather untoward. It feels so heartless and mercantile.
(You have gained a decent amount of credibility)

The two of you talk for a little longer, but the conversation eventually winds down. He pauses to check his pocketwatch, and says "I'm sorry, but I must head to the Bastille. If I am to study it, I will need to do so before I lose the the sunlight."

(You have gotten a peice of Shocking Revolution Gossip)
(You have lost some credibility)

(You have gotten a peice of Shocking Military Gossip)
(You have lost some credibility)
"Au revoir, madame." He says, before he packs up all of his materials, and drops some coins on the table for your respective refreshments.
He departs, and you decide to leave as well, before it gets too dark.

You survey the area and everyone here already looks like they have someone to talk to, which is concerning. Approaching a stranger is easy, approaching a group of them by yourself is far more daunting.
(You have gained a little credibility)
Curse the audacity of these strangers! How dare they have friends?
You spot a man who has just taken a seat, by himself, at the table of a nearby cafe. He's spread out a great sheet of paper, and weighed down the corners with empty saucers.

You approach him, but he doesn't acknowledge you at first, and appears totally lost in this document. From the looks of it, it's some kind of diagram or blueprint, but the exact details are lost on you.

"Ah hello madame," He says without looking up. His accent is foreign, but you're unable to place it. It sounds either Austrian or Hungarian. 

"My name is Christophe, if that's what you were going to ask."
"What business is it that you have here?"
"Ah, so you want something from me." He says with half of a smile.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Old Wounds.as: "They sound like cowards."
"They were too weak to stop it. They were afraid."
"How did Thérèse feel?"
"Antoine, something's bothering you, and you'll feel better if you say it now."
<Give him some space>
"Are you sure you should be drinking that much?"
"Reach out to the Church, they understand the needs of the people."
"What about the Military? They have the guns, after all."
"The Bourgeoisie resent the nobility, their priveleges and titles, just like you."
"Honestly? She's wonderful."
"She's useful enough, if a little irritating."
"Did your family keep any servants on staff?"
"You know what, Camille? I think he is, in his own way."
"He can seem that way sometimes, but mark my words. He's a threat."

After the rendezvous, Antoine offers to walk you home. Early on in the night, you were celebrating some of his increased influence among the revolutionaries, but you also noticed that he was taking intermittent sips from a small bottle of liquor. He's obviously had quite a bit to drink today.
Actually, now that you think about it, you've noticed that Antoine rarely drinks at all. Something is bothering him, and his normal fiery responses are few and far between.
"Back in Blérancourt, I was seeing someone else. Her name was Thérèse."
"This morning, I started thinking about the past, and I think my mind's been going in circles ever since." He nods, starting to open up.
"We were nineteen, and in love. Her father was most powerful man in town, and didn't approve of her daughter seeing a young playwright with a penchant for causing trouble."
"Still, we were inseperable. After a little while, I proposed to her, and she went to ask her father for permission. She was so excited."

"There was some family business that needed to be taken care of, so I was out of town for a little while. Every day, I dreamed of coming home. I ran through every scenario in my head. I thought of marrying Thérèse right away. I thought of how I'd have to convince her father to let her follow her heart. I thought of us having to steal away together in the middle of the night."

"By the time I got back, Thérèse was already married to someone else, Emmanuel Thorin. Emanuel was from an important family in town. Thérèse's father didn't just overrule her wishes, he used her like a bargaining chip."
"Nobody bothered to step in on her behalf, not even my own family." He growls through his teeth.
"Agreed. I certainly screamed as much at them when I found out." He snorts derisively at the memory. "If anger was fire, I would have burned all of Blérancourt to cinders."
"That's the cowardice I'm talking about." He snarls. "They didn't even try! They just let yet another important man have his way with other people's lives."
"When I went to see her, she was distant and evasive. I think she felt too guilty to even speak to me properly."
A few minutes later, your conversation reaches a long, silent lull.
(You have gained a some favor with Antoine)
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
"Of course, I went nearly mad with rage. So, I did what any full blooded man in my situation would do."
"I stole my family's silver, a pair of pistols, and rode for Paris."
"So excited." He says again, taking a swig from the small bottle of liquor he's been nursing throughout the night.
"When I came home, I was greeted by something else entirely."
"It was a good life for a few days before I was arrested." He says wistfully. "The kind of freedom I needed to clear my head. To align my principles."
"While I was locked in a reformatory, I had a lot of time to think about what, exactly, made me so angry."
"It wasn't just my romances being foiled, or someone I loved being hurt, it was the thought that this was happening all over France. That it's still happening every single day."
He starts, as if he didn't realize that you were talking to him. "Hmph! I drifted off didn't I?" He replies.
"Why are we so content to dine on the table scraps of powerful, selfish men? Why are we so content to let them carve up our lives?"
"Of course, I never blamed her. I know how much it must have hurt, which only made my anger worse."
He pauses for a while, searching his memories. "It's funny. You're the first person I've told this story to, who cared about how she felt."
After taking a moment to regain his calm, Antoine turns to you and says, "Did you know some of our fellow revolutionaries heard about our direct action with the posters? They called it inspiring."
"In fact, those same people have placed me in charge of secretly reaching out to some of the other causes in the city, to build alliances on behalf of the Revolution."

"Of course, while I understand the value of forming alliances, I also find the whole affair distasteful. I can't bring myself to begin the kinds of intrigues that have turned the King's courts into a festering pit of petty schemes."
"What do you think? Who should we reach out to?"
He looks at you askance. "The Church? You really think I should reach out to those agents of a foreign monarch, who support the king, and strut about like petty nobles?"
He looks at you askance. "The Military? You really think I should reach out to the King's personal attack dogs?"
He looks at you askance. "The Bourgeoisie? You really think I should reach out to those money-hungry pigs?"

You stay silent, but upbeat. You hold his hand, and try to create space for him to speak his mind. While he doesn't say anything immediately, you can tell that he appreciates the effort you put forward.

After a long pause, he rubs his chin thoughtfully. "Perhaps, you're right. While the priests in the cities are self centered and corrupt, the ones in the country-side might care about our cause. They're also experienced in rousing the common people to action."

He rubs his chin thoughtfully. "Perhaps, you're right. Most of their ranks are made of desperate common men, and they're a group founded in stern discipline. We'd just need to convince them to fight for a righteous cause, instead of a tyrannical one."
He rubs his chin thoughtfully. "Perhaps, you're right. In the end, they're common people just like us, and their clout would be useful."
(The Bourgoeisie have moved towards the Revolution by a decent amount)
(The Military has moved towards the Revolution by a decent amount)
(The Church has moved towards the Revolution by a decent amount)
You talk for a little bit longer, until the two of you arrive at your house. As always, Camille is waiting for you on your doorstep. "Bonsoir Madame!"
"Oh, and who is this?" Antoine asks.
"Monsieur, I am Camille, Madame Decaux's maid-of-all-works." Camille replies cheerily.
"What do you think of her, as your servant?" Antoine whispers to you.
"How and why I pollute my body is my business." He snaps at you.
"I'm glad to hear that. I always like to know that someone appreciates the people that do so much for them."
"That's a pity." Antoine replies with a stony expression. "I assumed you'd be more appreciative of someone who does so much for you."

"My family used to keep several, in fact. However, I've abandoned the practice. I can't fight for liberty while asking someone else to make my bed. Though, I must admit that Camille is quite charming, in her own way."
"I've never blown glass, I've never laid bricks, I've never made a boat..." Camille continues to list off tasks she's never done in your service.
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
"I've never blown glass, I've never laid bricks, I've never made a boat..." Camille continues to list off tasks she's never done in your service.
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
"I've never blown glass, I've never laid bricks, I've never made a boat..." Camille continues to list off tasks she's never done in your service.
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
"Bonne nuit, mesdames." Antoine says with an upwards nod, and walks away into the night.
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
"He seems nice."

You head upstairs to your room, your mind swirling the with night's revelations. You wonder if Antoine could have been different, or if he was always fated to become the man he is today. It takes a long time for you to get to sleep tonight.

You head upstairs to your room, your mind heavy the with night's revelations. You wonder if Antoine could have been different, or if he was always destined to become what he is today. Tossing and turning in bed, it takes a long time for you to get to sleep tonight.

"Of course, that name does't really make much sense. I cook, clean, get groceries and kill vermin, but there's lots of stuff I don't do. I've never done any carpentry, or locksmithing..." Camille trails off, as she starts to list more and more jobs she hasn't done.
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
(You have gained some favor with Antoine)
He sighs. "I'm sorry, you haven't done anything wrong. I'm just thinking about the past."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Persons of Qu: "Ah, but my outsider nature is what makes me work. I wasn't born into this, I want it more than anyone else."
"That's a rude imposition to be making sir. Are you questioning the choices of our host?"
"I believe Elisabeth can vouch for me."
Noticing a particularly intriguing group of guests on the other side of the room, you begin to approach them.
However, your intercepted by an older man with a haughty air about him.
Suddenly, he breaks into a gentle smile. "Now now, Madame Decaux. Let's not allow ourselves to say anything that we might not be able to take back."

You manage to chat with him for a little while and actually find him to be a decent conversationalist. You notice that he's looser than most, probably rattled by the fact that you didn't back down when he challenged you. It's remarkably easy to pull some easy gossip from him.
(You have gained a piece of Cheap Crown Gossip)
A short while later, he nervously excuses himself. You presume he's found someone else to harass over whether or not he feels that they belong here.

"... might be exactly what we need in a time like this." He admits. "So many voices are clamoring for our attention, and sometimes it feels damn near impossible to sift the worthy from the useless. Someone like yourself could be quite useful to us."
"... sounds like a waste of time. Why would anyone stop to consider the least desirable option?"
(You have gained a little credibility)
(You have lost some credibility)
"If you're going to impose yourself upon us, I advise that you invent an explanation better than that one."
With a curt nod, he excuses himself. You presume he's found someone else to harass over whether or not he feels that they belong here.
"Yvette Decaux, I presume?" He asks with an arched eyebrow. "I've observed you at several of these functions before, and I'm not certain that you understand what should be happening here."
"I am, of course, quite biased towards her." He admits. "She painted a portrait of my wife two years ago, you see."
(You have gained a little credibility)

"These are the persons of quality. They are the nobility, and the rightful rulers of France." He says, turning to gesture to some of them with his wineglass as the party guests mingle in their finery.
"Of course, you are not part of this group yet, no matter what your fortuitous marriage might promise in the future." He says, eyeing your engagement ring.
"What, exactly, do you feel that you have to offer these esteemed persons?"
"Outside perspective..."
He scowls at your rebuttal, and eyes you more carefully.
"Ah, yes. I'd heard rumors that you and Madame Le Brun were close, but I wasn't sure it was true. It's nice to know you've earned the approval of someone with such good taste."
(You have gained a little peril)
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Pierre's Info: “What do you know?”
“You have my condolences, Pierre. That sounds difficult.”
“If I’m your only real source, shouldn’t I be getting paid more?”
“If I’m your only real source, shouldn’t I be getting paid more?”
“Before we get into that… why did you need me, specifically, to do this?”
“But, of course Pierre! This has been a delight.”
“Pierre, this is just business.”
Pierre claps his hands together in delight, “Madame, it appears that you have done me a great service! With all of this gossip together, I can finally launch my most comprehensive social piece yet!”
“Now, I assume, you wish to know more about your beloved Armand, non?”

He hands you the paper, it’s an address. “The Guet Royal raided the studio a month ago and arrested everyone there. While supporting the king is certainly not a crime, some of this talk was getting violent, which the Crown can’t risk in times like this. Ever since then, the place has been abandoned. Go there, and you might find something that leads you to your Armand.”

“Journals like my own have always existed in one… unofficial capacity or another, but with the end of royal censorship, new papers are opening every day! The competition for readership, and for new information, has become ridiculous!” Pierre throws up his hands in exasperation.

“I can’t just print gossip that’s been sold to everyone else. My readers expect something unique in these pages, not the same unoriginal tripe bandied about in those… lesser papers.”

You find yourself slightly taken aback by the sincerity in Pierre’s voice.
“I needed you because most of my sources have taken their business to other… less esteemed publications.”
“Merci beaucoups, madame…” he sighs, pausing to inhale a heavy pinch of snuff. “But please, enough about my troubles, you are here to learn of your fiance, non?”

Pierre scowls at you for a fraction of a second, before breaking out into a wide and almost-sympathetic grin. “Madame, but if only I could! I would pay for your gracious insights with bars of silver, and fistfuls of rubies, as that is what they are worth!”

He gestures to his dilapidated and stained office. “However, while the pursuit of truth may make a man virtuous, it does not make him wealthy. The coins I give are all I can spare, as I need all that remains to keep the wheels of my press turning.”
While the empty liquor bottles laying on the ground make you doubt his honesty a little, you get the feeling that he isn’t going to budge on this.
“But please, enough about such ignoble matters, you are here to learn of your fiance, non?”
“I like to think we’ve made good business partners, non?”

“It may shock you to learn that your Armand managed to keep some rather… opinionated company.” Pierre says with the careful circumspection of someone severely downplaying the seriousness of a situation.
Pierre puts down his snuff box and favors you with a deep and theatrical bow. “Now you flatter me madame. Bone chance madame, and may God see fit to reunite you with your Armand in great haste.”
Pierre nods and grins, “But, of course, Madame! It is merely business, but I still hope it is good business. Adieu, madame!”
At the mention of God, Pierre makes the sign of the cross, but you’re pretty sure he did it backwards. “Adieu madame, and may our paths cross again!”
Pierre sighs and mops the sweat from his brow with a severely stained handkerchief. “To be honest madame, I am in a bit of a tough situation.”

“To put it simply, these compatriots of his are extreme nationalists. They don’t just want tax reform, they don’t just want a constitution, they want bigger changes for France, and don’t care what it takes to accomplish it.”

“There’s a studio in the seventh arrondissement where he and some like minded individuals preferred to discuss their plans for the country. Painters in the front, planning in the back.” Pierre starts scribbling on a piece of paper.
“These compatriots of his were royalists, but a more… dedicated kind. They felt that any kind of dissent was a violation of natural law, that sort of thing…”

He hands you the paper, it’s an address. “The Guet Royal raided the studio a month ago and arrested everyone there. The Crown looks down on that kind of thinking, after all. Ever since then, the place has been abandoned. Go there, and you might find something that leads you to your Armand.”

“Now, before you leave madame, I hope that you do not forget about me and my humble paper. I still find your social insights valuable, and I’m stilling willing to pay for anything you can bring to me.”

“There’s a studio in the seventh arrondissement where he and some like minded individuals preferred to discuss the proper course for the country. Painters in the front, planning in the back.” Pierre starts scribbling on a piece of paper.

When he realizes that he's not going to derive any further satisfaction from his conversation, he snorts in disgust and leaves. You sigh, and refocus your attention on the pair you were hoping to talk with earlier.

He narrows his eyes, and examines you more closely when you say that.

"He's tall, and handsome, with chestnut brown hair."

"Actually, could you help me find my fiance? He's supposed to be here."
"My fiance Armand is supposed to be here. Could you help me find him?"

"He's intelligent, wears a blue coat, and always has a book or pamphlet with him."

You sweep your gaze over the crowded tavern, and strain your ears for the sound of Armand's voice, but have yet to find anything. It's hard to walk around with all of your luggage, which only slows your progress further.

The other patrons don't look particularly happy with you either. You bump into yet countless patrons with your bags, and your searching is starting to give the impression that you're eavesdropping.

Just as you start to feel a little frustrated by this, the barmaid from before approaches you.
"Well, if he's funny then he should be popular with the patrons. I'll ask around for him, madame."
"A smart fellow like that shouldn't be too hard to notice."
"Oh, I'll definitely be on the lookout for him then!" The barmaid replies with a wink and a cheeky laugh.
"You just stay here, and I'll see what I can find."

She leaves your table to inquire with the other patrons about Armand. You're not sure if your description was enough to go off of, but she knows the place better than you do. 

Perhaps she'll have better luck.
She returns a few minutes later and gives you a shrug. "Madame, I'm sorry to tell you this, but I simply can't find your Armand anywhere."
She slips a piece of paper to you. You glance down and see a hastily written note.
"Oui, madame" She says with a curtsey.
She leaves you to your drink, and you take this time to examine your fellow patrons. Now that you're not taking up too much space, people seem to have lost interest in you.
You spend the next hour sipping your wine and taking in the room, but can't seem to find any trace of Armand, even the sound of his laugh.

She leaves you to your drink, and you take this time to examine your fellow patrons. Now that you're not taking up too much space, people seem to have lost interest in you.
You spend the next hour sipping your water and taking in the room, but can't seem to find any trace of Armand, even the sound of his laugh.
'Don't know what's going on. Patrons get upset when I mention your fiance. Even the owner won't talk.'
The Barmaid gives you a tiny shrug, but otherwise remains silent.

The Barmaid startles at your sudden forwardness, and you can feel the weight of eyes in the tavern scrutinizing you both. "Madame, please understand that I can't help you." She replies, a little too loudly.
You stare at her expectantly, hoping that she'll grasp your intent.
Understanding your implication, the Barmaid sighs, and picks up the note. She scribbles for a while.
"No madame, I believe your receipt has everything on it that we can put on it." She replies flatly.
She leaves you, and you take this time to examine your fellow patrons. Now that you're not taking up too much space, people seem to have lost interest in you.

You spend the next hour taking in the room, but can't seem to find any trace of Armand, even the sound of his laugh.

'I think your fiance has some powerful enemies. Don't know who. Don't know why. You'll have to get the rest from him.'

She gives you a quick curtsey and shuffles away, taking care to avoid any eye contact with you as she leaves.
Now that you're seated and sipping some of the house wine, you can see that the other patrons relax more around you. You're just another person stopping in for some rest and a quick drink.
The Barmaid sighs, and picks up the note. She scribbles on it for a while.

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Researching M: Researching Marcelle

You walk to a section of the city between the 3rd and 4th arrondissements. Viscountess Du Foix isn’t just a member of the aristocracy, she’s a woman who wields her title and noble privileges like a weapon.
There’s only one place to learn more about a woman like that...

During the second hour, you hear something about Marcelle’s father, the former Viscount du Foix. Apparently, Viscount Alfonso du Foix died a few years ago, and his funeral was so lavish that people are still discussing it today. 

Not exactly what you’re looking for, but it’s on the right track.
In the third hour, however, something piques your interest…
Apparently, Marcelle is rather obsessed with her clothing and personal appearance, even claiming to be a ‘fashion icon’.
Do you get to decide that about yourself? Isn’t that something that other people have to call you?

Marcelle’s vanity, demanding nature, and abrasive manner have led her into serious disagreements with several dressmakers and clothiers across the city. In fact, some of them simply refuse to do business with her anymore, though she claims the situation to be the other way around.

She would have to have been an unpleasant customer indeed, in order to drive a dressmaker away. Apparently, every order she places is completely unique, which means each item in her wardrobe would cost a fortune.
An idea strikes you, as quickly and surely as a lightning bolt.

Each of the vile Viscountess’ dresses would have cost far too much just to pay for it in coins. It would require a banknote. Any dressmaker that worked with Marcelle would have to know the name and address of her bank, in order to collect any payments.
All you had to do was find someone who had worked with her in the past, someone with a grudge. This would bring you one step closer to having the dark secrets of Marcelle’s money within your grasp.
Now you just need to find such a dressmaker… but where?
La Place Royale. The elegant square is packed today, with titled persons flitting this way and that, all eager to share the most scandalous social news of the day.

La Place Royale, the favored social spot for all the aristocrats in the city. The hub of all gossip, social news, slander, and scandal. If there was ever a telling secret, or a salacious rumor, this was the place to find it.
(La Place Royale is now available to visit in the Paris map)

You remember reading about this place over a year ago. It’s storied buildings are even more impressive in person. Elegantly dressed aristocrats strut about the gardens, stopping briefly to chat in hushed tones.
Without the benefit of a title, or an introduction, you can’t approach any of these groups directly. However, there’s nothing to stop you from overhearing things as you just ‘pass by’.
Staying on the absolute edge of conversations, you circle the square, pretending to be a traveller just admiring the apartments and gardens.
The first hour you spend on this task yields no information concerning Marcelle, but you do manage to hear some gossip that a certain newspaper might appreciate.
(You've obtained some gossip)
“Excuse me-”
“A moment, monsieur?” <Toss coin in hat>
“Just a second, can you-”
“Very well...” <Toss coin in hat>
“The Baron de Termes had a servant who quit for mysterious reasons. Know anything?”
"I'm looking for dirt on the Baron de Termes. I heard you might know something about their mystery servant."
“I should ask around in the marketplace…”
“Ugh, fine...” <Toss coin in hat>
Please, it will only take a mo-
“I’m just looking for the Baron de Termes mystery servant. Tell me and I’ll leave.”
"I can do this all day, just tell me what I want to know."
“The man on the corner feels like a good place to start.”
You walk the streets near the marketplace les Halles, and just… listen.

Porters, commoners, and servants bustle to and fro. They haggle, exchange coin for wares and occasionally lean in, to slyly share the most interesting and scandalous news of the day. The marketplace buzzes with activity, like a beehive. 

A man stands on a corner, reading the latest current events aloud from a newspaper to any passers-by willing to listen. Sometimes, people throw a coin into the hat placed at his feet.
“Joseph-Michel Montgolfier designing new flying balloon!”

The crier pauses to glare at you for a moment, before tapping his hat full of coins with his foot.

He returns to reading the headlines aloud to the crowd.
“Oh, merci madame!” The Crier says to you, feigning the appropriate amount of surprise. He folds up the newspaper and tucks it under one arm.
“Venetian arsenal in Corfu explodes, over 100 believed dead!”

The crier glares at your interruption with even greater intensity than before, and insistently taps his foot next to his hat full of coins on the ground.

With a deep breath, he continues proclaiming headlines.
(You have spent 1 Livre)
“How may I help you?”
“Oh, that is quite the mystery...”
“Oh, that is quite the mystery...”
“1st United States Congress declares new constitution to be in effect!”
Far from the nobility, this feels like the right place to inquire about Maximin’s mystery servant.
“What?” He shouts at you, a vein bulging at the corner of his forehead.
“Can you not see that I’m working?”
“Fine! If it will make you go away, then fine…” He angrily wads the newspaper up and tucks it under his arm.

Nobody’s asked about the mystery servant rumor for a while.” He pauses to think for a moment before continuing. “I remember my cousin tried to claim that this servant had committed murder in cold blood, but that turned out to be a pack of lies…”
“Fine! If it will make you go away, then fine…” He angrily wads the newspaper up and tucks it under his arm.
“Ah yes, I remember now! This servant is still in the city somewhere, working at a cafe. The good Baron threatened the owner to fire the servant, but the cafe owner wouldn’t budge.”
“Other than that, I am at a loss madame. Now, you must excuse me, as I must return to my work…” he unfolds the newspaper and returns to yelling to the crowd, and soliciting donations.
A mystery servant, who now works in a cafe. There must be over a hundred cafes in Paris, how are you supposed to find this servant?
While all of this knowledge is still fresh in your mind, you take out your journal and write down everything you’ve learned.
Deciding that you’ll need a little more information before you can track this person down, you decide to ask around the marketplace.

Delving into the marketplace proper, you talk with the various merchants, trying to learn a little more. It’s like fishing in a river for one particular fish. However, you walk away with one valuable piece of information.

Maximin’s mystery servant works at a cafe in Paris. They’re a woman with eyes that are different colors from each other. It’s a solid lead, but you still have a ways to go before you can use it to hurt Maximin.
Done for the day, you return home, to plan your next move.

You approach the man shouting newspaper articles to the nearby shoppers. Only a few people have stopped to actually listen to him. His clothes look like they’re of fine make, but they’re old enough to be in a state of disrepair.

All of the servants who suddenly left Maximin’s employ were men… except for this one. The mystery servant is a young woman.

Not only that, they were a woman with eyes that are different colors from each other. It’s said to be quite striking to behold.
You’ve never heard of anything like that before, but it’s certainly possible. If nothing else, it would make this person quite distinct. However, there are over a million people in Paris.
Knowing what they look like is simply not enough to track them down.

Acting on a hunch, you check in with the crier you saw reading the newspaper aloud earlier. Only a few people have stopped to actually listen to him. His clothes look like theyre of fine make, but theyre old enough to be in a state of disrepair.
“The Estates General approaches! Representatives from the third estate expected to demand changes to noble privileges!”

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Setting The S: “Here,” <Hand Over the Invitation>
“Madame Le Brun was unable to attend, but I’m here to deliver a painting on her behalf.”
“Umm… non, that shall not be necessary Camille.”
“Camille, that is a fantastic idea. Yes, you should.”
“Merci Camille, let’s head to the salon then.”
“Just to be sure, I want you to repeat the plan back to me.”

After going over the plan with Camille one more time, you step down from your carriage a few blocks away from the salon. A few passers by slow down to gawk at the elegant woman standing on the side of the street in her finery.
Let them stare.

Thankfully, you don’t plan on standing in their line. Instead, you approach the significantly shorter line reserved for the most honored guests, and wait there with Camille, using a well affected air of dignified impatience.

In a few moments you find yourself inside, and see the same doorman as before, who seems to be enjoying the opportunity to boss around anyone trying to enter the party.

He recognizes you immediately and leans away, like he’s expecting you to bite him. You consider it.
“Invitation, Madame?” he asks suspiciously.

He looks at you and frowns, then makes a great show of inspecting the invitation for authenticity. He is looking for any possible reason to deny you entry. Eventually he sighs and admits defeat, placing the paper inside his coat.

“Ah, I didn’t realize that you were now running errands for the esteemed Madame Le Brun.” The Doorman says with a frown while inspecting the invitation for authenticity. 

Unable to find a reason to deny you entry, he stuffs the invitation into his coat.

“I am to follow you into the salon, with the painting. We are to pretend that this painting is a surprise gift from Madame Le Brun. Then we shall use this painting to expose that most terrible Baron!”
“Before we leave, shall I ruin their hors d’œuvres and wine?”
Oui, madame! Camille bobs up and down as she attempts to curtsey while carrying the massive painting.
“You may enter, Madame.”
“However…” he starts, a grotesque smile manifesting on his face. “I must inform Baron Maximin of your arrival, and Madame Le Brun’s most generous gift.”

Camille follows you out of the carriage a few moments later, then reaches inside and retrieves the painting, covered in a sheet.

She wobbles back and forth under both the weight, and the awkward bulk of the painting.
As he turns to leave, another guest walks up and presents his invitation. “I am Monsieur Antoine Joseph Gorsas, journalist and art critic,” the man states flatly and impatiently.
“Oh, excusez-moi Monsieur, I was just leaving to-”
“No, you weren’t,” the critic interrupts, growing less amused by the moment.
“Pardon?”

“The line here is very long, and we’ve waited a long time. You will stay here, check our invitations, and let us in. There’s no reason to delay.” The Monsieur Gorsas says, raising his voice just loud enough for the crowd to hear him. Various murmurs of discontent ripple up and down the line.

“Oh, je suis désolé, monsieur” the Doorman apologizes, frantically darting his eyes between you and the increasingly agitated crowd, trying to figure out a way to leave and warn his master of your arrival.
You don’t give him an opportunity to do so. Instead you walk into the party. Camille follows in tow, only pausing to make rude faces at the Doorman.
Your revenge starts now.
“I must say, I’m amazed that you’ve already moved onto Le Brun. After the last party, we all assumed your tastes were more… pious.”
“I must admit that this is most surprising. However, it makes sense that you would move on from the young Corporal for something more… fair.”
“Don’t worry madame, I’ve got it!” she cheerily assures you.
“It does make wonder though. Does the Madame Gazel know you’re doing this for Madame Le Brun? Or did you find her too dreary, and just move on?”
It takes a second to realize what he’s talking about, but once you do, your first instinct is to slap the smug grin off of his presumptive, leering face.
However, for better or for worse, your reason wins out. You refrain from hitting him, and maintain your cover by chuckling dryly, as if he was actually funny.
Even if his rude implications about you and Ludovico are correct, he could still be polite enough to keep his implications to himself.

"What? Are you ok? Do we need to contact the watch? Do we need to form a mob?" Camille asks, suddenly spewing a torrent of both her own concern and increasingly concerning solutions to your problem.
You narrow your eyes at him, and clutch the book as tightly as you can.
You narrow your eyes at him, and clutch the book as tightly as you can. He glances around and notices all the people watching him. They're too scared to intervene, but they're still witnesses.
The gunshot is loud, almost impossibly so. You look down, and see blood running from your chest, before you lose your footing, and topple over in the street.
Slowly your vision grows darker, and darker, until nothing but blackness remains.

Slowly, carefully, he takes a step away from you.

"You're a bold one madame, I'll give you that." He says, wagging his finger.
"Just remember, everyone's lucky until the day they aren't." He makes a throat slitting motion before he hurries away and disappears into an alley.
Heart pounding, you manage to reach your home without any further incident, and Camille is there, waiting for you. "Bonsoir Madame!" She announces with her usual cheeriness.
"Will you at least give it a try? If not, I won't pester you about this. The story itself ins't important."
"How was your night with Father Sidotti?"
"Right now, I feel like the Crown might be the best choice."
"I simply don't know who to choose."
"Right now, I think the Revolution might actually be the right choice."
"You're right! The Crown has ruled with the Pope's assent for centuries. There's no reason for us to turn our backs on them now."
"The Revolutionaries? Are you sure? They haven't always expressed the best attitudes towards the Church."
"You're right! The Crown has ruled with the Pope's assent for centuries. There's no reason for us to turn our backs on them now."

"You're right! There are people starving in the streets. There has never been a more important time for us to help the poor and the downtrodden. I'll recommend to my superiors that we throw our support behind the Revolutionaries."
"The Crown? Are you sure? France is already in such a poor state. Perhaps this is the right time for a change."

"You're right! There are people starving in the streets. There has never been a more important time for us to help the poor and the downtrodden. I'll recommend to my superiors that we throw our support behind the Revolutionaries."

Relaxing at the party, you feel more comfortable with your new life than before. Sipping from your recently acquired glass of wine, you notice a fresh batch of hors d'oeuvres being brought out from the kitchen.

This feels right. You could get used to this.

Suddenly, you feel someone barge into you, sending you reeling a few steps. While you manage to catch your balance on a nearby table, your chest feels wet, and your wineglass now appears to be empty.

Oh no.

With a mutter of half hearted retorts, the pair skulk away, much to the delight of those present. Your dress may be in worse condition than when you started, but at least you got to have some fun at the expense of those who deserve it.

With narry a backward glance, the two leave, giggling to themselves.

Looking around at the rest of the guests at the party, hoping to find some sort of aid, you can tell that you're being studiously ignored.
With a mutter of apology, the pair depart and leave you alone. The crowd takes their focus off of you and returns to the party.

Her drunk friend decides that now would be a good time to chime in. "What's wrong? It's not like I made that dress look any worse."

You hear a few people in the crowd chuckle at this clumsy barb.

(You have lost some credibility)
The room feels palpably quieter as the two of them stare at you in disbelief.
Then, they start to laugh.

"What are you, a child?" The inebriated friend manages to ask. You can hear a few chuckles from the crowd around you.

(You have lost a little more credibility)
Eyes frowning, mouths agape, the pair just stares at you in shock.

Looking down, you see an enormous wine stain down your front.

(Your outfit has lost some novelty)

Turning around, you see two women, one of them is obviously deep in their cups. The other appears to be trying to prevent her friend from embarassing themselves too much. 

"Sorry about the stain, we were just leaving." The sober one apologizes half-heartedly.
"Why did we stop? Where are we going?" She slurs, looking confused.

Surprised by your patience and mangnanimity, they get some water and help you blot at the stain before it dries completely. It's enough to get rid of most of the stain, but it's still noticable to those who look for it.

(You have gained a little credibility back)

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Stranger and: “Camille, did you know about this?”
“Looks like we both got lucky today.” (-25 Livre)
“Who was Marie-Jeanne? How well did she know Armand?”
“Nothing yet, Camille. Nothing yet.”
“Who was Marie-Jeanne? How well did she know Armand?”
“Nothing yet, Camille. Nothing yet.”
Back home, you finally pull the note and key out from under your stays. Unfamiliar handwriting written in rich, emerald ink.

‘Dear Armand,

I will always appreciate your commitment to our cause, and I know France will be better for it. However, our chance of being caught grows with every passing day. I will not waste ink painting terrible pictures of the consequences, as you are already familiar with them.’
“I was just about to start making lunch…” Camille says, pointing awkwardly at the stove.

“Know about what?” Camille asks, glancing between you and the bag of coins in your hands. “Was that Monsieur Armand’s? Why would he leave money in the house?”

She seems to be even more confused by all of this than you are.

Camille looks utterly shocked when you press the money into her hands. “Madame I can’t possibly take this, it’s too much, it’s too…” she trails off as she evaluates your expression, and composes herself a moment later.

(You have given away 25 Livres!)
“Madame, what’s going on?”
“I never asked anyone’s names, madame.” Camille admits, looking downcast. “So many of Monsieur Armand’s guests valued their privacy, that I wanted to give them a polite amount space.”
“Understood madame!” Camille replies cheerily. “Armand required his privacy as well, it’s no wonder the two of you were engaged.”
“Madame, what would you like me to do?”

“However...” Camille straightens up, tapping her finger on her chin. “There was a woman who came by more frequently than the other guests. She had brown hair, and a scar on her chin.
I remember her because she always wore a silver necklace, with the prettiest emerald in the center of it.
You look down at the green ink used the write the note to Armand. A connection?
“That’s all I can remember madame. Now… if I may ask, can I have the kitchen to myself? I’d like to start making your lunch.”

‘If fortune turns against us, then I want you to flee Paris entirely. I know you’ve objected to the idea before, but it’s the only way for you to stay safe. To aid in this, I’ve secreted a package under the loose floorboards beneath your stove. This key will open it.’

You look at the key. It’s still here, so Armand never received the note.
After a brief pause, Camille ventures “Madame, if I may ask, can I have the kitchen to myself? I’d like to start making your lunch.”

‘Your partner in conspiracy,

Marie-Jeanne’

You turn over the letter and find no additional writing, no additional context or explanation. 

Who is Marie-Jeanne? How long has Armand known her for? Is she one of the people he’d been writing back home?

Heading downstairs, you walk into the kitchen. It’s clean but cramped, and Camille keeps it well stocked with fresh produce. You find the stove, made of dark iron and standing on a set of clawed feet. 

Alone, on your hands and knees, you feel around until you find a set of loose floorboards.
You pull up the floorboards and fish around in the dark until you find a small wooden box, held shut by a padlock. You open it with the key you found behind the painting.
Inside the box you find a magnetic compass, a map of Paris with notes concerning when the guards change at every one of the city gates, and a leather bag heavy with coins.

You look inside the bag… that’s a lot of coins.

(You have gained 100 Livres!)
You look up from your sudden windfall to see Camille standing in the doorway to the kitchen. Her eyes are darting between you and the box in confusion.

Circling the party, you see an interesting group of people. The conversation is flying between them quickly and easily. The perfect place to obtain some gossip.

However, just as you start to approach them, you get stopped by a woman you've never seen before. "A moment of your time, if you please." She says, in a tone of voice that suggests that you don't actually have a choice.
"But I knew her husband Charles very well, and I suppose that's good enough for me."

She keeps talking with you, and seems genuinely curious about Madame Gazel. Which is good, because honestly you want her to be focusing as little attention on your as possible.
While you're happy to answer her questions, you don't want to miss your opportunity with the other group, so you politely excuse yourself.

Finally, you manage to get away from her and find that the group that you were originally trying to approach has already broken up, and scattered to the rest of the party. You curse your misfortune and wonder if there's anything else you can do tonight in order to salvage things.
Unfortunately for her, you've already pushed passed her, and continued on. You've wasted enough time as is.
You can feel her impotent anger radiating behind you, like standing with your back to a fire.
(You have gained a little peril)
You manage to reach your intended group right before they split up. You introduce yourself quickly, and keep the conversation flowing just long enough to get some interesting gossip.
(You have gained a piece of Cheap Bourgeoisie Gossip)
"Madame Decaux, I'm a little curious as to how you fit in with all of this." She continues, gesturing discreetly to the party of trendy and moneyed individuals all around you.

Soon, they disperse, and you find yourself cursing the woman who sought to test your patience.

Who does she think she is?
Of course you belong here. You belong wherever you can manage to get in. Otherwise, you wouldn't be there.
You sigh and rub your temples to prevent an oncoming headache. Once it subsides, you check to see if there's anything else you can do at this party.
"I must admit, that's quite good. I look forward to seeing the results of your efforts."
"Nice try, but not enough. Understand now that this circle is for the people who have already achieved greatness. You can take your fruitless grasping elsewhere."
(You have gained a little credibility)
She steps aside, like a sentry at a guardhouse, and you walk away. You try not to dwell on the baffling audacity of what just transpired.
(You have lost some credibility)

Just as you can feel a fiery retort burn its way from your mind to your lips, she's already turned and left. You don't know what's worse, the insult, or the fact that you still can't figure out what possessed her to just approach you, insult you, and leave.

Well, at least she left.

You maintan a diplomatically neutral facial expression, and take a deep sip of your wine. 

Here it comes. The lecture.

"The Bourgeoisie is a unique group, as we're the only one where one has to maintain their status, once they achieve it. The aristocracy are born into their titles and will keep them, no matter how poor they become, or how ineffectively their wield their powers. Members of the military are considered veterans for life."
"We're not like them. Every single day is a struggle to maintain our status. There can be no rest for us, because everything we do matters."
"Everyone here deserves to be here. Why do you?"
"Oh, really?"
"Pardonne-moi?" She manages to sputter out, and she frantically begins to formulate a retort.
"Madame Gazel?" She asks, eying you skeptically. "I haven't spoken with her much myself."
asdfasdf
"For liberty? I'll see what I can do."
"Antoine, I'm not ready to commit crimes for a man I've never met."
"Just tell me the problem, and I'll handle the rest."
"Excuse me? I don't work for you, Antoine."
"What, exactly, do you need me to do?"
As you walk around the party, sipping your wine, you notice Antoine is walking directly towards you. He look concerned.
He gently takes you by the elbow and leads you to a corner of the room, away from everyone else.

"While we may have gotten away unscathed, it appears that the printmaker who made the posters wasn't so lucky. One of his apprentices betrayed him to the archers, and now our friend is imprisoned in Château de Vincennes, and awaiting a very one-sided trial."
"Normally, I would do something myself, but I have reason to believe the archers have been told to keep an eye on me." He continues, eyeing certain guests at the party suspiciously.
"This man, Monsieur Clet, he has taken risks for us. It's time for us to repay the favor."
"Can you try to help him?"
"I knew I could count on you."
"Really, that's where you draw your line?" He asks, incredulous. "This man helped us. We should help him."

"Ugh... if you can't help then I'll find someone who can."

He takes a few moments explaining where Château de Vincennes is, and everything you'd need to know about the location. It used to be a fortress, but one half of it was converted into a prison, and the other half into a nunnery. Usually, it's used to hold criminals who the Crown consider a real threat, but doesn't want to abuse, yet.
"Yvette, something dire has happened, and there is something I will need you to do." He says in a low voice.
With dismissive gesture, he turns from you and stalks away, back towards the other party guests.
"I don't exactly what you can do for him, but it will do great things for the Revolution if we can show people that we defend those who aid us."
He bends low and kisses the back of your hand. "I'm sorry, but I should step away, before anyone gets suspicious. We have to keep this secret, for now."
With that, he turns from you and strolls away, towards the other party guests.
(Château de Vincennes is now available to visit in the Paris map)

He pauses to glower at you. "Fine, let me explain the problem first."
He sighs and nods. "Your caution is understandable."

(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
