The front of the building is the painting studio, the floors spattered with pigments, and still littered with the scraps of various art supplies. An ornate desk sits in the front of the room, near the door, with papers scattered all around it. A few finished canvases still remain on the walls, though it looks like a lot of the others were either seized or destroyed.

Tugging on the edges of your hood to make sure your face is hidden from view, you glance down again at the hastily scribbled address Pierre gave you in his office. In addition to your regular traveling clothes, you have a small bag hanging off of your shoulder, and a portable lantern with a flint.

Putting down your unlit lantern, you start checking the boards on the windows, seeing if any of them are loose. On the third window, you find one set of boards easily gives way, like it’s been pulled out before.

Someone else has been here.

With a crash and the sound of splintering wood, you can hear the door being kicked open.

“Halt, in the name of the king!” someone shouts into the building.
“You! Put your hands in the air! What are you doing here?”
“Lost, eh? That’s a good story.” He says, his voice even, but stern.
“Your… fiance?” He asks, incredulous for a moment. “You’re looking for your fiance, in the middle of the night, in a building ordered closed by the king?”
“Do you have any earthly idea how many times I’ve heard that?” He asks, his face switching to an expression of tired disapproval.
“In fact, it’s so good, that you can tell everyone down at the watch post all about it…”
He sighs and pinches the bridge of his nose. “Non, I don’t have the time for this. Come with me, we’re going to the watch post, and you’re going to explain this to someone who cares.”
“Come with me, we’re going to the watch post, and you’ll have plenty of time to come up with a better excuse as to why we found you in building ordered closed by the King.”

Leaning back and craning your neck to examine the roof, you see there’s a hole big enough for you to enter the building through, but you don’t have a ladder, or any way to get up there. For a moment you consider trying to enter the building next door, so you can drop down onto the roof, but it’s better to do this as quickly as possible.
Gingerly, you take down each of the boards, leaving them in a neat pile by the window to be put back later. Secrets are easier to uncover when nobody knows that you’re looking at all.

You carefully ease yourself through the window, making sure none of your clothes get caught on any exposed nails. Once inside, you close your eyes for a few moments, so they’ll adjust to the darkness faster.

Inside, the studio is even darker than you would have guessed. Between the boards on the windows, and the lack of lighting in the surrounding street, it’s nearly impossible to pick out any detail smaller than the walls and doors.

You carefully use a flint stowed in the base of your lantern to light it, then muffle most of the light with the hem of your cloak.
“Madame, I’d like to inspect the building first. You never know who’s taken up residence in empty places like this.”

Crouching as low as his sizeable frame will allow, Hansel advances towards the building with his hand firmly on the grip of his sabre. He glances inside the windows and tries the door, which appears to be have been nailed shut.

Eventually, he finds that some of the boards covering one of the windows are loose, quietly pries them off, and easily hops through the window into the building inside. You catch glimpses of him through some of the other windows as he scouts out the darkened interior.

Hansel gazes warily at the building before turning back to you. For a moment he looks like he’s about to object, but your mind is obviously made up. 

“Understood, madame. We go together.”
After what feels like an eternity, you see his hand emerge from the opened window and motion for you to approach. You hike up your skirts and quietly hurry across the street towards him.

You waited for sunset before you headed out, as it feels like these sort of things are better done under the cover of darkness. However, everything still feels too bright. Every hanging lantern, every candle-lit window, feels like an eye staring down at you.
When you get to the window, Hansel’s hands emerge from the darkness and grab you by the waist, easily helping you into the building.

The mercenary crouches down and places his hand on the grip of his sabre. You hike up your skirts, and get ready to follow him. On his signal, you quietly dash across the street together, watching for any movement in the windows as your approach.

Now that you’re closer, you can see that the door has been nailed shut. Wordlessly, you and Hansel start checking the boards on the windows, seeing if any of them are loose. On the third window, you find one of boards easily gives way, like it’s been pulled out before.

Someone else has been here.
You get Hansel’s attention, and he quietly takes down the boards, leaving them in a neat pile by the window to be put back later.

He enters the building first, his face frozen in a grim expression that almost makes you feel bad for any dangerous persons you might encounter.

Almost.

From your position outside, you peer into the gloom and watch Hansel examine the room for a few moments before he gives a satisfied nod, dropping his hand from his weapon. Returning to the window, he grabs you by the waist, and easily helps you into the building.

Now that you have a little more light, you can see that most of the furniture inside is broken, and enough things are missing to make you wonder how much the Guet Royal seized during their raid. It’s also only a matter of time before someone spots you and comes to investigate.
Your time is limited, where do you plan on searching for clues?

The entrance to the back room isn’t obvious and if Pierre hadn’t told you about it earlier, you might have mistaken it for a closet door. When you go to open the door, you notice that the latch has been torn off. Probably a casualty of the raid.

The stairs creak underneath your feet as you make your way to the second floor. The long table and scattered cutlery suggests that it was used as a dining area. A small fireplace occupies one side of the room, with a wide swath of ash spilling out of the fireplace and onto the floor. Above the fireplace itself, a painting hangs on the mantle.

Winding your way through the streets of the 7th arrondissement, you can’t help but think about how out of the way this place would have been for Armand. Yet, Pierre said that he was still a regular visitor. Despite yourself, you find your heart beating faster and faster as you get closer to the abandoned studio.

Inside, the studio is even darker than you would have guessed. Between the boards on the windows, and the lack of lighting in the surrounding street, it’s nearly impossible to pick out any detail smaller than the walls and doors.

You carefully use a flint stowed in the base of your lantern to light it, then muffle most of the light with the hem of your cloak.
Now that you have a little more light, you can see that most of the furniture inside is broken, and enough things are missing to make you wonder how much the Guet Royal seized during their raid.
Hansel steps in front of you and whispers. “Now that we have a light in here, it’s only a matter of time before someone spots us. I recommend we move quickly, madame.”
“Where should we look?”
Scanning the painting studio, you try to determine what you’ll investigate.

The desk by the door is so beautiful that it seems to clash with the rough practicality of the other furniture in the room. All of the drawers have been flung open, and papers have been scattered everywhere.

The paintings on the wall are all traditional historical pieces, exactly the sort of thing L’Academie exalts as ‘true art’. Judging by the stern faces and repeated images, you’re sure that the paintings are all meant to be some kind of political allegory, but you can’t really tell what of.

Inside, the back room is cramped, mostly occupied by a circular table with some small chairs. Various notes are pinned to the wall, and as you shine your lantern about, you notice a slight glimmer under the table.
What are you going to investigate in the back room?
You scan the second floor, deciding what to investigate.

Rounding a corner, you find yourself on an empty street, looking across the road at the studio. The windows of the small, two storey building have been boarded up, and there’s a charred hole in the roof. A sign nailed to the door reads ‘Closed! On orders of the King.’
You rummage through the papers, but it seems like everything useful has already been taken.
Looking at the paintings, you feel like you’ve learned something about the artists here, but nothing useful about Armand. You’ll have to search somewhere he would have spent a lot of time in.
You feel like you’ve learned everything you can from the paintings in this room.
You lean close to the notes on the wall, and squint to read them. None of them make any sense, as if they were written in another language, or some kind of code.
You bend down to investigate under the table, trying to find what caught the light of your lantern and glimmered at you from the dark.

You find a small scattering of coins. It appears that, at some point in the chaos, someone must have dropped their coin purse, and nobody noticed it. It doesn’t bring you closer to Armand, but you’ll never turn down free coin.
No. Wait. It’s just terrible handwriting.

You bend down carefully, making sure you don’t kneel in the large swath of ashes in front of the fireplace. A cold breeze blows at your back and you look up at the charred hole in the roof of the building. This fire must have gotten large enough to set a portion of the ceiling ablaze. It’s a miracle this building is still standing at all.

Whoever started this fire didn’t have time to do things properly, they just needed something burned.

Stepping over the ash in front of the fireplace, you gingerly take the painting off of its hook and examine it closely. It’s not as carefully detailed as some of the others in the building, but there’s a certain joyful energy to it. Whoever painted this genuinely enjoyed making it.

Eventually, you can deduce a meaning from the scratchings. All the notes are suggested readings, various books and pamphlets. They seem to cover a broad range of texts related to religious or political theory. The authors extend from France to the rest of the continent, and even the Americas.

Rounding a corner, you find yourself on an empty street, looking across the road at the studio. The windows of the small, two storey building have been boarded up, and there’s a charred hole in the roof. A sign nailed to the door reads ‘Closed! On orders of the King.’
While you’re sure this reading list is insightful, it won’t bring you closer to finding Armand.
You find nothing else of value under the circular table.

You pick through the ashes, finding fragments of leather and scraps of unburned paper. The writing on the paper is handwritten, not printed. It looks like a list of names. A membership list?

That’s when you spot it.
‘-and de Marbo’, written in familiar handwriting on a fragment of paper. Armand was here, perhaps in this very room. Maybe there’s something else connected to him nearby.
The rest of the unburned scraps look too small or unclear to provide you with any additional information.

It’s a dining scene, done in a reflected perspective intended to make the actual room feel larger than it really is. All the men and women in the picture are laughing, clinking glasses and looking merry. 

Even Armand.

Armand’s smiling face is looking back at you from the picture, a glass raised in mid toast, and a quill in his free hand. On one side of him is a man you remember from your last night together with Armand. The man is named Isaac. On the other side of him, is a young woman, with strawberry blonde hair, who you’ve never seen before. Her hand is on his shoulder.

You turn the painting back and forth looking for more details, until you hear something metallic shift. Flipping the painting over, you find a note tucked into the frame on the back of painting, along with a key. You don’t recognize the handwriting, but decide against taking the time to read the note now, while illegally trespassing in a condemned building. You carefully fold the note around the key and secret it under your stays.
You can’t help but grin with satisfaction. This is the lead you were looking for.

Quickly and quietly, you skulk to the window you entered the building through. Peering through the window, it seems like the coast is clear for now. You lever yourself out the window, and into the street.
Before you can step any further towards the closed building, Hansel steps in front of you.

“Ja, madame.” Hansel grunts as you give the signal to leave, leading you to the window you entered the building through. He effortlessly helps you out the window before following you out, scanning the street for witnesses.

Outside, you fastidiously put the boards back where you found them on the window. Your ears perk up at the sound of approaching footsteps, and you spot the reflection of lantern light off of nearby buildings. The Guet Royal are on there way, but as long as you keep moving, you should be gone before they arrive.
Without even a look back, you disappear into the dark alley you initially approached the studio from.
With a precious lead in your possession, and the authorities none the wiser, you vanish into the night.

Outside, he puts the boards back on the window where he found them. You can hear approaching footsteps, and spot the reflection of lantern light off of nearby buildings. The Guet Royal are on there way, but as long as you keep moving, you should be gone before they arrive.
“After you, madame.” Hansel gestures towards the dark alley you initially approached the studio from.
With a precious lead in your possession, your bodyguard at your back, and the authorities none the wiser, you disappear into the night.
This particular investigation has cost you some precious time.
(You have gained 6 Livres)
This particular investigation has cost you some precious time.
Glancing around, you don’t see anyone at all, as if the King’s notice somehow closed the entire street.
(You have gained some peril)
(You have gained some peril)
This particular investigation has cost you some precious time.
(You have gained some peril)
This particular investigation has cost you some precious time.
(You have gained some peril)
This particular investigation has cost you some precious time.
(You have gained some peril)
Having learned everything you can from the painting studio, you decide to search elsewhere.
Having learned everything you can from the back room, you decide to search elsewhere.
Rather than stand around in the middle of a dark street, you hike up your skirts and hurry across the road to the studio.
Your ears perk up at the sound of voices. They’re distant, but it feels like they’re headed in this direction. Glancing out a window, you see the flicker of lantern light on nearby buildings.
Someone must have spotted you and summoned the Guet Royal. If they find you here, they will most certainly arrest you.
“Gottverdammt! The Guet Royal are on their way. Someone must have spotted us and summoned them.” Hansel growls, scanning the various avenues of approach.
You don’t have much time before they arrive, a few minutes at most.
“We don’t have long before they arrive. What should we do, madame?”
“Stall them, Madame?” Hansel asks with a cocked eyebrow. “Hmmm… I think I have something that should do the trick.”

“Ja, madame.” Hansel grunts with a sound of frustration that echoes your own. He leads you to the window you entered the building through. He effortlessly helps you out the window before following you out, scanning the street for witnesses.

Quickly and quietly, you skulk to the window you entered the building through. Peering through the window, it seems like the coast is clear for now. You lever yourself out the window, and into the street.

With that, Hansel pulls out a flask of brandy from his coat and pours it all over himself. He then rumples his coat, doing up a few of the buttons into the wrong holes, and rumples his hair until he looks truly disheveled.
“This should buy you some time, madame.”
You immediately notice that the door’s been nailed shut.
Hansel exits through the window you both entered from and jogs up the street towards the approaching authorities, you can already hear him shouting at them, slurring his words like a drunk.
“Monsieurs, Gott sei dank! Someone has stolen my house!”
While you don’t have time to listen to Hansel’s entire ploy, you’re sure that he’ll manage to waste everyone’s time enough with wild stories for you to find what you’re looking for.
(You have lost quite a bit of peril)

Outside, he puts the boards back on the window where he found them. You can hear approaching footsteps, and spot the reflection of lantern light off of nearby buildings. The Guet Royal are on there way, but as long as you keep moving, you should be gone before they arrive.
“After you, madame.” Hansel gestures towards the dark alley you initially approached the studio from.
While the authorities may be none the wiser of your deeds, you curse the circumstances that led you to this dead end. With your bodyguard are your back, you disappear into the night.

Outside, you fastidiously put the boards back where you found them on the window. Your ears perk up at the sound of approaching footsteps, and you spot the reflection of lantern light off of nearby buildings. The Guet Royal are on their way, but as long as you keep moving, you should be gone before they arrive.
Without even a look back, you disappear into the dark alley you initially approached the studio from.
The pounding of boots is getting louder and louder. The Guet Royal are here.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Bishop of: Charles-Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord, or simply 'Talleyrand' is figure of much discussion in France. Born as the scion to a powerful noble family, his foot was maimed at an early age in an accident. Unable to particapte in the courtly dances of the courtiers, or march adequately enough to serve in the military, he was deemed useless by his family. Thus, he was sent into the priesthood, like many unwanted sons of nobility.

While he's fulfilled his duties to the Church well, he's also been the subject of much scandal. Talleyrand believes that he embodies a modern system of Catholic values, including his preferences towards the needs of the common people over the nobility. However, these modern views seem to be dismissive of his vows of celibacy. Despite the infirmities that caused his family to dismiss him, he's still been considered quite desirable by many women in France, due to his kindness, erudition, and snapping witicisms.

Of course, this has caused some uproar, as Talleyrand has never even been to Autun. Ignoring his critics, he spent the evening celebrating this turn of good fortune by dining with his mistress in the Louvre.

However, actual advancement within the Church has evaded him for some time. While it's well known that he's been impatiently waiting for the Archbishop of Bourges to finally join the heavenly host, Talleyrand has also had his eye on the post of the Bishop of Autun.

Unfortunately for him, it seems that Talleyrand's prayers have gone unanswered. While the Bishop of Autun has moved to Lyon, he's selected a different successor to his post. This has left the ambitious Talleyrand fuming, and the more orthodox members of the clergy laughing behind their hands.

A few days ago, his pious prayers were answered, and the Bishop of Autun moved to Leon. This opening has made made Talleyrand the new bishop, and given him all of the power he wanted. This includes a wealth of property, and a salary of nearly fifty thousrand livres a year.
The Revolution has gained a powerful ally within the Church, but the credibility of the Church has been damaged, for reasons that don't require divine insight to perceive.

(The Church has lost a little power)
(The Church has moved towards the Revolution by a decent amount)
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

(The Church has gained some power)
(The Church has moved towards the Crown a little)
It appears that the traditionalists in the Church have won this day, and the Revolution has lost the chance to have a powerful ally.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Bourgeois: Only two days ago, Prime Minister Necker was suddenly dismissed by the king. It was a decision that did not sit well with most.

Today, the members of the National Assembly publicly called for the creation of a 'Bourgeois Militia'. 

They want their own army.

If that wasn't disturbing enough, it's well known at this point that this militia will have no shortage of volunteers. There are already fears that members of the military will desert to this new army, as they no longer feel any particular loyalty to the Crown.

If that wasn't disturbing enough, it's well known at this point that this militia will have no shortage of volunteers. While there aren't many fears of large scale desertion within the military, there are still a lot of angry citizens out there, and it doesn't take a lot of manpower to throw up a barricade in the streets and start trouble.

Then again, a large amount of angry people doesn't make an army. While Paris certainly contains enough sickles, kitchen knives, and hammers to allow for violent mobs, any uprising would need rifles and even cannons to succeed.

Those tend to be in short supply.

This militia could overwhelm and rob the ocassional group of watchmen, or even a small military checkoint, but the only large concentration of weaponry that you can think of in Paris is the Bastille. The imposing castle used to be a major prison, but now it's mostly an armory that happens to hold a few especially odious criminals in its spare cells.
And so, in Paris, life goes on.
Of course, that would be utterly insane. Nobody would try to storm a castle in the middle of Paris. That would plunge the city into the kind of chaos that one could never turn back from.
The situation is dire, but surely, everyone will be more reasonable than that, right?
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Cardinal: “Please monsieur, I need to know.”
“Perhaps you are right. It may be too much for me.”
“Mon dieu! I grew up in Grenoble, but never found out the truth. What happened?”
<Eavesdrop>
<Leave them alone>
You happen upon a pair of men whispering in a corner together. They’re trying to look as happy and engaged as the other guests, but they’re movements are too stiff. They seem concerned.

The younger one sighs, and gestures to the crowd with his wine glass. “Everyone’s talking about reforming the estates as if it’s going to be as simple as making a request. Does nobody remember what happened in Grenoble? They sent soldiers into that town just for trying to hold a meeting.”
“I hear that he loaded two bullets in his pistol before he… did it.”

“Well that would certainly explain why it was a closed casket affair. There mustn’t have been much of him left, after that.” 

Your mind conjures up a gruesome image, entirely against your will, and you wretch internally at it.
However, this does give you the level of detail you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself isn’t valuable. Details, on the other hand, make for fine gossip. This should be valuable to someone.

You hear a throat clear.

“Can we help you, madame?” The younger man asks you, with a suspicious scowl.
Before you can answer, his older friend chimes in. “Perhaps we should take our conversation elsewhere. I doubt that we’ll find any privacy here.”

The two of them disappear to a more secluded section of the party, watching you carefully all the while. 

You have a feeling that you’ll be watched more closely from now on.
The older guest stops his friend mid sentence. “I’m not sure if we should continue.”
“I would not want to offend the madame’s sensibilities with such dreadful details.”
After a long pause, the older man relents. “Fine, if you must know...”
“Don’t worry, such details are unnecessary to understanding the bigger picture.” The older man says in an a patronizing tone.
The older man replies wearily “Agreed, and the bloodshed was monstrous. Did you hear about their Bishop?”

“The archbishop of Grenoble shot himself.” The younger man says flatly. “It was a suicide, and a particularly gruesome one at that. That’s why he was in a closed casket instead of being laid out properly. It was also why the church was so unwilling to divulge the details of his death.”
This is exactly the level of detail you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself, isn’t of any consequence. Gruesome details, on the other hand, make for fine gossip. This should be valuable to someone.
You continue your hushed conversation with the two men, and manage to tease out a few more specifics. The three of you eventually go your separate ways.

“I suppose he’s right.” The younger man admits. “What’s most important is that archbishop’s death was a suicide, and this made the church extremely uncomfortable. This is why they were so quiet about his passing.”

During your conversation, you manage to get a few more details about the time of death, who discovered the body, and more. This is exactly what you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself, isn’t of any consequence. Specific details add an air of truthfulness which is necessary for quality gossip. This should be valuable to someone.
"I can understand why, madame. It was grizzly enough that the church didnt make any official announcements. The archbishops funeral was closed casket because-"

The younger man examines you carefully before he says “That’s quite an unusual accent you have, for someone who grew up in Grenoble.”

Your mind races, and you’re not sure if you can remember what a Grenoble accent even sounds like.

“Well, if you did actually grow up there, you must be more familiar with the facts than us.” The older man demures, already pulling his friend away by the elbow. “We would hate to supply you with any misinformation.”

He puts a strong emphasis on the word ‘supply’.

The two of them disappear to a more secluded section of the party, watching you carefully all the while. 

You have a feeling they didn’t believe you.
(You have acquired some gossip. This will be useful later.)

“That he'd killed himself after the riots. Yes, even I found that distressing.”

You’d heard that too, but it was only a rumor. The Church never confirmed this, but why would they?
(You have gained a little peril)
(You have lost some credibility)
(You have acquired some gossip. This will be useful later.)
If you could learn more, this might be some truly valuable gossip.
They turn, noticing you for the first time.

The men are speaking to each other in low voices, and it’s difficult to hear them over the din of the party. You edge a little closer to listen to them, pretending to scan the party as if you were looking for a friend that got lost in the crowd.

You decide against engaging them in conversation, or listening in. While it’s nice to have some reliable gossip, you don’t need it that badly right now. Instead, you spend some time wandering about the party, sipping at your wine, taking in the sights and the sounds.
“He must have felt some guilt for everything that happened.” The older man ventures.
“For a many of the cloth to commit the cardinal sin? It is the only explanation.”
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Customer: “She snubbed me at a party. I hate her.”
“Marcelle? She’s a good friend of mine.”
“Never heard of her.”
“That vile woman snubbed me at a party. I hate her.”
“You seem bothered.”
“The bank note, can I see it?”
“After a story like that, I absolutely have to see the bank note!"
“Fatima, have you ever done business with the Viscountess du Foix?”
“She’s a good friend of mine.”
“I’m just curious.”
You arrive again at Fatima’s dress shop, and while you can’t see the proprietor, you can hear her grumbling from the backroom.

Eventually, Fatima shuffles her way out to meet you in the front of the shop, dropping a ledger onto a nearby table. She seems to be lacking in her normal energy or enthusiasm.

“Welcome back,” she mumbles.

Fatima perks up at this and looks at you with curiosity. “Oh, really? Well it looks like we have something in common, though it tends to make us unpopular. In my case, the Viscountess didn’t snub me at a party, she did so here.”
Finally, she forces a smile. “Shall we do business?”

“Well, a month ago, I was approached by a servant working for the Viscountess du Foix, a ‘genius’ who wanted to commission a dress she had designed herself. I quoted a price to this servant and they immediately tried to tell me it was too high.”
“This servant swore up and down that making something for this Viscountess was ‘extremely prestigious’, and that I should even work at a discount, for all the new business it would bring me.”
The dressmaker snorts derisively. “I may be new to running my own shop, but not new enough to fall for that old ruse.”

“Still, starting a new shop is expensive, and the price we agreed on was very nice. He showed me the sketches for this ‘genius’ design and it honestly wasn’t terrible. A little tacky for my tastes, but...” Fatima sighs and hangs her head for moment. “I wasn’t thinking. I saw the Livres written on that banknote, and didn’t think to check the client’s reputation. I agreed.”

“Between my other jobs, I spent over a month working on this dress, just getting by on the initial payment for materials. Every other day, I’d get a whole list of changes from her. She wouldn’t even check on the dress in person, but something always had to be bigger or more intricate.”
“Anytime I suggested that we tone things down for the sake of elegance, she’d threaten to cancel the order, which would leave me holding the bill.”

“I finally finished it, and this giant pink confection was a crime against good taste. I hated it so much that I didn’t even write my name in the lining. The Viscountess finally arrived in person to see her creation and…”
“She hated it. Even went so far as accusing me of ‘butchering’ her design.”
“How can I help you?”

“After calling me every name under the sun, she took the dress, but refused to pay the bill. She claimed it was ‘compensation’ for her lost time.” Fatima bites down on the stem of her pipe hard enough that, for a second, you’ll worry that she’ll crack one of her teeth. “I could take her to court, but no judge would take the word of a minor shopkeep over that of an aristocrat. I’d need a good lawyer… which I can’t afford.”
“So that’s my tale of woe. In fact, I still keep the original bank note for my materials payment hanging in my office. It’s a reminder to be careful who I do business with.”
“Sorry to bore you with my story.”
“I suppose...” Fatima says with a shrug. “As long as you don’t make fun of me when you see it.”
I suppose... Fatima says with a shrug. As long as you dont make fun of me when you see it.

(You have gained some credibility)
(You have gained some peril)

“You see, a month ago, I was approached by a servant working for the Viscountess du Foix. This servant said the Viscountess was a ‘genius’ who wanted to commission a dress she had designed herself. I quoted a price to them and they immediately tried to tell me it was too high.”
Fatima disappears into the back of the shop for a moment.

She returns with the bank note, written out on a piece of paper. “I should have known something was wrong the moment I saw this thing. Why would a noble give me a note from some minor place like Caisse de Confiance? She probably cheated all the respectable banks.”
You study the bank note, taking care to memorize the name and address.
“Am I really that obvious?” She asks with a sigh. “I had a big order, a custom project. It took me forever, cost a lot to make, and then just… fell through.”
(Bank and Mistrust is now available to visit in the Paris map)
After a few moments, she takes the note back. “So, Madamme Decaux, shall we do business?”
(You have lost some credibility)

At the mention of Marcelle’s title, Fatima’s sneers for a second, as if she’d just smelled something truly foul.

She opens one eye, judging you carefully.
“I’m going to have a devil of a time making ends meet now.”
Fatima opens one eye, judging you carefully.
Fatima’s voice is flat and level. “How do you know her?”
“How interesting...” she mutters, chewing on the end of her pipe.
You lie through your teeth with an easy familiarity, and Fatima makes no sign of suspecting your false ignorance.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Dauphin's: It's an open secret that Louis Joseph, Dauphin of France and heir to the throne of His Majesty King Louis XVI, has suffered from grave illnesses since he was a young child. High fevers, and difficulty withbreathing have dogged him his entire life, and he's only seven years old.
While they have other children, this has been a source of great distress for the King and Queen, who had many difficulties conceiving children at all.

Now, with the price of bread the highest it's ever been, and the royal coffers nearly empty, over six hundred thousand livres were spent on the young boy's funeral. 

Then again, the lives of princes has never been the object of economy.

The Dauphin has seen to be in much better health than before, and the royal physicians have declared him to be on the road to recovery. While the young boy is still unsteady, he's been seen joining his mother on long walks around the gardens at Versailes.

Her Majesty has put every available resource into ensuring their child's health, but the illnesses have seemed to persist. On particularly bad days, His Majesty has been unable to stay focused and perform his duties to the nation. He simply cannot take his mind off of the state of his son.

Yesterday, the unthinkable happened. 

The Dauphin died. It was consumption.
(The Crown has lost a decent amount of power)
(The Crown has gained a decent amount of power)
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

The King, seen to be in great distress, has abandoned his duties in Paris, and retired to Versailles to greive. His ministers attempted to advise him against this, considering the grave situation facing the country, but were ignored.

What can one possibly say to man who has just lost his son?

This news has already been cause for His Majesty, the King, to be more vigorous and optimistic. Having this great weight lifted from his shoulders will certainly allow him to be more focused on his duties to the country.
