You wander around the party, scanning the room for someone interesting to talk to. You hear some shuffling behind you.
"Guess who?" A sultry voice whispers in your ear.
You also can't help but notice how many guests' eyes linger on the way she's holding your hand. Nobody says a word, but they do watch.

Finally, the two of you manage to find an empty room in the party, forgotten by the other guests. A low fire burns in the fireplace, but nobody is here. She slowly shuts the door behind you, and takes a seat in a big, overstuffed chair.
"Sit." She commands, pointing to a spot on the floor in front of her.

Careful to make sure that you don't step on your own dress, you sit on the floor infront of her, your legs curled off to one side and your body propped up on one hand. She looms over you, and she smiles.
Undaunted, you stride up to her, and in a smooth motion you sit on her lap. Surprised, she leans back and lets a wide grin blossom across her face. Her features flicker in the firelight.
Walking off to the side, you grab one of the chairs and drag it in front of her. Comfortably, you take a seat. All Madame Gazel can do is roll her eyes.
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
She entwines her fingers in the hair on the back of your head, and slowly but firmly, Madame Gazel pulls your face close to hers. "And I ever love instilling obedience in you."
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)

The two of you engage in little snippets of conversation, all of them meaningless. Instead, the both of you are focused on each other. The entire party going on in the other rooms fades into the background as you slowly let go of yourself. Let yourself be made lesser than another. Let yourself be controlled.
"Mmm... a mere lucky guess." She replies, but you can hear the smile in her voice.

The room goes dark as someone comes up behind you and places their hands over your eyes.

<Black Background>
Turning yourself around, you find yourself face to face with none other than Madame Gazel. "In what world do I sound like Armand?"
"Fortunately for you, I'm already in a great mood, and I'd like to celebrate it with you. First, however, we'll need to find somewhere quiet."
She drops her hands from your eyes and you turn around to find yourself face to face with none other but Madame Gazel.
"Oh, you ever remain full of surprises."
Suddenly, your spine goes stiff at the sound of the door opening. A woman walks into the room, and the both of you go as still as statues.
She looks disgusted by what she sees, but also completely unsurprised. As if she was looking for something.
"What, exactly are the two of you doing?"
After a pause, Madame Gazel agrees. "She's right. It's nothing at all."
The room goes silent, and even you are taken aback by the audacity of the woman who just said that. That is, until you remember that the woman who made that comment is you.
"Armand? Really?" The voice asks, as they drop their hands from your eyes.
"You fell?"
She glares suspicously at you and mumbles "Well, you do look rather flushed."
"Oh don't bother with those preposterous lies."
Madame Gazel stands up her chair, still holding onto one of your hands. "It's true! My dear friend here is so clumsy. I just have no idea what she'd do without me."

(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained some peril)
She sneers at you both. "You disgusting people can't evade the eyes of society forever."
The two of you sit together in stony silence. Even the crackling of the fire seems muted.
This interloper seems surprised, yet also smugly satisfied. Like weilding this power is what fulfills her.
"Good... I thought as much."
With that, this person leaves as suddenly as they arrived. Yet, the pall they cast over the room remains. Madame Gazel sighs, and stares at the ceiling.
"Ignoring my request? How disobedient." The low voice replies. "Now, guess who?"
"I know I said that I was in a great mood before, but this is... that was..." She trails off, never completing the sentence. She doesn't need to.
Suddenly, she stands up, the shine of tears just starting to well up in her eyes. "I'm sorry Yvette... I just need to.. I just-"
With that, Honorade leaves, and you are alone.
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel... Don't worry, it's not really your fault.)
You glance around the room. There's nothing here except a low fire, and a sense of heartache.

Alone, you just sit in the room by yourself for a while. You lose track of time as you relive every detail of what just transpired, over and over again. You can't help it. All you can do it relive the moments, picking apart the flaws of every exchange.
Unable to stand this indignity anymore, you stand up in a whirl of finery and fury. You rush out the door to find this interloper and tell her exactly what you think of her disgust.
Outwardly she looks calm, but she's squeezing your hand so hard that your fingers are starting to tingle.
"I suppose that's reasonable." She says, with a strange sense of disappointment about her.
The suspicious woman leaves, glancing back at the two of you one last time before she disappears from your sight.
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
After a few moments, the two of you finally exhale in unison.
"Well, that certainly got my heart racing." Madame Gazel giggles.
"W-well, this is disgusting. In fact, both of you are." The interloper replies with with venom, but far quieter than she intended. The lack of volume seems to rob her of the intended gravitas.
"You are at least partly correct." Honorade chimes in. "I too am absolutely disgusted."
"But you're free to leave at any time."
"This isn't over." She sneers at you both. "You people can't evade the eyes of society forever."
With that she leaves, and tries to slam the door on her way out. Unfortunately for her, the door gets caught on the carpet and just lazily drifts shut.
(You have gained some peril)
"I must admit that I never expected you to be the one to defending me, Yvette. In fact, I never really expected anyone to defend me at all."
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have lost a little credibility)

Taking the time to lock the door this time, the two of you resume your same positions as before, and spend some more time together, whispering meaningless nothings and drawing ever closer. The time slips away from the both of you.
"You know that's not what I meant."
It's not a good feeling.
Realizing that you've already drawn your fair share of suspicion, the two of you eventually part ways. If nothing else, this has ensured that you've had a lovely evening.
You can't hear anything other than your own breathing and the blood pumping in your ears. The anger is so overwhelming that it's become intoxicating.
Hurtling from room to room, you come upon her, merrily talking with other guests as if nothing had ever happened. As if she was innocent.

Words of purest venom issue forth from your mouth, with such speed and violence that you don't even remember what you said. What you do remember, is the looks on the faces of everyone who heard you say it.

(You have gained quite a bit of peril)
(You have gained quite a bit of credibility)
The rest of the evening is a blur. You're not even sure if you did anything else at the party before you headed home. You spend a few hours trying to peice the events together in your journal.
"I'm in a great mood, and I'd like to celebrate it with you. First, however, we'll need to find somewhere quiet."
"Good girl."
(You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
You can't even remember when the conversation stopped, but both of your wrists are in Madame Gazel's hands, and her lips are drifting so close to yours.
She's not wrong. You can feel how red your cheeks are.
Still, some part of this stranger remains unconvinced, which makes sense. Your lie was absolutely preposterous.

None of hte other guests have no context for this display of fury. All they know is that you were willing to come to Madame Gazel's defense in a most spectacular fashion. Even if they don't approve of it, they do seem to respect it.
She grabs you by the hand, and leads you away to a distant corner of the party.

Your progress through the crowds of the party is surprisingly slow. People keep stopping the two of you to pay their respects to Madame Gazel, and ask her for her opinion on various matters particular to the bourgeoisie.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Final Sit: <Knock on the door>
"Don't worry, I would have suggested a nude, even if you didn't."
"Elisabeth, what's going on over there?"
<Wait>
"Elisabeth, are you even painting anymore?"
<Just walk in>
<Wait some more>
"Just shut up and kiss me already."
"In that case, I'd love some tea please."
<Wait>
<Wait>
"That was lovely. Nobody's made me feel the way Elisabeth does."
"It'll take some time before I know how I feel about this."
<Idealized Painting Check>
<Honest Painting Check>
<You, as she sees you, check>
"Elisabeth is extremely useful. It's good to have her trust."
"This might have been a mistake."
"That's because your clients don't know you like I do. They don't trust you like I do."
"Well, as long you don't go parading this in public I'll be fine."

It takes a little longer than before to get to Elisabeth's studio today. There's no special event, the streets are simply crowded with throngs of people going about their daily business. 

You resist the urge to scream and shove them out of your way, but just barely.
Still, you manage to arrive at the painting studio without incident or injury.
Elisabeth doesn't say anything for a while, but instead shifts uncomfortably at her easel.

Elisabeth puts down her brush for a moment and laughs into the back of her hand. "Oh really, is that so?"

(You have gained some favor with Elisabeth)
"Now, I need you to stop being so funny for a moment, I can't be gigling during some of these more precise details." The artist says with a mock sternness.
"Of course not, this is just for me... and you."
With nothing more than a contented smile, Elisabeth returns to her painting, still glancing up at you on ocassiona before squinting down at some particular detail.
Elisabeth returns to her painting, still glancing up at you at regular intervals before squinting down at some particular detail.

Another hour passes, and you take a break to stand up and stretch. Even with your relaxed pose on the couch, all of that time spent staying exactly still starts to wear on you. 

You return back to your position, and Elisabeth to her art.
Later, you find yourself shifting on the couch again. This has been quite a long session.
"Oh, what?" Elisabeth asks, standing up from her canvas.

You silently roll your shoulders and resettle into your pose. You're not positioned to look at Elisabeth directly, but out of the corner of your eye you can see her leaning away from the canvas to examine you.
Still thinking of the myriad people who wouldn't get out of your way on the walk over here, you knock sharply on the door.
You squint as you notice that her brush hand hasn't moved in an awfully long time.

FInally, Elisabeth stands up from her easel with a laugh. "I'm sorry Yvette, but I've been done over half an hour ago." 

She favors you with a sly grin. "I just enjoy looking at you like this."
She gets up from her easel and walks over to you. "You must be very cold."
Her finger traces down the outside of your thigh. "How'd you like to warm up?"

"Well, the client is always right." She replies with a smirk. 

With the rustling sound of skirts, Elisabeth kneels on the couch and places a hand on the armrest behind you. Gently, she leans forward over you. You crane your neck until your lips meet.

"Fair enough, I'll fetch us some refreshements. You must be famished."

Before you can reply, the rumbling of your stomach speaks for you.
You have to admit, she is very warm.

Some time later, after taking the time to fix your hair and slip back into your foundation garments, you're taking tea and pastries with Elisabeth.

They taste amazing, but that might just be because you're famished.

While Elisabeth is out fetching said refreshments, you take the time to slip back into your foundation garments. You keep your stays tied loosely, because you'd hate to get in the way of your own appetite.

The two of you lounge and chat about the painting for some time. You pace about the studio while you talk, relishing the chance to stretch your limbs after all this time.

Eventually it gets late enough that the two of you have to say your goodbyes. Elisabeth helps you back into your dress.
Keeping Elisabeth's previous requests for discretion in mind, you let yourself into her studio. A cool breeze sweeps through the open windows, rustling the cloth that covers the painting-in-progress.
Outside, you walk home. Compared to the nightmarish hustle and bustle of before, the streets feel almost abandoned. You stroll alone, completely lost in your own thoughts.
You arrive home, still unsure of how you feel.
Feeling buoyed by the heady thrills of love, you ascend to your bedroom on light feet, and prepare yourself for bed.
Your mind reels with uncertainty as you carefully ascend the stairs to your bedroom. Still preoccupied with your mixed feelings, you fall into a restless sleep.
She grabs you by the wrist and pulls you inside.

Elisabeth stops to breathe quietly, slowly regaining her composure. One of her hands plays with the edge of the canvas apron she's wearing over her dress.

"Ok, I'm fine now. Shall we get started? I'm just itching to work!"
"Sorry, I must have finished up half an hour ago." She says with a sly grin. "I just enjoy looking at you like this."

"Oh, I almost forgot!" Elisabeth giggles. "I should probably show you the painting that you've been sitting for, all of this time."

With a burst of fresh energy she gets up and walks over to her easel.

She turns around the canvas and you see your future.

You asked Elisabeth to give you perfection and she delivered it unto you. Every beauty has been refined, and every flaw erased. You may be nude in the painting, but you feel as regal as any monarch laden with jewels, silks, and ermine.

She turns around the canvas and you see yourself. 

The image is surprising, but in an interesting way. You aren't unattractive by any stretch of the imagination, but like most you often gloss over the details of your own features, preferring the image you see in your head. You almost want to disagree with the painting but you know it's correct. 

It makes you think the way the best pieces of art do. It is a beautiful portrait, in that way that only the unadulterated truth can achieve.

"Ah, it's great to see you!" Elisabeth says as she strides into the room, already dressed to paint. "Shall we get started? I'm just itching to work."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)

She turns around the canvas and you see yourself. Well, not just yourself.

It's Elisabeth's version of you, and while she isn't in the portrait itself, you can see so much of her personality in the painting. You look relaxed and confident, but adorned with an enigmatic smile and eyes that seems to be looking somewhere else.

It's obvious that a tremendous amount of work has gone into this painting. If you squint closely, you can see places where the oil paints have been layered and layered, the result of endless attempts to get some tiny detail just right. It's a labor of love and it shows.
"It was really brave of you to ask me to paint you honestly, and I'm proud of the results." Elisabeth smiles, regarding the painting with her hands on her hips.
"I hope you like it." Elisabeth says sheepishly. "I wanted to make sure that it still feels like you."
Putting down her paints and removing her apron, she walks over to you. "You must be very cold."
(You have earned a lot of favor with Elisabeth, but you probably already knew that, didn't you?)

When Elisabeth returns with the tea and pastries, you waste no time in digging in. 

They taste amazing, but of course, hunger has always been the sweetest spice.
"I can't wait to get this framed and hung up in my collection."

With a grin of triumph, and a mind aflame with possibility, you practically dance up the stairs to your bedroom. You can't help but spend a few minutes practicing regal faces in your vanity's mirror before you turn down for the night.
Burdened with internal turmoil, you ascend to your bedroom with a heavy tread. Wearily, you prepare yourself for bed.

The door creaks open and you can see Elisabeth's angry face on the other side.

"Yvette, if this is a joke, it's not funny. You know my situation." She hisses at you, making significant glances to the shapes of the servants in the windows above.

(You have lost a little favor with Elisabeth)
Everywhere you look in the painting, you are struck by an uncanny perfection that reminds you that what you are seeing isn't real. Yet.
Elisabeth takes a deep breat, and her next words are almost a sigh of relief. "I'm really proud of this one. I can't wait to get it framed and hung up in my collection."

With what has become a practiced ease, you disrobe and take your position on the satin couch. 

Elisabeth takes the cover off of your portrait and starts preparing her paints.
At this stage, she's focusing on specific details of your portrait. Ocassionally, she asks for you to minutely shift parts of your body this way and that.
"I wasn't sure you'd even agree to even pose for me. Nudes tend to make clients nervous."

"Oh really, you trust me?" Elisabeth asks with an arched eyebrow. She's trying to remain aloof, but you can tell that she's actually a little touched.

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The First Sit: <Knock on the door>
"Are you sure that's why you chose to do this?"
"Alright, I suppose that makes sense."
<Just walk in>
"Make me gorgeous, like a Queen."
"Depict me as I really am. There is beauty in honesty."
"Paint me as you see me. That way, it can be about both of us."
"Depict me as you see me."
"Depict me as you see me."
"Depict me as you see me."
"Depict me as you see me."
"Depict me as you see me."
"Alright, I suppose I can do that..."
"I hope you're ready for this."
"Wait, what kind of painting is this going to be?"
A warm breeze caresses your skin as you check the address that Elisabeth gave you a few nights ago, confirming that you're heading to the right place.

"That's very brave of you." Elisabeth says with a smile. "I normally spend so much time trying to flatter my clients that the truth might be an interesting challenge." 

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
If you're going to do something, you might as well do it right.
"Well, it's a nude portrait of you reclining on that couch, though I think you figured that part out already." Elisabeth says with a giggle as she sets up her canvas and paints.

Shutting the door behind you, she says "I'm sorry for that, I'm just worried my husband's servants heard you."

Taking a moment to compose herself, she smiles. "I'm really glad you've decided to do this."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)

Finally, you undo your stays and with a sigh, let your linen chemise fall to the floor. You take a deep breath, your lungs freed from the restrictions of corsetry.

"Do you feel better?" Elisabeth asks, leading you over to the couch.
"That was... something else." Elisabeth manages to stammer to you.

After spending more than a few moments admiring you, Elisabeth gives you some specifics on how to pose. A wrist here, an ankle there, laying your head back in order to better catch the light on your face.

"If you're feeling nervous, then just think about the fact that you're one of the most beautiful people to ever grace this furniture." She says with a sly grin.

You take a seat, feeling more at ease, despite the unfamiliar situation.
"That's why you should be naked, laying on my beautiful couch."

Taken aback by your comment, her face flushes a rose red.

"Well, perhaps I had some ulterior motives..."
She reaches out and gently takes you by the hand. "There's no need to be shy. I've painted hundreds of people before."

Elisabeth walks in, wearing a paint spattered apron, and carying a freshly stretched canvas, while you're still in the middle of your inspection. "Salut Yvette! Please come in, and close the door quietly, I don't want my husband's servant to hear us." (You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)

She walks to her easel and using a piece of charcoal, starts to sketch out your position on the canvas. You can't see what she's doing, but you can hear her mumble to herself while she works.

From the sounds of it, the sketching is going well.

A few minutes pass and you realize how comfortable you are, despite your vulnerable position. Being naked no longer feels different. Like plunging into cold water, the initial shock is really the most noticable part
Eventually, like the water, it just feels calm and refreshing.

A few hours pass, punctuated only by the occasional break to get up and stretch. Elisabeth won't let you look at the canvas on your breaks, so instead you content yourself with staring out the window, at the way the sunlight plays with the leaves on the vines.
"Oh, I wouldn't recommend that. Painting Queens only seems to lead to trouble for me."
Elisabeth doesn't reply at first. Instead she stares at you quizzacly, as if she's uncertain that you're serious.
She starts drawing again with a fresh energy, scribbling with her charcoal all over the canvas.
She looks you, seemingly with fresh eyes, and starts scribbling furiously on her canvas. Judging by the sounds of her muttering, she's enjoying the challenge.
Still, you can tell that she's keeping your request in mind. She spends the next few minutes correcting a few lines of her charcoal.

When you finally break for the day, Elisabeth takes off her canvas apron, makes some tea, and brings out a few small pastries while you get dressed. 

In the midst of devouring said pastries, you realize that you're suprisingly hungry for someone who's spent the day sitting in one place.

Every time you pass a stranger on the street, you expect them to know, somehow. To know that you're on your way to a beautiful, fascinating woman's studio so that she can paint a nude portrait of you for her private collection.

You feel nervous. You feel anticipation.

After spending an hour chatting and looking at your figure sketched out on the canvas, you decide to head home. Out in the street, your footsteps feel lighter, the world seems brighter, and more in focus.
"Get in, get in!" She whispers to you, motioning you inside.

"To be specific, I've spent so much time painting clothed figures, that I feel like I'm losing touch with my fundamentals. This will let me practice my anatomy rendering, and the satin on the couch will let me keep current on my fabric skills."

Your skin slides along the cool satin, as you get settled into place. Elisabeth gently arranges your pose, one limb at a time, helping you settle into just the right position.

"Alright, you're doing your part just fine. It's time for me to do mine!"

Keeping that in mind, you stride over to the couch, slowly disrobing as you walk. The line of discarded clothing forms a trail behind you until finally, you drape your corset over the back of the couch, and slowly recline into a comfortable position.

"Are you sure you've never done this before?"

You give no reply, other than an appropriately enigmatic smile.
"I have the framing and positioning set, how would you like me to depict you?"
What a day.

Eventually, she breaks into a broad smile. "I think I'd like that very much."

(You've gained some favor with Elisabeth)

You glance back down at the paper, then at the number on the house. You're here. 

The studio feels like a seperate building that's been attached to her house, and while you assume that her husband is at work, you can see the shapes of servants through the home's windows.
How best to proceed?
You rap your nuckles against the door, elegantly but firmly.

Not wanting to make too much noise, you open the door and step inside the studio. The place is clean, though it's still spattered with dried paint. Shrubs and ivies growing over the windows provide some privacy, but still let the sunlight filter in.

The door suddenly opens just wide enough for you to see Elisabeth's startled face.

"Yvette, is that you?"
She leads you to a couch, upholstered in satin. "I'll need you to undress and pose for me here."

Nervously, you begin to fumble with the ties and toggles of your dress.

As you strip down to your foundation garments, you utter a silent prayer of thanks to the fact that it's a warm day, so at least you won't be shivering on the couch.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The First Spa: The First Sparks
“I’m not sure if I should...”
“I’ll get my things, let’s go!”
“I’ll get my things, let’s go!”
“I’m sorry, she’s simply not here.”
“I’m sorry, you have the wrong woman.”
“Camille, please answer the door.”
“I’ll get it!”
"Camille, ready my things. I have to go!"
“Camille, ready my things. I have to go!”
“I’m not going, Camille. Tell him I’m not here.”
“I’m Yvette Decaux. What’s the matter?”
“Who’s asking?”
“Mon dieu, there isn’t a moment to spare! Let’s go!”
“Mon dieu, there isn’t a moment to spare! Let’s go!”
“Then why did you do it?”
“It’s alright, I’m here now.”
“You did a very brave thing today.”
“When I heard you were hurt, I’d never been so afraid before.”
“Please, don’t leave me.”

A week ago, a wallpaper manufacturer named Jean-Baptiste Réveillon made a speech demanding bread prices to be lowered to something workers could afford. However, this speech was misinterpreted as a plan to control the wages of workers.
Last night, a protest at his factory resolved peacefully.

Following the riots, the watchmen of the Guet Royal were deemed not enough to contain the rising tensions, and the soldiers of Garde Francais will now patrol the city. The streets of Paris feel like they’ve been occupied by a foreign army.

“Madame, please!” The man reaches out and grabs your wrist. Instinctively, you pull back from him, alarmed by this manhandling from a complete stranger. However, you find no malice in his eyes, only desperation. “Dumas is going to die. We already tried to get a priest to perform his last rites, but he waved the Father off.”
“Corporal Dumas, he… he only wanted to see you.”

“Madame, please!” He shouts as you start to shut the door, jamming his leg in the doorway so you can’t shut it completely. You step back from the door, expecting aggression. However, you find no violence in his eyes, only desperation. “Dumas is going to die. We already tried to get a priest to perform his last rites, but he waved the Father off.”
“Corporal Dumas, he… he only wants to see her.”

You can tell from his face that he doesn’t believe you, but he steps back anyway.

“I see madame. It seems that I’ve made a mistake…”
“I will leave you here, and return to my comrade.” He turns his back on you, and mounts his horse. The glare he gives you as he rides away could strip the paint off a house.
(You have lost a decent amount of favor with the Military)
You return to your morning preparations.
(The Military has gained a decent amount of power)

In fact, Revolutionary demagogues are already framing this change as an occupation, an attempt by the monarchy to use a display of arms to cow the people of the third estate ahead of the Estates General. It’s hard to argue with their logic, when armed soldiers patrol the streets.
(The Revolution has gained a large amount of power)

The lawyers, doctors, and merchants of the Bourgeoisie have expressed worry to their revolutionary colleagues of the third estate. They want a statement from the revolutionaries, condemning the destruction of an innocent man’s property, but these requests have gone unanswered...
(The Bourgeoisie has moved towards the Crown by quite a bit)
...and so, in a fit of anger, Paris has started to burn.

Yesterday’s crowds, returned today. They were fewer in number, but greater in anger. However, the watchmen of the Guet Royal were tipped off by a former participant from yesterday’s protests. Aware of the new crowd’s violent intent, they wasted no time in cracking down on individual groups before they could coalesce into a single mass.

A mob of angry citizens grows in power and bravery with every additional person. Once large enough, it can become as powerful as a tidal wave. Small groups, however, can be brushed aside as easily as the rain. The factories were left unharmed.
(The Bourgeoisie has gained a decent amount of power)
Today, however… was different.
The organizers of the protest, men and women, were rounded up and will stand trial in the next few days for sedition, and conspiring against the crown. If found guilty, they could be hanged.

Several aristocrats and generals have expressed concern for the possibility of future violence, and suggested using the soldier of the Gardes Françaises to help maintain order. The King has forbidden this, expressing full confidence in the Guet Royal’s ability to patrol the streets of Paris.
(The Military has lost some power)
Even more are praising the King for his even-handed judgement, saying that the presence of soldiers on the streets would have only increased tensions.
(The Crown has gained quite a bit of power)
Violence has been contained… for now.

Yesterday’s crowds, over three thousand strong, returned today. As mobs began to smash Réveillon’s factory, the watchmen of the Guet Royal were mobilized to contain the crowds, suddenly reinforced by the Queen’s Dragoons, who were in the area for a training exercise.
(The Bourgeoisie has lost some power)

The sudden presence of the military was a disquieting one. It’s one thing to face the watchmen one sees everyday on the street, but it’s another to see mounted soldiers with rifles and sabers. One exists to keep the established order, the other exists to kill. Fear began to escalate through the crowd.
Fear led to violence.
Today, however… was different.

A brick was thrown. A rifle was fired. Nobody knows which happened first, but for a brief moment the floodgates of violence were opened, and blood flowed in the streets around a simple wallpaper factory.

In the midst of this madness, a common soldier broke ranks, riding into the center of the conflict, waving his hat, imploring everyone to put down their weapons and come to their senses. The unbelievable sight was enough to stun those who saw it, to make them reconsider their actions.
He was struck down by a bullet, fired by one of his own comrades. An accident.

His name was Corporal Thomas-Alexandre Dumas, and he will be remembered as a hero. His death lead to an abrupt cease-fire and is credited with greatly diminishing the amount of casualties that day. This has led to a sudden swelling of support for the members of the soldiering class, from all corners of society.
Your concentration is broken by the sound of someone knocking on the door downstairs. You look up from your collection of newspapers.
(The Military has gained a large amount of power)

His funeral was one of the most widely attended in recent history, with demagogues from both the Crown and Revolution claiming Thomas-Alexandre as a martyr to their cause. The Military establishment has chosen to remain silent on the matter.

(The Crown has gained a little power)
(The Revolution has gained a little power)

This silence, in fact, has been deeply concerning for members of the aristocracy, who are worried that the common soldiers will be less likely to bear arms against their fellow citizens. Still, despite this, the soldiers of the Gardes Françaises have volunteered to patrol the streets until a measure of peace is restored. This has been greeted with a wary assent by the public.

This silence, in fact, has been deeply concerning for the nationalists of the revolution, who were surprised by the willingness of common soldiers to fire upon their fellow citizens of the third estate. Still, despite this, the soldiers of the Gardes Françaises have volunteered to patrol the streets until a measure of peace is restored. This has been greeted with a wary assent by the public.
Today, however… was different.
(The Military has moved its allegiance towards the Revolution by a decent amount)
...and so, with the loss of a voice pleading for peace, Paris has started to burn.
(The Military has moved its allegiance towards the Crown by a decent amount)
The same knock at the door again, only it’s louder and more frantic.
“Oui, Madame! You hear Camille call from the kitchen, and hear her walk to the front door downstairs. You can make out the muffled noises of a frantic conversation. Camille gasps, dropping something.
You head downstairs at let the man standing at the door inside. He's wearing the uniform of a dragoon, and he stenches of gunpowder.

Camille rushes into your room, her eyes wide with shock.

“Madame, Corporal Dumas has been shot.”
“The man downstairs is asking for you to come with him. He looks worried.”

With that command, Camille becomes a frenzy of action as you get ready as quickly as possible. Stays are laced into place, clothes are retrieved, and shoes are buckled on, all at a whirlwind pace. You rush down the stairs, pulling on your travelling cloak.

“That is a good point Madame.” Camille admits, wringing her apron in hands. “It might be dangerous to be out on the streets right now, but this…” 

She trails off, staring at you expectantly.
The crowds from yesterday returned, unsatisfied. Over five thousand strong, the protests escalated to violence, and Réveillon’s factory was destroyed.
“This might be the last time you get to see him.”
“O-Oui madame.” Camille stammers. She turns and heads downstairs, obviously tense.
Downstairs, you can hear her talking with the young soldier at the door. While you can’t make out any of the words, you can hear the barely contained anger in his voice. The door shuts quietly.
(You have lost a decent amount of favor with the Military)
As he rides away, you look out the window at the plumes of smoke billowing into the air above the Faubourg Saint-Antoine district.
This all looks like it’s going to get worse before it gets better.

When he died, it became obvious that Corporal Thomas-Alexandre Dumas would be remembered as a hero. His death lead to an abrupt cease-fire and is credited with greatly diminishing the amount of casualties that day. This has led to a sudden swelling of support for the members of the soldiering class, from all corners of society.
“Is Madame Yvette Decaux here?” he asks, breathing heavily.
“I’ve been sent for you. Corporal Dumas was shot during the riots, his condition is getting worse. Please come with me.”

He frowns in confusion and irritation, and shifts from foot to foot. He places his hand on the door frame and cranes his neck to look beyond you, into the house. “I’m asking on behalf on Corporal Thomas-Alexandre Dumas. Corporal Dumas was shot during the riots.”
(The Bourgeoisie has lost a large amount of power)
“Please, I’ve been sent to find Madame Decaux. His condition is getting worse, and he needs to speak with her.”
You rush to your room and grab your barest necessities before returning to the door. Through the doorway, you see the soldier has just finished adjusting his saddle so two people can ride it.
Stepping outside, you’ve never been helped onto a horse so quickly in your life. The young man sent to fetch you jumps into the saddle and you take off together.

Everything becomes a blur as you barrel through the streets at a full gallop. Buildings whip by, and you can barely make out the shocked and confused faces of the pedestrians leaping out your way. 

Plumes of smoke loom ahead of you on the city skyline, and you can taste ash on the wind.

In a few jarring minutes, you find yourself being helped off of the horse in Faubourg Saint-Antoine, the same district that the riots had been taking place in. Tents and barricades thrown up in the middle of the street give the feeling of a military encampment. Everyone looks to be in the same disheveled state as the man sent to retrieve you. Faces are stained black with smoke, and uniforms are spattered with mud... and what you sincerely hope is only more mud.
You are led into a tent to find a large group of men milling about aimlessly, in front of a canvas cot. The moment they notice you, you’re immediately pushed to the front.
At the sight of you, Thomas-Alexandre sits up in his cot, and forces himself to stand, an act so laborious that it hurts just to watch.

“My comrades, please!” He calls out to the room, his strong and mirthful voice reduced to a rasp. “As much as I love the idea of a beautiful woman being delivered directly to my bed, I must say that this is a bit much!”

This joke manages to elicit a few chuckles from the grim countenances of the assembled soldiers. The dire mood is dispelled for a moment. 

“Please, leave us.” He asks, and his comrades file out of the room.

The moment the last man leaves the room, Thomas sits down onto the bed with such force that you’re worried that it might topple over. He coughs, covering his mouth politely, but you can’t help but notice his palm as he tries, nonchalantly, to hide it from view.
The rioters then marched on Réveillon’s home, burning and looting it. The violence couldn’t be contained by the watchmen of the Guet Royal, and the army was called in to restore order.
It’s wet and red.
“That… that hurt a lot more than I thought it would.”

“Because if I stand up and make jokes, they might think that I’m going to be fine. They’ll think that swagger and a brave face can make bullets miss, and wounds go away.” He sighs shakily, and leans his shoulder against your leg, one hand grasping tightly onto your skirts. Even sitting up must be hard for him.
He smiles, and leans his shoulder against your leg, as if checking to see that you’re really there. “Yes… you are here.”
“They are good men, and they deserve a good lie.”

He pauses, almost as if to gather his strength. You are in the middle of an encampment with over a hundred men and horses, and yet you can hear nothing except for his breathing. After a long pause, he says. “I’m so glad you came.”

“The bullet slashed one my lungs, and I’m not sure how long I have left. The surgeon advised against talking, but he’s put me through enough pain that I think I’m allowed to ignore him for a little while.”
After a long pause he wheezes “By the way, I know it’s rude to demand someone’s presence, but I hope you can forgive me… given the circumstances.”

Taking your hand in his, he looks into your eyes. “I know that we haven’t known each other for that long, but I wanted to say… my life has had a lot of disappointments in it. A lot of things, and a lot of people that didn’t live up to their promises. You were never one of them.”
“Every single day with you, was a pleasant surprise.”
They restored order with bullets.

“Nonsense.” He smiles weakly. “I was simply the first to act. I’m certain my other comrades would have done the same thing, had I not stepped in.”

You’re not certain that’s true.

“But still, you came. Isn’t that what bravery is? Being scared, but doing the right thing anyway?” His hand absentmindedly reaches towards the bullet wound in his chest, and he gasps with pain the moment his hand even gets near it.

“I’m sorry, but fortune seems to have made other plans.” He gestures to the wound in his chest. The bloodstain on his clothes is spreading, and that’s only the parts that you can see. 

He looks up at you, eyes straining to focus on your face.
(You have gained some favor with Alex)
His vibrant face has slowly faded to an ashen color, and his lips start to shake. “I’m sorry Yvette… I wish I had more time…”
Everything inside him seems to slow down, like a candle fading in the dark. His next words are barely above a whisper.
He's gone.
You carefully lay him down on the bed, and shut his eyes.
With those last words, you leave the tent, and walk out into the makeshift camp. Men doff their hats and helmets to you in respect as you pass, but otherwise leave you be.
Over one hundred people were killed, and even more wounded.
With those last words, you leave the tent, and walk out into the makeshift camp. Men doff their hats and helmets to you in respect as you pass, but otherwise leave you be.

Without any words left to say, you simply stare at Thomas in silence. Eventually, you leave the tent, and walk out into the makeshift camp. Men doff their hats and helmets to you in respect as you pass, but otherwise leave you be.
“It’s never a pleasant experience.”
(You have gained a decent amount of favor with Alex)
His vibrant face has slowly faded to an ashen color, and his lips start to shake. “I’m sorry Yvette… I’m going to need you to be brave, one last time.”
(You have gained a little favor with Alex)
His vibrant face has slowly faded to an ashen color, and his lips start to shake. “I’ve done my duty. Now you must fulfill your own purpose. Find your happiness.”

You walk home without incident. Something about your manner seems to ward off any passers-by from inquiring about the smell of gunpowder on your person, or the bloodstains on your skirts. Exhausted, you walk in a daze.
You get home, and realize that it’s much later in the day than you expected. You feel absolutely drained.
(You have gained a level of exhaustion)
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Full Pict: “You know what? Let’s find out if that’s true.” <Unveil the painting>
“Well, if you want to preserve your work so badly, you could always pay me.”
“Nice try, but it’s not backbiting if I’m right here. So, how much will you pay?”
“Insults? Really? Fine, have it your way. Prepare for ruin.” <Unveil the painting>
“Yes, money. Every week. In exchange for my silence.”
“Well, not just for me, Marguerite and Gabriel need to live as well.”
“It’s a portrait of Maximin’s secret family. Well, ‘family’ is a generous way to put it.”
“I don’t feel qualified to explain this piece. Maximin, would you like to try?”
“Why, in fact she does! Before that, she was the good Baron’s maid.”
“Well, she has to support the Baron’s son somehow...”
“He also threatened to have her falsely accused of theft, don’t forget that part.”
“Yes, he turned on her once she wouldn’t abandon her child.”
“Yes, I am she.”
“I don’t know what you’re talking about…”
“Well, you’re supposed to be smart. What does the name ‘Rose’ mean to you?”
“It’s like you said, ‘Titles don’t elevate us above consequences’. Au revoir.”
“Don’t flatter yourself. I have no intention of seeing you again, just your money.”
“How much would you pay to ensure this ‘family portrait’ never saw the light of day?”
“I’m going to live an amazing life Maximin. Enjoy paying for it.”
“It’s like you said, ‘Titles don’t elevate us above consequences’. Au revoir.”
“Don’t flatter yourself. None of us have any intention of seeing you again, just your money.”
“Marguerite and Gabriel will finally get to live a happy life, free from fear. Enjoy paying for it.”

With everyone else preoccupied, you manage to slip away from the conversation. It appears that that Camille is almost done setting up the painting. It’s on a wall with a series of other portraits, surrounded by some smaller pictures, so the eye will naturally be drawn to it.
“The painting is ready madame, all you need to do is pull off the sheet!” She whispers to you excitedly.
“Were we lovers? Of course! All I asked is that she get rid of the boy, but instead she defied me. Now she seeks to use it against me, just like I said she would.”
“I couldn’t let my work be jeopardized. Anyone would have done what I’ve done.”
Maximin may have seized one of your hands, but he should have grabbed both.
He reexamines you, studying you like an insect. “You… you really are this base?”
“How dare you? You presume to threaten me, you backbiting trollop?”
“I stand on the edge of greatness, of changing this nation, and what you want is money?”
Maximin's eyes narrow to slits. “I always knew you were a leech.”
Marcelle’s eyes narrow to slits. “I always knew you were a leech, but I'd expected better from Rose.”
In a fluid movement you snatch the corner of the sheet with your free hand and unveil Madame Le Brun’s painting. The culmination of your efforts. The culmination of your revenge.
“Behold!” Camille suddenly screams from behind you, pointing to the painting. If people weren’t paying attention to the painting before, they sure are now.

It’s just in time too. It appears that the art critic, Monsieur Gorsas has entered the room. He seems to have taken an interest in the curious image of a covered painting in the middle of a salon, and is walking over to you. A few other guests follow in his wake.
“Umm… yes! Behold.” Camille says again, quietly, before returning to her place behind you.
The painting is exactly as you remember it. An utterly gorgeous piece, and arresting in its imagery, it shows the sides of Maximin he would keep hidden from the world.

Maximin, the entitled noble.
Maximin, the secret father.
Maximin, the remorseless predator.
“What is the meaning of this piece?” Monsieur Gorsas asks, studying the painting.
“Is this true Baron Maximin? I’d heard rumors to this effect, but I’d dismissed them as fanciful slander.”
“It is… it is…” Maximin stammers, trying to think of a way to make the ghastly portrayal of himself seem like a bold artistic statement.
“Because it is slander!” Maximin nearly screams.

“So, this didn’t happen? You did not have a child with this woman?” Monsieur Gorsas asks sharply, eyes flicking back and forth between the Maximin in front of him, and his villainous aspect in the painting.
“Doesn’t that woman work at Cafe Principe?” asks a voice from the back of the crowd.
The crowd goes quiet at this statement, as they collectively start to piece together what all of this means. Eyes glance to you, to Maximin, to the painting, over and over again.
This is it. Your vengeance is nigh!
The crowd goes quiet at this statement, as they collectively start to piece together what all of this means. Eyes glance to you, to Maximin, to the painting, over and over again.
“It’s certainly one of Le Brun’s works, judging from the eyes,” the art critic notes adeptly. “It’s also a family scene. However, if I so remember Baron Maximin, you are not married… non?”
“I- I… I don’t…”  Maximin stammers, then stop. His desire to hear himself talk has finally failed him.
The already quiet room falls deathly silent, waiting for an explanation that just isn’t coming.
Slowly, murmurs of confusion build.
Hundreds of outraged voices build on each other until they form a dull roar. People press forward to question Maximin, with Monsieur Gorsas at the front.
Someone taps you on your shoulder.

Suddenly, you’re face to face with two guests that seem familiar. It takes you a moment to recognize them, but you realize that these people were present the night that your were humiliated by Maximin.
“Is this true? Did Maximin truly prey upon one of his servants?”

“Falsely accuse one of this servants of stealing from him? That’s no small crime. Mon dieu, that means she’d would have been…” the shocked guest trails off mid-sentence, as she and her partner seem to answer the question for themselves at the same time.
With a trembling hand, you reach out to grab the edge of the sheet, and reveal Maximin’s secret to the world.
"Mon dieu, and he had a child with her, but still threw her out? That means she..." The shocked guest trails off mid-sentence, as she and her partner seem to come to the same conclusion together.

The answer dawns on them. Years of rumors, and of Maximin’s capricious acts of self-preservation, each ignored individually, suddenly coalescing into an undeniable picture. Much like the one hanging on the wall, that picture reveals a terrible truth.
“And you Madame, you’re Yvette De Caux, aren’t you?” the man suddenly asks.

“I knew you seemed familiar!” The woman exclaims excitedly. Other guests start to turn in her direction, to listen. “Now it makes sense why Maximin would go to such great lengths to slander you. He tried to drive you away, just like his maid, because you knew the truth about him!”

“Non, non, it’s definitely you!” The woman exclaims excitedly. Other guests start to turn in her direction, to listen. “Now it makes sense why Maximin would go to such great lengths to slander you. He tried to drive you away, just like his maid, because you knew the truth about him!”

(You have gained a staggering amount of credibility)
(You have lost a staggering amount of peril)
The order of events there is a little backwards, but you’ll take it.
“Madame, you have down the working people of Paris, and the nation of France a great service by exposing this corrupt aristocrat’s vile past. We are in your debt.”
(You have gained a staggering amount of favor with Antoine)
“As for Maximin…” the man grumbles.

Suddenly, with your hand clutching the corner of the sheet, you feel a hand clamp down tightly around your wrist. It appears that Maximin managed to exit his conversation a little sooner than you expected.
(Maximin has been ruined)

The next few moments are a chaotic blur as you are led through what was once Maximin’s great salon by the crowd. Camille follows behind, desperately trying to keep up. Cheers go up wherever you are seen, and toasts are made.
Someone even throws you a rose.

You get the feeling as if a spell has been broken. How many of these people were Maximin’s admirers but a moment ago?

Did they always secretly hate him, or did their opinions really change this quickly?
Maximin is a predator, and got exactly what he deserves, but is justice what they actually care about? How quickly would these people, so swept up in celebration, be willing to turn on you someday?
It’s a disquieting thought, and one that almost ruins your good spirits. Almost.

You drink deep from the chalice of victory that night. You also drink deep from several, actual chalices, as you are led to your carriage. Your revenge is complete. Your victory is absolute. You are the talk of the town.

Outside, a variety of eager hands help you and Camille into your carriage. With a wave to an adoring crowd, your coachman takes off, and you disappear into the night, already a minor legend in your own right.
The mysterious country woman, who broke a monster.
“I will pay you 100 Livres now,” he growls. “Then, I will pay you 100 Livres, every week, as long as this does not reach the public.”
“What, exactly, do you think you are doing?” he hisses at you.

“If, however, you decide to betray my trust and attempt to ruin me, I will deny it all as a fanciful fabrication and drag you through so many legal proceedings that you’ll have wished you stayed in your backwards little village.”
He finally releases his grip on your wrist. He was holding it tightly enough to leave a bruise. Slowly, he produces a banknote from his coat and places it in your hand.

(You have gained 100 Livres)
(You are now blackmailing Maximin)
“Now, begone. Begone and leave me to my work.”

Baron Maximin looks at you with such venom that, for a moment, you’re certain that he’s going to strike you. Then, the energy dissipates. You hold all the cards now, not him. He angrily turns his back on you.

Baron Maximin looks at you with such venom that, for a moment, youre certain that hes going to strike you. Then, the energy dissipates. You hold all the cards now, not him. He angrily turns his back on you.

Baron Maximin looks at you with such venom that, for a moment, youre certain that hes going to strike you. Then, the energy dissipates. You hold all the cards now, not him. He angrily turns his back on you.
“I will pay you 50 Livres now,” he growls. “Then, I will pay both you and that traitorous maid 50 Livres, every week, as long as this does not reach the public.”

“If, however, any of you decide to betray my trust, I will deny it all as a fanciful fabrication. I will ruin you, I will ruin that manipulative little trollop, and I will even ruin her spawn as well.”
He finally releases his grip on your wrist. He was holding it tightly enough to leave a bruise. Slowly, he produces a banknote from his coat and places it in your hand.

Maximin stares at you, eyes widening in horror, eyes darting between the covered painting, and the approaching Monsieur Gorsas.

“What did that little woman tell you?” He whispers slowly. “That I was a monster?”

(You have gained 50 Livres)
(You are now blackmailing Maximin)
“Now, begone. Begone and leave me to my work.”
This is it. You've won.
He looks across the room and gestures imperiously to someone.

A moment later, a familiar servant approaches you. 

“You summoned me, Baron Maximin?”
The Doorman tenses upon seeing Maximin’s sour expression. “Was Madame Le Brun’s painting to your liking? Should we not display it?”
“Jérôme, your talent for understatement is surpassed only by your incompetence...” Maximin growls, fixing his servant with a venomous glare.
You consider feeling bad for Jérôme. Briefly. You consider it briefly, but he’s terrible.

“You will escort Madame Decaux and her maid from my salon, via the servant’s entrance. You will make sure that they take Madame Le Brun’s painting with them. You will do so politely, you will make sure that nobody sees that loathsome painting under any circumstances, and then you will return here.” Maximin commands tensely.
“Uh… oui Baron Maximin.” Jérôme replies, bowing deeply while his eyes frantically dart around, looking for some kind of reason for this sudden turn of events.
Maximin glances up to the covered painting, glances down to you, and notices the approaching Monsieur Gorsas. His eyes widen in horror.

After Camille takes down the painting, you and your loyal maid follow Jérôme through a winding maze of undecorated hallways, and soon find yourself outside the party. The doorman is still staring at you, unable to fathom what has gone on between you and Maximin.
You feel no need to explain yourself to him.
Instead, you simply turn your back, walk away, and signal your coachman. You and Camille slip inside, along with the painting and head home.
The best revenge is a life well lived, but it’s even better when the ones who’ve wronged you have to watch you live it.

It all dawns on them. Years of rumors, and of Maximins capricious acts of self-preservation, each ignored individually, suddenly coalescing into an undeniable picture. Much like the one hanging on the wall, that picture reveals a terrible truth.
“I took her in when nobody else would. I gave her a job, I paid her well, I did everything I was supposed to do and more.” He sneers as he whispers this at you, every word dripping with venom.

At the sound of your approaching footsteps, the coachman’s hand flickers towards his weapon. Turning towards you, he looks you up and down before he relaxes. With an apologetic nod, he gestures you towards the door of the carriage.
The door opens immediately, and the man inside steps out.

“You’re not being rude, it’s a fair question,” he replies, flicking his rank insignia for emphasis. “Every now and again, someone remembers my father and sends me an invitation as a courtesy between nobles.”

“Despite my considerable talents, I think they’re really just inviting my father’s memory, not me. Still, I attend because I’d hate to insult the host by turning them down. A comrade of mine was nice enough to arrange for me to have this carriage for the evening.” He waves around to your conveyance, which is probably only meant for officers.
“Let me turn the question around. What was a commoner like you doing at that party?”
“You’re a woman on a mission, then?” Corporal Dumas grins, offering a mock salute. “When you find him, I’m sure he’ll appreciate your loyalty. At least, I can’t imagine a man who wouldn’t.”
“How tragic” Corporal Dumas replies dryly. “He certainly wouldn’t be the first man to abandon a good woman.”
“When you find him, are you planning on winning him back, or simply getting revenge?”
“Fair,” he replies.
“Fair,” he replies.
“Fair,” he replies.

“How tragic” Corporal Dumas replies dryly. “He certainly wouldn’t be the first man to abandon a good woman.”
“Of course! I enjoy being the center of attention, and there isn’t a audience I cannot thrill,” he laughs. “From the theater to the sword, I have repartee for all occasions.”
“Is there anything else you’d like to know?”
“Of course! I enjoy being the center of attention, and there isn’t a audience I cannot thrill,” he laughs. “From the theater to the sword, I have repartee for all occasions.”
“As you can tell, I’m also extremely humble.” He gives you an exaggerated wink.
“When you find him, are you planning on winning him back, or simply getting revenge?”
“Fair,” he replies.
“Fair,” he replies.
“Fair,” he replies.
“As you can tell, I’m also extremely humble.” He gives you an exaggerated wink.
“What about yourself, what happened in there?”
Corporal Dumas nods approvingly “I saw your ‘performance’ outside, right as you left. You don’t seem very shaken.”

“When I wear these colors, I represent the Queen herself. I could never turn down a woman in need.” He straightens up in his seat, looking every bit the man of action. “Besides, it’s the right thing to do, which is its own reward.”
“Disgusting,” Corporal Dumas replies, his lips curling into a sneer. “I have no idea what our host was thinking, doing something so mindless and cruel. They should be ashamed.”

He sighs, and looks out the window at the passing scenery. “You made the right move. There’s a certain kind of person that sees sport in hurting the vulnerable, whether that vulnerability comes from circumstance, ability, or birth. They’re all the same craven creatures, that feed on feeling powerful. You can never let them see their barbs land.”
“Even when they sting…”
"You deserve better."

“Finally, someone who gets it!” Corporal Dumas slaps his thigh and laughs with excitement. “Amazing! I’ll have you know that it took me over a year in Paris to fully fully grasp that fact.”
“Let me turn the question around. What was a commoner like you doing at that party?”
“I’m glad you’re enjoying yourself. I think I’d have a hard time believing someone who felt no joy from being in Paris.”
“If it helps at all, please remember that first impressions, while important, rarely tell the whole story.”

He stares out the window at the city. “Sometimes I feel like that’s why I fell in love with this place. It does not love unconditionally, it can be infuriatingly fickle. Still, here you can climb to heights greater than any other place in the world.”

His expression becomes grave, “However, a word of caution. There’s more to this city than luxury, love, and knowledge. We’re at the center of an empire, goods and treasure from colonies all over the world, flowing in to benefit one point.”
“Yet, in a city holding a world’s worth of riches, people here still starve.”

He sighs and shakes his head “Je suis désolé, I’m being an awful conversationalist. Please forgive me. What I mean to say is that Paris is beautiful, but life here can be just as harsh and dangerous as anywhere else, if not more.”
“I’m not trying to frighten you, I just want you to exercise due caution.”
“Je vous en prie” He replies with a nod. “Thank you for taking my warnings seriously.”
“Perhaps I do. All the same, I hope you stay safe.”
He smiles. “Oh really? Perhaps I should be taking lessons in safety from you.”

Your conversation dies down as fatigue overtakes you both. Soon, there is only the sound of the carriage’s wheels and the horse’s hooves as you wind your way through Paris to your home. You’ve almost drifted off to sleep before you’re jolted awake by the carriage coming to a stop.

Your conversation with Corporal Dumas continues for the entire ride. He’s polite, forward, and seems to have a healthy respect for you. However, you find that he dodges your questions whenever the subject of his family comes up. You try to not let it bother you. Everyone has their secrets, after all.

The coachman opens the door and waves you out. As you’re stepping down, Corporal Dumas looks out the door at your home and whistles to himself. 

“You’ve chosen quite the place to live. Well, if nothing else, the rent will be cheap.”

“Until we meet again, madame!” He calls from carriage with a quick bow, as they drive off into the night. 

You turn to your home and see that Camille is already there, holding the door open for you.
“Who was that?” she asks.
You step inside and head upstairs, your mind still reeling from the day's events. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.

You’re surprised by the carriage coming to a stop. You were so lost in dialogue that you hadn’t even realized that you managed to make it home. Before the coachman can even hop off of his box, Corporal Dumas opens the door and steps down. He offers you his hand.

He helps you down effortlessly and favors you with a theatrical bow. “After braving all manners of danger, we have arrived at your home, safe and sound. The Queen’s Dragoons are proud to add another great victory to their name.”
“And while we accept no payment, I must ask of you a favor, madame.”
“How tragic” Corporal Dumas replies dryly. “He certainly wouldn’t be the first man to abandon a good woman.”
“The next time that we meet, please call me Thomas-Alexandre,” He pauses to stare into your eyes, “Or simply Alex if you like.”

You wrap your knuckles gently against the carriage door.

Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Great Hat: The Estates General has led to some interesting quandaries. The King’s made it clear that he plans to set a bold new direction for France, but has been unclear on what that actually means.
To that end, yesterday revealed one of the strangest of such pitfalls in known memory. This incident centers on the who, exactly, is allowed to wear a hat.

However, the King managed to diffuse this situation with a joke, congratulating the members of the Third Estate on their sudden, and miraculous promotion. He then manged to turn everyone's attention to the business at hand. If this was a subtle challenge to the King's authority on the part of the Third Estate, then it fell flat.

(The Crown has gained a little power)
(The Revolution has lost a little power)

At a preliminary meeting before the Estates General, the King took off his hat to salute the assembled members. In response, as per custom, all the assembled nobles and commoners removed their hats as a sign of respect. However, after this greeting, only the king and the nobles were supposed to put their hats back on, while the members of the Third Estate were supposed to remain without.

At a preliminary meeting before the Estates General, the King took off his hat to salute the assembled members. In response, as per custom, all the assembled nobles and commoners removed their hats as a sign of respect. However, after this greeting, only the king and the nobles were supposed to put their hats back on, while the members of the Third Estate were supposed to remain without.

(The Crown has lost a little power)
(The Revolution has gained a little power)

Whether it was an act of clear rebellion, or mere confusion in the face of ancient and arcane ceremony, many members of the Third Estate put their hats back on. This functionally signalled that they felt themselves the equals of the nobility, and the King.
And so, in Paris, life goes on.
For reasons that even you find unclear, this whole affair was deemed utterly scandalous. It's said that the Queen herself went pale with rage at this collapse of ceremony.

Whether it was an act of clear rebellion, or mere confusion in the face of ancient and arcane ceremony, many members of the Third Estate put their hats back on. This functionally signalled that they felt themselves the equals of the nobility, and the King.
It's not just the Queen either. Many have already seen this incident as an harbinger of more disorder to come.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Lovesick: "Father, my name is Yvette Decaux, and I am a common woman in need."
"It appears that Parisians have a very different way of entertaining their party guests."
"I'm looking for my missing fiance, but it turns out this party was held by one of his enemies."
"Imagine St. Sebastian, but with insults instead of arrows."
"I get the impression that you're not from Paris. What brings you here?"
"It's me, the woman who just got castigated by the host, then thrown out."
"I'm not happy with what happened, but I'll be alright."
"Honestly? I feel terrible, and just hope this day ends as soon as possible."
"It's fine, I thought it was interesting."
"Why are you nervous?"
"Don't worry Father, this is new to me, as well."
"Maybe I'll have to get thrown out of parties more often."
"I'm not happy with what happened, but I'll be alright."
"Honestly? I feel terrible, and just hope this day ends as soon soon as possible."
"I'm not happy with what happened, but I'll be alright."
"Honestly? I feel terrible, and just hope this day ends as soon as possible."
"Just a nice man, doing the Lord's work."
"A most intriguing young priest. Hopefully someone I'll see again."
"Thank you, Father Sidotti. Until we meet again."
"Are you sure, Father Sidotti? I can always make more enemies, if you'd like."
"May I trouble you for a ride home? My coachman was tricked into leaving without me."
"My carriage is gone, and there's no way I'm walking home in these heels. I need a ride."
You reach out and knock on the door of the carriage. The silhouetted figure jumps in surprise.
An accented voice calls out to you. “Uh… who is it?”
He stares at you for a while and almost starts talking, before thinking better of it. This process repeats a few more times, before he finally speaks.
“May I ask what happened?”

With a slight smile he exhales, looking less tense than before.

“I’m glad to see that you’re taking this setback in good humor. Not everyone would be so unflustered by such a turn of events.”
He raises his eyebrows. “What a worrying turn of events. A missing fiance, sudden enemies, and now a missing carriage. It sounds like you’ve been beset by quite the number of misfortunes.”

The young priest laughs loudly.

“I must be very fortunate, to have a martyr in my presence. I’m glad to see you made it without any extra holes in you.”
You’re not so sure if you actually feel unflustered, but it’s good that you can project it.
“While I wasn’t present for it, I heard about what our host put you through. I’m sorry you’ve had to endure such a dreadful humiliation.”
“I’m guessing then that you must be the one I’ve heard about. I’m sorry that our host felt it acceptable to treat you so poorly.”

After a few more giggles, his face turns more serious. “I heard that you were searching for your fiance, and that our host thought it would be good sport to ridicule you in front of their friends. Utterly barbaric.” He follows this up by muttering something decidedly unchristian to himself in Italian.
“Are you... alright?”
“Oh my!” the voice behind the door calls out. After some fumbling, he parts the curtains on the carriage windows.

“You’re right. I was born and raised in Rome. My family’s about as traditional as it comes, so when my parents had three sons, they knew what to do with us immediately. One man of arms, one man of letters, and one…” he gestures broadly to himself, “man of the cloth.”
“Resilience is good…” he replies trailing off for a moment. “Just make sure to give yourself time to rest. Even the most minor of injuries can wear on the soul, if left uncared for.”
“I can certainly understand why.” Father Sidotti replies. He gestures, not at you, but at your situation in general. “I hope, at least, that I’ve managed to make things a little more bearable.”

“The seminary wasn’t bad, it was the first time in my life that people were happy that I spent all of my time reading. I was ordained a few years ago and shuffled around to help with various parishes in Rome. All the older priests liked me because I didn’t talk too much.”
He blushes for a moment and stares out the window “Though, that made holding mass a little difficult for me. A lot of awkward silences.”

“A few months ago, I was pulled aside and told that I would be sent to Paris. There’s been a lot of… unrest here. My superiors in Rome wanted an outside opinion.” He pauses for a moment to fiddle with his rosary.

“You see, sending a bishop or a cardinal here, with all their retinue, would arouse too much suspicion. It’d make people think something bad was going to happen. A single priest? Nobody notices that.”
“Sorry, I didn’t mean to bore you with my life story. I ramble when I’m nervous.”
“Really?” he coughs awkwardly and looks away. “You are too kind, madame.”
“Would you believe that it’s the first time I’ve shared my carriage with an enchanting woman?”

Behind the door you hear a sputter of barely suppressed laughter.

He opens the door.
He shrugs. “Well, at least we’re on equal footing.”
A flush of color darkens the young priest’s cheeks. “While I appreciate the offer, please don’t feel obligated to make enemies just for my sake. I might not always be around to save you.”
“But what about you? Are you alright?”
“How are you feeling, right now?”

Eventually the conversation dies down, the adrenaline rush of the night’s disasters and indignities giving way to simple exhaustion. Father Sidotti settles into his books, and you occupy yourself with watching the scenery go by, and trying not to fall asleep.

The conversation continues apace for the rest of the carriage ride. Most of your free time growing up was spent reading, and ignoring your parents, so you both seem to have a lot in common. When this evening started, you didn’t expect to find yourself in a carriage, discussing Voltaire and Goethe with a Catholic Priest.

The carriage stops and the coachman opens the door. As you step down into the street, Father Sidotti leans out of the carriage to look at your home. 

“Ah, I see you have chosen to live humbly. It’s good for the soul.” He muses aloud.

“Until we meet again, madame!” He calls cheerily before the carriage drives off into the night. 

You realize that Camille is already waiting for you at the door.
“Who was that?” she asks.
You step inside and head upstairs, your mind still reeling from the day's events. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
“Hello Madame Decaux! Do not worry, I’m sure there’s something I can do for you.”
Your mind brimming with new possibilities, you step inside and head upstairs. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.

The carriage rolls to a stop, cutting him off mid sentence. You hear the crunch of hobnailed boots on cobblestones as the coachman walks to the door, but Father Sidotti opens it first. He steps down and offers you his hand.

“This has been a rare pleasure madame,” he says as you step into the street.
“Hopefully, we’ll meet again under better circumstances.”
“Please, call me Ludovico.” He says with a nod before stepping into his carriage and disappearing into the night.
“Heaven help you, if you do,” he chuckles, “And please madame, call me Ludovico.”

With a nod, Ludovico steps into his carriage, and disappears into the night.

You turn to your home find that Camille is already there, holding the door open for you.

(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
